However, programming a full-body workout of that intensity is harder to do especially if you're a beginner. The volume you do should be the same just spread out the 6 weeks. With higher frequency training you lower the intensity of your workouts. Especially on back to back days like in the image I have shown. It's also important not to train every ser to failure when doing this. Your body recovery if doing it right goes up too as you get something called the repeated bout effect. This repeate
Continue Reading
You can get the best strength and size gains doing full body twice a week and the research shows this. However, programming a full-body workout of that intensity is harder to do especially if you're a beginner. The volume you do should be the same just spread out the 6 weeks. With higher frequency training you lower the intensity of your workouts. Especially on back to back days like in the image I have shown. It's also important not to train every ser to failure when doing this. Your body recovery if doing it right goes up too as you get something called the repeated bout effect. This repeated stimulus leads to less muscle damage over time. Certain athletes do this too. This however is not necessary if you're a beginner and if you can't train 6x a week then training a muscle 2–3x a week is more than enough as long as you get the required total volume.

Well, I don’t think this man was unintelligent, just unaware of current events. This was quite a while ago, I was taking a road trip from Michigan to California meandering throughout the country. I got lost somewhere in Texas, really not sure exactly where even, driving down what could best be described as a “dusty trail”, so far off the freeway, when I spied a store. I drove up to the store and got out to get something to drink and some snacks and directions back to the freeway. There were two older gentlemen sitting on the porch and one of them says, “Ain’t that there one of them Japs?”. The other one turned and looked at me and replies, “Yep, he is one of them Japs”. Then asks me what I’m doing there. I told him I was lost and needed directions and some snacks. And he asks, “Are you here peacefully, then?” I answered in the affirmative and he said, “Welcome to the best country in the world, son”, then got up and shook my hand. “Didn’t know they started allowing y’all back in the country.” Wow! The best part of it all, he took his hat off, placed it on his chest and apologized for his nation having killed so many of my people. Well, ignorant sure doesn’t mean “bad person”.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I still shake my head about this incident.
 
Flew into Lauderdale and a friend’s mom picked me up.
 
We got on to the subject of Michael Jackson. It was the seventies.
 
She said something to the effect of “ He shouldn’t be allowed to make all that money he does!”
 
I reassured her that surely his parents would keep it in trust for him and advise him how to spend it judiciously.
 
Aaah no that was not what she meant- he ought not be allowed to keep it because he was black.
 
I knew I was not in Kansas anymore….

Q: What are the best exercises that I should be doing weekly?
 ·
 
Cardio exercises would be best if your goal is stamina and cardiovascular health. Dr. Kenneth Cooper, who spent his career studying cardio exercise and its effects, developed a point system to measure the cardio effects of different exercises at various durations and intensity levels. He recommends a minimum of 35 points per week for men, 27 points per week for women, exercising at least 4 days a week and at most 6. (He specifically recommends taking at least one day off each week.)
 
His point system tells you for each type of exercise the number of points earned for various times and distances, as shown in this table: 
https://www.cooperaerobics.com/Downloads/About/Aerobics-Points-System.aspx
 
The table starts with Walking/Running, but scroll down through the document to see the points for cycling, for swimming, and other cardio exercises, including some sports. My own favorite is 
Nordic walking
.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: This is not strictly a correct answer because it is not about someone I met but something I saw on American TV many years ago. Well this isn’t per say related to American’s ignorant about America but rather, American’s being ignorant about the world.
 
When I was in New York back in 2013, it was my first time visiting and so I was taking everything all in and loving it. So I had decided to meet one of my mates when he was there as well as he knew New York better than me as he had gone before.
 
So we arrived we needed to get to our hotel and thought the subway would have been inconvenient and so we caught a cab. Now firstly, we have crazy taxi’s in South Africa, but this guy was something else entirely. Racing through red lights, swerving to miss pedestrians, the works and while doing this he decides to create conversation with us. Now me being the naive South African, I am more than willing to chat with this guy, who seems to be of Arab descent. He then proceeds to ask the usual, based on our accents and luggage, Is it our first time in New York? Where are we from? and how long we’re staying. Now in response to the question, ‘Where are you guys from? you’ve got a strange accent’ our response was obviously ‘South Africa, do you know it?’, his prompt response was “Yeah, yeah, my wife … she’s from South Africa”, now naturally this excited me, so I’m like, “Oh, really?”, for him to then say, “Yeah man, you know Egypt right?”
 
Now at this moment my mate face-palms himself and I just keep quiet and the conversation doesn’t really go anywhere from there. Now for all you who don’t already know, Egypt and South Africa are worlds apart, let’s put that in context. South Africa is nearly 6500 kms away from Egypt, or visually:
Now for further context on this a trip from London to New York is just over 5500 kms. That really puts the size of Africa in context and the level of ignorance of some Americans.
 
Look in their defense there is so much to do, see and happening in America that I can sometimes not blame them, but regardless, this did happen.

I'm going anonymous because this person is actually on Quora. But I'm Mexican. Yes, for the ones that thing we are all racists and drug dealers, shoot me down now because I'm not afraid to say I'm Mexican. I know that those stereotypes are true for some, but certainly not for all. Anyway, let me get to my story.
 
I was commenting on a question where I was asked 
“How are you treated by others because of your nationality?”
 I was curious to see what others wrote, so I did the same. I had commented that I had been called slurs, been looked at differently because of my ethnicity, or asked to be more “American” because I have a light accent and I speak Spanish. I can tolerate all of that nonsense. However, what really struck me was a comment I got saying:
 
“Are you even Mexican? I find it offensive to some people that you are acting as a certain nationality when you clearly are not.”
 
This infuriated me. 1. This person doesn't know me to save their life and 2. It feels as if they were basically stripping me of my heritage and my culture!!
 
I was not happy. I responded with “what makes you think I'm not Mexican?”
 
They jab back saying “I looked at your profile picture. You have brown hair, blue eyes, and your name isn’t even Hispanic.” By this point I wanted to choke this person out.
 
I ended the conversation with “I think it's funny how you apparently know more about me that I do myself. First off, I'm Mexican. I was born in Mexico to Mexican parents. I've been raised with the Mexican culture. Also, I think it's quite funny how you think that all Mexicans are supposed to look brown, with black hair and dark eyes. Screw you.” Also, my last name is Italian. I’ll share my last name because that won’t give me away. My last name is 
Vía
. Which comes from Italy. My first name is from English descent. I explained how there are millions of Mexicans with Italian last names, German last names, English and Irish last names, and even Chinese last names. This even explaining how I know many Mexicans with first names from other ethnic origin besides Hispanic. Good day to that sir.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article: It is advisable to follow different muscle group/muscle movement splits. Example: push, pull & legs. Upper body or lower body. Training one muscle all days may make that muscle sore and eventually make it stiff or overuse which is not good for the body. Though a person resuming workout after a long time or performing workout for the first time may follow whole body workout for initial few days to get started.

On holiday in Ecuador in the late 90s with my then-girlfriend, we went on a 7 day boat tour of the Galapagos Islands. And on that boat was a young American woman who believed that, as a result of semi-regular viewings of the Discovery Channel on cable TV, she knew pretty much everything there was to know about the natural world. Basically the same as an advanced degree, the Discovery Channel was in her mind.
 
She also believed, it turned out, that all fish were the same species and, rather like different breeds of dog, could all breed with each other. A shark-halibut hybrid fish was just as possible in her opinion as an Alsatian-Spaniel cross.
 
She got really upset when I tried to explain that different kinds of fish were genetically distinct species and came from surprisingly different branches of the tree of life.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I met an older American lady travelling.
 
She asked me where I was from.
 
I told her Australia.
 
She said “Oh, your English is very good. Did you learn it there.”
 
Kinda shocked, I decide to take the piss and said “Nah, learnt it in the UK.”
 
She then said “That explains your accent.”
 
Then again, she might have misheard and thought I said Austria. But the Polish girl with us heard me said Australia.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: The guy who asked a tour guide in Mexico what elevation we were at while standing on the beach? The lady who asked a guide “why is it so cold up here?” while standing atop Pikes Peak? The cashier who couldn't figure out how much change to give me after I gave him $10 and 23 cents for an $8.23 item? First of all, Internet is not “very cheap”. It's over $50 a month.
 
Poor depends how you define it. Poor people often live in bad neighborhoods. But many live in nicer neighborhoods and forego extra things to get by. If you're basing “poor” on being below the poverty level, that's almost impossible to achieve these days. Poverty level is where you make a low enough amount of money to qualify for aid. However, even at mimunim wage it is not possible to work 40 hours and still qualify. These people are living on under $1,000 a month, and that's without bills and rent taken out. These people almost all have cell phones, and most have cars because a car is essential to working. If they have cell phones, they have internet. Poor isn't what you think it is. It's struggling to get by, going into debt, but still having a car and a phone.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Bad, no.
 
But not ideal.
 
The problem is the muscles need time to rest.
 
So if you want to do full body workouts every day, that is fine. But it’s not the optimal way toward muscle and strength growth.
 
Two better options:
Full body workouts three days a week with at least a day in between workouts, or
Some type of split routine, where the different muscles are never taxed two days in a row
The point is for muscles to get 48+ hours of rest in between being beaten up in the exercise routines.
 
If you like full body workouts, but you don’t want to have days you don’t exercise, there are other options for the
Continue Reading
Bad, no.
 
But not ideal.
 
The problem is the muscles need time to rest.
 
So if you want to do full body workouts every day, that is fine. But it’s not the optimal way toward muscle and strength growth.
 
Two better options:
Full body workouts three days a week with at least a day in between workouts, or
Some type of split routine, where the different muscles are never taxed two days in a row
The point is for muscles to get 48+ hours of rest in between being beaten up in the exercise routines.
 
If you like full body workouts, but you don’t want to have days you don’t exercise, there are other options for the “rest” days. You can use them for cardio. Stretching. Yoga. Long walks.
 
You certainly can, and probably should, exercise every single day. It’s good for the body. Great for the soul! But if you’re going to put your body through all that stress, you should definitely seek the path to the best results.

“Ignorant” in the UK can mean a lack of knowledge or rudeness, so if you mean the second definition, we’ve just returned from the Mississippi Delta, visiting a few towns and cities along the river starting in Memphis and finishing in New Orleans. The fabled Southern charm was almost universal, most people were friendly, garrulous and interested, we had a great time. The one exception was a young lady in the gift shop at Graceland (Graceland was a highlight, I didn’t want to go but I’m glad I did) who was VERY rude when I stood at the counter to pay for some ice creams. She looked very confused when I countered with EXTREME politeness in return, finishing with “thank you SO much, I hope the rest of your day is as pleasant as you are”. I could see my wife out of the corner of my eye laughing.

article:
Well my most ignorant American encounter was actually in the United States.
 
I live in the Central Valley of California about one hundred miles or so from the central coast.

Continue Reading
Well my most ignorant American encounter was actually in the United States.
 
I live in the Central Valley of California about one hundred miles or so from the central coast.
 
One week end my wife and I drove over to the small town of Cambria for the day. While in Cambria we decided to drive on Highway 1, the Pacific Coast Highway a little further North where there is an almost year round Elephant Seal colony on a beach near San Simeon and Hearst Castle.
 
Now this was in early September. The beaches at that time where still filled with Bull Elephant Seals, measuring about twenty feet around 6.1 metres in length and weighing in tons. Though they look like Jabba the Hut or giant slugs those critters can move at a pace that most humans get brathless running.
 
So we arrive at the parking lot over looking the beach, called a rookery when the seals are present.
 
The viewing area is on a cliff, only about one hundred feet (30 m.) high. This cliff is also topped with a wooden and chain link fence, so you can view through, but there are warning signs every few feet which include warnings about climbing down onto the beach below.
 
As my wife and I watched, a young family came along the fence, young man, young woman and a toddler as well as a baby in the womans arms.
 
There was a muttering between them, and the young man with camera climbed up and over the fence. On reaching the ground on the other side, the young woman passed the baby over to him along with a camera.
 
He then climbed down onto the beach with the baby to find one of the huge Bull Elephant Seal so he could pose the baby for a “photo opportuni...

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?
article:
Volume, particularly close to failure
 is what causes soreness.
 
So, you aren’t doing anything wrong. Some people might say:
 
“I did just one set and I got sore!”
 
Sure, if you are a beginner or detrained, you could get sore, especially if it is a high rep set. Rest-pause sets in particular really get me sore. But, if you are doing a typical low volume protocol like 3x3, 2x5 or 5x2, 10x1, etc…
even 
with heavy weights close to failure, you just won’t get that sore in most cases.
 
It’s just not 
enough
.
 
So, question answered:
 
If you are not sore on a low volume training protocol, that is totally normal.
 
A 
bet
Continue Reading
Volume, particularly close to failure
 is what causes soreness.
 
So, you aren’t doing anything wrong. Some people might say:
 
“I did just one set and I got sore!”
 
Sure, if you are a beginner or detrained, you could get sore, especially if it is a high rep set. Rest-pause sets in particular really get me sore. But, if you are doing a typical low volume protocol like 3x3, 2x5 or 5x2, 10x1, etc…
even 
with heavy weights close to failure, you just won’t get that sore in most cases.
 
It’s just not 
enough
.
 
So, question answered:
 
If you are not sore on a low volume training protocol, that is totally normal.
 
A 
better 
question would be:
 
If 
you are training for strength and size, is a low volume program 
appropriate
?
 
This is a question that comes up really, really often, and no one seems to agree-not even the literature!
 
How do you make 
THIS:
Bigger and stronger?
 
Some people do really well on low volume! Others do really well on high volume!
 
In general, I tend to recommend more volume for those that want to improve size, as the research shows that gains tend to scale quite linearly with volume. However, it might not be that clear, for a few reasons.
 
High volume training
 tends to increase 
sarcoplasm 
in the muscle. This is like your fuel tank-it includes glycogen storage as well as mitochondria for energy production needed during high volume training.
So, if you train with high volumes, your body can adapt by making your fuel tank bigger. Makes sense, right? This looks like muscle…because it basically 
IS 
muscle. It’s 
in 
the muscle and it looks like muscle from the outside. It’s muscle…just a different type.
 
But…it won’t really make you 
stronger
. In fact, pound for pound, it’ll actually make you 
WEAKER
, as it doesn’t help your strength, but does add weight!
 
It’s not contractile tissue!
Muscle is mostly water…and then protein…but there is glycogen and fat there, too. That’s sarcoplasm. Fuel tank.
 
So, a lot of these studies are switching people from low (or no) volume programs to high volume programs, and finding that their muscles get bigger. A big part of what they are often seeing is the fuel tank getting bigger in response…
not 
the actual muscle fibers!
 
I’d wager that after a few weeks of going back to lower volume training (or nothing)…a lot of those gains are going to be lost, because they body doesn’t really need as big of a fuel tank anymore. It’s temporary. It’s transient. If I do high volume and then go on vacation, in a week or two, that extra weight is GONE. It’s often up to 4–5kg, and it’s not preventable with eating more. It’s a response to training.
 
It’s a longer-duration pump.
Arnold
 
loved 
the pump…he often trained forty, fifty, sixty sets per workout before competitions. And he responded marvelously to it.
 
He bench pressed north of 500lbs when he was a young man, but during his Mr. Olympia prep, most sets seemed to be with 2–3 plates per side-just 225–315lbs, about 50–60% of 1 rep max!
 
For set, after set, after set.
Serge Nubret
 did as well-he did mostly sets of 15–20 reps far away from failure his entire career. Sometimes his workouts lasted 
FIVE HOURS
, and he did them 6 times per week.
 
Plus, he was French, so it was literally a full time job!
 
Will this work for you?
 
Maybe. But probably not.
 
Without anabolics, this type of training isn’t nearly as effective for size.
 
Most strong advocates for 
high volume training 
are on drugs.
 
Doing endless sets will just leave you tired, battered and injured.
 
However…the thing is, most strong advocates for 
low volume training
 are also on drugs.
 
The Dorian and Menzer method of one all out set to failure works for naturals…but best with pharmaceutical enhancement.
They are ALWAYS growing, so they can get away with this type of training.
 
For naturals, both high volume and low volume are death sentences for gains.
 
Why?
 
High volume
 will cause an increase in cortisol, which is very catabolic and can cause muscle breakdown. It can also cause a decrease in testosterone, and if you are natural you don’t have the luxury of ignoring that. High volume will pump you up, but after a few weeks you’ll plateau hard. Your sarcoplasm can only get so big.
 
Low volume
 isn’t enough stimulation for a natural to grow optimally in 
most 
cases. Especially if you cannot push a set close to or to TRUE failure, then low volume training will be crap for gains. Guess what? Most people cannot-or at least, do not.
 
I think in five years, I’ve seen maybe five people go to true failure in the gym…let alone go beyond failure. Part of that is because I’m in China where the gym culture is new…but I think globally, people training HARD is just quite rare. I typically train quite 
close
 
to
 
failure
.
It’s just how I’m wired.
 
For a natural, ideally you need a mix. Moderate volume most of the time, occasional high volume blocks, occasional low volume blocks with the odd week or two totally off.
 
Sometimes to failure, sometimes a few reps shy, sometimes completely avoiding it, especially if your goal is strength as well as size.
 
You need to be SMART about how much volume you do. A lot of this is individual, and you’ll have to discover for yourself.
 
Follow me on 
Instagram 
for daily diet and training tips! Subscribe to my 
YouTube 
channel for longer form, informative content.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

Actually, I used him on about 80% of my shows. He is British, from just outside of London. I never checked his visa status. Since I hired him through a lighting company, I figured he was either a citizen or had the appropriate visa. I try to stay away from political discussions with those I hire for a production. However, these last 18 months have made that tough.
I would listen to him explain how then candidate Tru
Continue Reading
I produce large conventions, what is called the content part, with sets, lighting, video, graphics, speeches, etc. I have been using the same lighting director for the last 2 years. Actually, I used him on about 80% of my shows. He is British, from just outside of London. I never checked his visa status. Since I hired him through a lighting company, I figured he was either a citizen or had the appropriate visa. I try to stay away from political discussions with those I hire for a production. However, these last 18 months have made that tough.
I would listen to him explain how then candidate Trump was “right on” about immigration. He particularly believed so about Muslims and those from South of this country. I listened as he said that he was sure most Puerto Ricans were here illegally. I explained that Puerto Rico was a US commonwealth. He stated that commonwealths were just a “system for poor and lazy” people to take advantage of the real citizens and hard workers. Now, that seemed a bit odd coming from someone living in Chicago, but from the UK. I let it go.
This went on a bit. Then, after way too many drinks in celebration of one he'll of a show, he let it slip that his visa had expired 9 years ago. However, since he was white the US would never deport him. This is a man here illegally, earning about $175,000/year. His goal he stated, was to marry his girlfriend and then he was sure to never be deported. He kept his bashing of what he called “illegals” for months.
I finally stopped hiring him. I also called the INS 5 times. I was told by the INS official that there are over 300,000 English, Irish, and French here illegally, all earning a median income of $64,000. He also said that going after these people was a sure way to stop any promotions in your future.
So, really, the dumbest or most hypocritical person was an American in name only. He hated other people here illegally. Just as bad was a part of our government who was affair to go after these people due to political repercussions.
Honestly, it was sad all the way around.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I have met many in the United States that believe the US of A is America.
 
If that is not ignorant, what is?!
 
The name comes from the declaration of independence and later repeated in the Constitution. In the declaration it is spelled ‘the united States of America’ in the constitution ‘the United States of America’. In the former clearly a denomination as ‘united’ was not capitalized, in the later they took the effort to make sure the founders convey the intent of making ‘United States’ the name of the country being created in the CONTINENT of America. Given the attention to detail the founders p
Continue Reading
I have met many in the United States that believe the US of A is America.
 
If that is not ignorant, what is?!
 
The name comes from the declaration of independence and later repeated in the Constitution. In the declaration it is spelled ‘the united States of America’ in the constitution ‘the United States of America’. In the former clearly a denomination as ‘united’ was not capitalized, in the later they took the effort to make sure the founders convey the intent of making ‘United States’ the name of the country being created in the CONTINENT of America. Given the attention to detail the founders put on the creation of this nation and its form of governance, one would think that if they intended to make the name of this nation the same as that of the continent, they would have said something, somehow, somewhere. They did no such thing.

One student stated, very loudly, “You know what really bothers me? All those people who are shouting and holding up signs…why aren't they speaking English?”

This happened many years ago, but it is what came to mind when I read this question…
 
I was teaching class, and we were discussing the U.S. invasion of Iraq. Students were discussing their various thoughts on the situation.
 
One student stated, very loudly, “You know what really bothers me? All those people who are shouting and holding up signs…why aren't they speaking English?”
 
I explained that it is unreasonable to expect people in a foreign country to protest in another country's language. She didn't understand what I meant, and the class was trying to explain to her that Arabic is the language of the people who were protesting.
 
After a while, I stopped everyone and asked her where she thought “those people" lived. She said, “I don't know…near Arizona?”
 
That is when I realized that she thought the the Middle East was next to the American Midwest! I showed her where it is on the map, and she said, “Oh! Things make so much more sense, now!”

article:

At a very general level,workout 5-6 days a week. Keep one day as Rest day.
 
If your workout program is a full bodyworkout( which is generally recommended for beginners) then I suggest workout on ALTERNATE days.
 
Later your program wil change to 2 muscle groups a day, and then you can think of going every day.
 
As far as the pain part is considered. Its just the first few days.
 
Later either the pain will make you discontinue going to the gym. Or you will accept that PAIN is a part of your life every single time you workout. 
 
Cheers, eat clean, train dirty:)

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
There is no best. There is no one size fits all routine. Generally speaking, a handful of compound exercises( No more than 10), split up over 2–3 workouts, with reps between 4–8 for upper body and 6–20 for legs works best for most.
 
There are 2 common denominators when people experience rapid growth:
When you are overtraining and you cut the volume of the workout in half.
When you have been doing the same workout(exercise selection, rep scheme, etc) for a long time and you switch everything around.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
Many people will only work the same muscle group at most 2x a week if lifting heavily. Additionally, if these are your first three days, your muscles are not accustomed or expecting this rapid jump in activity. As you continue with your workouts you will eventually get less sore. Some muscle groups may become so used to this stress they don’t really get sore anymore and will require different exercises and increased weight/intensity to get sore.
 
Don’t work a muscle that is already sore if you have only given it a day or two of rest. Be sure to stretch their full range of motion and do some very
Continue Reading
Many people will only work the same muscle group at most 2x a week if lifting heavily. Additionally, if these are your first three days, your muscles are not accustomed or expecting this rapid jump in activity. As you continue with your workouts you will eventually get less sore. Some muscle groups may become so used to this stress they don’t really get sore anymore and will require different exercises and increased weight/intensity to get sore.
 
Don’t work a muscle that is already sore if you have only given it a day or two of rest. Be sure to stretch their full range of motion and do some very light exercise with them to flush them out. You’d be amazed how much better your legs will feel after leg day if you go for a light jog the following day.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
I think full body workouts kick the shit out of split routines.
 
There’s no comparison.
 
That being said…let’s compare them!
 
Full body routine advantages
High frequency of 
muscle protein synthesis
. Compared with the split routine, every muscle group is getting hit multiple times per week, meaning that it leads to more muscle growth (see chart below, FFM 1.1% increase in the full body group vs .4% increase in the split group)
More fat loss
. Studies consistently show that full body routines cause better fat loss, often double or more of that of a split routine. (see chart below, -5.7% fat loss for full
Continue Reading
I think full body workouts kick the shit out of split routines.
 
There’s no comparison.
 
That being said…let’s compare them!
 
Full body routine advantages
High frequency of 
muscle protein synthesis
. Compared with the split routine, every muscle group is getting hit multiple times per week, meaning that it leads to more muscle growth (see chart below, FFM 1.1% increase in the full body group vs .4% increase in the split group)
More fat loss
. Studies consistently show that full body routines cause better fat loss, often double or more of that of a split routine. (see chart below, -5.7% fat loss for full body, vs -2.1% for split group)
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4885621/
Triple the fat loss and triple the muscle growth? Sign me up!
More frequent 
practice 
with the movements-that could explain why the bench results were very similar above (simple movement) but the full body group got better squat gains (more complex movement). They just had more 
practice
.
Sorry…I just love that video.
 
Full body routine disadvantages
They’re 
hard
. This is BY FAR the main reason people gravitate towards bro splits. Mentally, going into the gym and working your entire body just is on another plane of existence in terms of difficulty compared to just working one chunk of muscle, even if the volume is the same. It’s easy to tap out when you have to do front squats, RDLs, bench press, overhead press, seated rows, pulldowns, lateral raises, curls, extensions and ab wheel all in the same day.
Perhaps because of this, they can be tough on your 
hormone levels
. Check the above chart; the full body testosterone went up 11%, but the split went up 21%! Keep in mind this was just four weeks, working out just three times per week, as well. Keeping up a full body protocol all the time, for higher volumes could 
probably 
lead to reductions in T for some people.
They give you 
less time 
to 
recover
. This is part of the reason that I really am sure to use a lot of variety in my training when incorporating higher frequency. If you use the same movements all the time, be prepared for your joints to be unhappy. You need to vary the movement patterns enough that it shifts the stress on the joints at least slightly.
Split routine advantages
More 
recovery time 
for each body part between workouts.
Might have better satellite cell activation (check the answer below) due to the 
increased concentrated workload 
and greater 
muscle damage
. 
Geoffrey Verity Schofield's answer to How fast does lost muscle grow back with muscle memory?
Get a 
better pump
-doing more work in one session can lead to greater metabolic stress for that muscle.
Can help you develop a better 
mind-muscle connection. 
Yes, that’s a real thing, especially for the upper body.
Causes increased 
soreness
, which can facilitate growth and let you “feel” that muscle better. This could be a disadvantage if you don’t like this feeling…I personally kinda like it for some twisted reason.
Split routine disadvantages
Lower frequency 
per muscle group. This is probably the biggest reason why split routines suck. You do chest on Monday (obviously), and your chest is really only growing for about 36–48hours afterwards. There are 168 hours of the week-why would you only have each muscle group growing 20–30% of the time? 
Not optimal! 
Full body routines can get that number up to 70–80+% for the entire body, which explains the massive difference in both muscle gain and fat loss.
You 
can 
actually 
LOSE muscle
. In the above example, you’re growing on Monday, Tuesday and maybe Wednesday. You might be maintaining on Thursday and Friday. But especially if you are cutting or not getting in enough protein, or not sleeping well, it’s entirely possible for the weekend to be in a catabolic state.
Not that kind of Weaknd; he’s in a catabolic state 24/7
You can 
lose “touch” 
with an exercise. This isn’t gonna happen with bicep curls or lateral raises, but with something like squatting or Olympic lifting, it’s entirely possible for the nervous system to slightly forget how to do these movements if you’re only doing them once per week.
All in all, I’d do full body 
most 
of the time, but if you hit a plateau, splitting up your routine can be a nice change of pace.
 
You’ll have more time to recover, and can really focus on blasting a body part to force it to grow, perhaps through the aforementioned satellite cells. You can recover any hormonal or structural stress incurred during your full body bonanza.
 
I’ve taken a page out of Eric Helm’s book
and been doing full body workouts 4–6 times a week recently, and it’s been astonishingly effective. Tough…but the gains have been impressive.
 
But, I won’t do it for the rest of my life, as it’s not sustainable.
 
Check out my new 
Space
, 
follow me on 
Instagram
 
for daily diet and training tips! Subscribe to my 
YouTube
 
channel for longer form, informative content.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
When I was a freshman in a public high school*, there was a whole new assortment of students… all of the public junior high kids were now thrown in with the local private school kids whose schools didn't go past eighth grade. There was the big Catholic institution and a bunch of smaller church schools that many of us had never heard of. After an adjustment period, most kids adapted without too much of a problem.
 
Then there were these two girls from one of the tiny church schools.
 
I was in a couple of general courses with them and I had never seen anything like it. I don't know that they were tau
Continue Reading
When I was a freshman in a public high school*, there was a whole new assortment of students… all of the public junior high kids were now thrown in with the local private school kids whose schools didn't go past eighth grade. There was the big Catholic institution and a bunch of smaller church schools that many of us had never heard of. After an adjustment period, most kids adapted without too much of a problem.
 
Then there were these two girls from one of the tiny church schools.
 
I was in a couple of general courses with them and I had never seen anything like it. I don't know that they were taught anything at all. They were fourteen, fifteen years old and they could barely read. The teacher would ask them to read a paragraph aloud and they would stammer and sound out words until she took the awful pressure off them and chose someone else. They didn't know basic geography. If you said something about India, they would give you a blank look and say something like, “My aunt says she’s part Cherokee.” They couldn't do basic math, find Africa on a map or explain to the home ec teacher why bread dough rises. The mean-girl joke at the time was that they knew how to make Popsicle-stick crosses and sing “Jesus Loves Me” but not much else.
 
This wasn't a fringe religion or an entity like the Amish, who keep isolated schools with rules about how far children are to be educated. This was a mainstream American Protestant religion, which was what was so incredible about it. Maybe the teachers were just completely indifferent and ran it like a daily Sunday school. I have no idea, but I know that it did the girls a real disservice when they joined us.
 
*in most American high schools, “Freshman” is the first year, or ninth grade.

There is no fit answer to this question. It all depends on genetics, bodyframe, regularity, intensity, diet, age, present health etc.
 
You may be young and all enthusiastic to do this work. Maybe you are still in college and hold few responsibilities in life. You keep your target in mind and follow up regularly with workouts, irrespective of the bodypain that occurs while progressing and under qualitative coaching. Most important, you follow a right diet, alongwith right quantitative micronutrients and macronutrients, you will progress relatively faster than another individual who's just joined the gym when you have, but has something in his mind while exercising and attending phone calls while at the gym.
 
Picking weights also has a clear edge with genetics. Two individuals who eat the same and have joined the gym at the same time need not have to follow the same chart of workout after a couple of weeks. It changes according to your likes, your pros and your cons. Yes, a certain movement may be easy for you to perform with a relatively bigger weight than your colleague with comparatively less weight; and vice versa in some other movement. One of you could soar over the other somewhere. Who? How? Where?…. It's impossible to talk now; that's genetics. Then you have to work on your weaker aspects and strengthen them.
 
You will definitely pick more weight with gradual time. It's foolish to state a fixed time. Understand that the body gets adapted to a certain weight after some time and then we have to pick more, to feel that same punch there. The flow will carry on. Thus, you will definitely pick more weight after some time and maybe much more than you are presently imagining.
 
You must also understand your target. What do you want to do? Muscles, strength, lean physique, flexibility? It all can be achieved, but slowly. Only the style of training will differ according to concentration of motive.
 
So, Good Luck. Just move on.

Below is the best one week workout routine according to me.
Now as I'm an ectomorph (hard gainer/skinny), the workout plan is more preferable to ectomorph body type, but in the end I'll also state the necessary changes in the workout routine for other body types.
Monday : Chest and triceps
Pushups (warmup)
Barbell bench press 4 sets of 12,10,10,8
Incline dumbell press 4 sets of 12,10,10,8
Straight bench dumbell flys 3 sets of 12,10,8
Dips 4 sets to failure
Skull crushers 4 sets of 12,10,10,8
Tuesday : rest
 
Wednesday : Back and biceps
Wide grip pull-ups or Lat pull-downs 4 sets
Deadlifts 2 sets of 12, 10
Bent over Barbell rows 3 sets of 12,10,8
Single arm dumbell rows 3 sets of 12,10,8
Seated Cable rows 2 sets of 15,13
Standing Bicep curls 3 sets of 12,10,8
Hammer curls 3 sets of 12,10,8
Thursday : Shoulders, traps and forearms
Barbell overhead press 3 sets of 12,10,8
Dumbell overhead press 3 sets of 12,10,8
Lateral raises 3 sets of 12,10,8
Front dumbell raises 3 sets of 12,10,8
Seated bent over rear delt raises 3 sets of 12,10,8
Upright rows 3 sets of 12,10,8
Barbell shrugs 3 sets of 25,20,20
Wrist curls 3 sets till failure
Friday : rest
 
Saturday : legs
Back squat 3 sets of 15,12,10
Front squat 3 sets of 15,12,10
Stiff legged deadlift 3 sets of 12,10,8
Leg press 4 sets
Leg extensions 3 sets of 12,10,8
Leg curls 3 sets of 12,10,8
Standing calf raises 4 sets to failure
Seated calf raises or donkey calf raises 4 sets to failure
Sunday : rest
 
Do various ab exercises on rest days (Sunday, Tuesday and friday) for continuously 15 to 20 mins, these ab exercises include crunches, butt-up, leg raises, hanging clock, flutter kicks, V-ups.
 
Now for different body types
Ectomorph : 
use heavy weights with low reps and rest of 2 mins max.
Mesomorph : 
heavy weights for 12 to 15 reps with 1 min to 2 min rest. This type could train triceps and biceps on a different day that would be arms day and add more exercises to them, point being they could work out 5 to 6 days a week.
Endomorph : 
less heavy weights for more reps to burn more calories, this body type could also workout 5 to 6 days a week, but they require more cardio compared to both other types.
Hope this was helpful.

I'm Scottish and in none of the many conversations we had, did she ask one question about Scotland or the UK until the day she blew me out of the water by asking, “What language do you speak in Scotland?”

I had known, and become friends with, my 74 year old, ex middle school teacher, now American health insurance agent for about two years. We spoke often as friends and she made no bones about her disgust of American ignorance.
 
I'm Scottish and in none of the many conversations we had, did she ask one question about Scotland or the UK until the day she blew me out of the water by asking, “What language do you speak in Scotland?”
 
I'm pretty sure a certain part of my anatomy puckered up as the words left her lips. I looked at her with a mixture of disbelief, anger and despair before I was able to answer, “Swahili.” The friendship was doomed when she then, with enormous confidence and no sign of irony or sarcasm replied, “I think that's more of a middle eastern language!!”
 
Absolutely stunning and by no means an isolated incident.

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?
article:
Don't train your arms every day of you want to gain muscle. It won't work, give them 48–72 hours of recovery between concentrated training sessions.
Assuming you follow this advice, the timeline is still longer than most people like to hear. It takes about 1" of girth to visibly notice a change in size, which is ~10 lbs you need to gain. Assuming you can gain 2 lbs a month (meaning you're doing a pretty good job of training and eating) and you're looking at about 5 months of training to gain obvious muscle.

Okay, so this question addresses being poor in terms of monetary value. And while everyone is entitled to their questions and I am not challenging that in any respect, I have to ask this: why is being poor only a financial matter? What about those people who are poor with respect to peace, satisfaction or satiation of soul? Or who, despite having a lot of cash, are unable to avail different opportunities or put it to good use because of lack of clarity?
 
Being financially strong is no longer a definition of being rich or powerful or influential (in many, if not all, aspects of life). Money has become a fairly easier target to achieve. We have come across many viral blogs and videos that lacked quality content and yet, ricocheted in popularity and earned the owners instant success and fortune. And in other cases, we have heard of people losing millions in a matter of hours, even minutes. And as many examples have shown, those who have greater willpower can actually turn tables and make their lives worthy.
 
So, shouldn’t we be addressing this side of poverty that is the actual cause of many fluctuations in the lives of people and that actually affect how they turn out? Money given to an enriched mind will result in discoveries while the same given to a spoiled one will result in dust. See where the difference lies?

article:
Squat: First of all, you will never not want to be able to get up off the ground. When loaded and done properly, the squat will have positive effects on your quads, glutes, hams, abs, low back, lats, and upper back, as well as increasing stability and proper movement patterns in the knees, ankles and hips. Also who doesn't want a nice set of glutes?

Continue Reading
Squat: First of all, you will never not want to be able to get up off the ground. When loaded and done properly, the squat will have positive effects on your quads, glutes, hams, abs, low back, lats, and upper back, as well as increasing stability and proper movement patterns in the knees, ankles and hips. Also who doesn't want a nice set of glutes?
Deadlift: You're literally picking something up off the ground. Again, not something you don't want to not be able to do. Deadlifts work all the muscles worked in the squat with more of an emphasis on the back muscles, plus traps and rotator cuff muscles. Get a good deadlift and reduce chances of random back injuries. 
Bent Row: Many people have given an answer as a pressing movement. Although they do build a nice chest/shoulders, you're never really going to need to do a strict press in every day movements. Not only will the bent row improve your posture, but will also heavily tax your lats, low back, and abs. 
I've chosen these three because they're, in my opinion, the more important of the primal movement patterns to be done correctly. You will 
not
 be able to build a well rounded, show ready physique, but you can become much, much stronger in every day life and while doing the majority of every day tasks.

I went to South Korea for a year, to teach English at which this offensive event took place. A large group of us foreign ESL teachers all met up for dinner, our restaurant of choice, Indian.
 
We were a diverse group of people of all hues, hailing from the US, South Africa, India(including the restaurant owners) and little old me, from England. As we were all waiting for our meals to arrive, we engaged in polite conversation. I can't remember who I was talking to or saying, but I was rudely interr

I am from London, England. It is significant to tell you that I am also of African Caribbean descent.
 
I went to South Korea for a year, to teach English at which this offensive event took place. A large group of us foreign ESL teachers all met up for dinner, our restaurant of choice, Indian.
 
We were a diverse group of people of all hues, hailing from the US, South Africa, India(including the restaurant owners) and little old me, from England. As we were all waiting for our meals to arrive, we engaged in polite conversation. I can't remember who I was talking to or saying, but I was rudely interrupted by a girl who I think it's interesting to highlight, she was American but also of African descent, of which I found out later, her parents were also Caribbean!
 
Anyway, she interrupted my conversation rudely, asking me if my “accent was real or fake”!! I would like to point out that I have one of those cool London accents, a bit like Russel Brand from ‘Forgetting Sarah Marshall’, or so I’ve been told by another American guy I met there! She then reiterated and asked me if I was putting my “accent on”!!!
 
I was completely taken aback, a little humiliated actually and replied simply, that “I’m from London”. The rest of the time we were at the restaurant she would chuckle with her friend, every time I spoke, who interestingly was actually teaching in China and was in town for a visit.
 
So there we have it, whilst in Korea, in an Indian restaurant, with a bunch of foreigners from everywhere, an American thought it strange, that I was from England! As if, there was no such thing as a plane, travel or migration!!

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
Rule of thumb for any trainee.
Don’t try to train 4 days a week unless you are fully adapted to training 3 days a week.
Don’t train 5 days a week unless you are fully adapted to training 4 days a week.
Etc.
Don’t train more than you need to progress.
Your progress will eventually slow down or halt. You will need to add more training at this point. This is hard if everything is already dialled to 11.
If you go straight from none or light training to too much you will get injured or burned out.
For 4–5 years I used to work with a guy who was rather overweight and unfit. Once or twice a year he would de
Continue Reading
Rule of thumb for any trainee.
Don’t try to train 4 days a week unless you are fully adapted to training 3 days a week.
Don’t train 5 days a week unless you are fully adapted to training 4 days a week.
Etc.
Don’t train more than you need to progress.
Your progress will eventually slow down or halt. You will need to add more training at this point. This is hard if everything is already dialled to 11.
If you go straight from none or light training to too much you will get injured or burned out.
For 4–5 years I used to work with a guy who was rather overweight and unfit. Once or twice a year he would decide to get fit and come to me with his training and diet plan. It was invariably extreme with a diet of oatmeal and protein shakes and smoothies, training 6–7 days a week with weights, bootcamp calisthenics, bike riding and running.
 
Every time I would advise him to reconsider. Eat normally, just a little less than usual, train three times a week, start by getting stronger, walk a bit daily. He would nod thoughtfully and go back to his navy seal hell week business.
 
He never ever stuck to his plan longer than two weeks and he is still just as unfit as he ever was, only more overweight. Don’t be like him.

Lady: “Are you from Ireland?” (I can only guess it was the acce

Unfortunately, I’ve only been to the US once, to visit family.
 
I was a child at the time, the second youngest of five. We were all excited as it was our first trip abroad and a big event when you’ve got five kids (age range from 7 to 16) My poor parents manage to stagger off our flight from Glasgow and we get through passport control. My father hands over our family passport (still allowed at that time) which clearly stated that we were UK citizens. The lovely lady in passport control then had the following conversation with my dad:
 
Lady: “Are you from Ireland?” (I can only guess it was the accent)
 
Dad: “No, we’re Scottish.”
 
Lady: “You’re Scottish. Oh my! Your children speak such good English!”
 
Dad: “Er… thanks. It’s actually the language we speak in Scotland.”
 
I still wonder how someone could work in passport control, regularly process planeloads of Scottish people and not know that everyone in Scotland speaks English.

I met a woman who believes that “scientists” put a chip in her brain to track her and read her thoughts. A close runner-up is a guy I know who believes that we did not land men on the moon. He believes a lot of other wacky conspiracy theories. Me! The most embarrassing and culturally ignorant thing I ever said was when my coworker Khalil was going to go on a trip to Lebanon for five weeks. I wished him well and said "watch out for those Palestinians, I hear they can really be trouble." He told me with a dead pan expression "I am Palestinian." The blood drained from my face as I realized I had heard about Israelis and Palestinians on the news all my life but had no idea who these people were. I admitted my ignorance and my embarrassment, and told him that I needed to educate myself about all the people of the world and the struggles they experience, and that that was an eye-opening moment for me. I decided then to become more culturally aware and quit letting my middle-class white upbringing narrow my view of the world.

You workout properly by deciding if you want to build muscle or build strength( and yes building strength will give you muscle, but not as much as a bodybuilder)

(which is a good choice btw) then you need a exercise that target all muscles at the same time.
 
These exercise are the best for building muscle strength:
 
Sumo-deadlift
Pull ups/chin ups(When you are able to do 20 pull ups, then you would be ready to do them with weights)
(Don’t think of other exercises than these two)
 
Now, you may ask how to do you do it. You do it by using progressive overload.
 
Progressive overload
 
It means you add 2,5 kg per week in your workouts. Let’s say you sumo-deadlift 20 kg. Next week 22,5 kg. next week 25 kg ,27,5kg, 30 kg and so on.
 
If it’s pull-up/chin up then you add 1 reps every week. Fx 2 pull up in week 1. 3 pull up in week 2. 4 pull up in week 5. 6 pull up in week 6. Simple, right?
 
2–3 times a week
 
See which one works best for you.
 
Diet:
 
Potatoes/brown rice(high carb= insulin better muscle growth)
 
All kinds of meat(just eat till you are full) It’s a myth that you need a lot of it.
 
Don’t run marathons
 
Running is great but more than 3 miles is unnescarry. HIIT or sprinting is better for fat loss and athlisme.
 
If you choose muscle building
 
Then you have to do a so called chest day, tricep day. Fx.
 
Monday: Chest & tricep
 
Thursaday: Back and biceps
 
Wednesday: Legs and shoulders
 
Thursday: abs
 
Friday: Idk, you choose
 
You choose isolation exercises like bicep curls and tricep extension.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was on a language trip with an American family. They were really nice people, but I was baffled by how little they knew about anything outside of the United States. My favorite moment was a discussion with their eldest son, who was around 15 at the time.
 
“Do you have cars in France?
 — Are you kidding me?
 — Well… No.
 — What is the brand of your mom's car?
 — ‘Pew-jawt’* why?
 — It’s pronounced ‘Peugeot’ and it’s a French brand.”
 
He then went to tell his mother what he had just discovered. It turned out she didn't know either.

“Do you have cars in France?

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I once interviewed someone who couldn’t explain his own job. As in, the very highly paid job that he had been doing for over a year.
 
I explained his job to him.
 
Then I asked him what I’d just told him.
 
He still couldn’t explain the job.
 
So he didn’t get the job.
 
Another time, I talked to a guy who’d spent a year as an exchange student in Paris.
 
I said, “Oh, Paris, that must have been great.”
 
“It’s OK, I guess.”
 
“Well, what did you do while you were there? Anything interesting?”
 
“No, nothing special.”

I once interviewed someone who couldn’t explain his own job. As in, the very highly paid job that he had been doing for over a year.
 
I explained his job to him.
 
Then I asked him what I’d just told him.
 
He still couldn’t explain the job.
 
So he didn’t get the job.
 
Another time, I talked to a guy who’d spent a year as an exchange student in Paris.
 
I said, “Oh, Paris, that must have been great.”
 
“It’s OK, I guess.”
 
“Well, what did you do while you were there? Anything interesting?”
 
“No, nothing special.”
 
Nothing special. In Paris. For a year.
 
Not food. Not romance. Not a good book. Not something seen through a window or out walking. Nothing.
 
I told him I’d give him five minutes to make something up. Anything.
 
He couldn’t or wouldn’t.
 
So he didn’t get the job either.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Whilst travelling in Mexico an American tourist complimented me on my good English language skills, to which I thanked her and told her I was from the UK. 
She said “oh, the UK! Do you learn English there?”
I thought she was joking so laughed and just said “of course” to which she replied “but British is your first language right?”
 
Whilst on the same trip, actually on the same tour bus, a different American asked me where I was from. This time I said England so that they’d not have the confusion over English again, to which he replied “oh is that near New Zealand?”.

For reference, literally everyone in this little anecdote are in America and have (presumably) lived here for at least a little while
 
I have a friend in middle school. She is not the ignorant person. Neither is her mom, who also comes into play here.
 
What my friend 
is 
is athletic as heck.
 
She's thin and lanky, she walks or bikes the couple miles to school and back each day (which she chooses depends on weather), and she's won more than a few awards for the school's track team.
 
Her mom makes sure she and her younger sister (also thin and lanky) get plenty of good food to eat. Not just good-tasting food, but good-for-you food.
 
My friend recently discovered she has high cholesterol despite all this.
 
Her mom called the doctor's office to schedule an appointment for her, and answered the secretary when asked what the appointment was about.
 
The secretary is the one who's about to get roasted like my brother's blackened smores marshmallows.
 
The secretary has Friendmom stop right there, and basically says, "I can tell you how to fix this right now."
 
"Great!" Says Friendmom. "How?"
 
"Make your daughter eat less fast food, play fewer videogames, and get more exercise."
 
Let me make this clear:
 
My friend is very athletic, way more athletic than I've ever been. She eats healthy, another thing I'm sadly lacking in sometimes. She's like a really really strong twig, while I'm closer to a mushy rock. Yet my cholesterol is fine, and hers is not. And this secretary is refusing to schedule an appointment for her and is instead telling Friendmom what she would have to do if Friend was dangerously fat.
 
Needless to say, while I can't remember who Friendmom said hung up first, I'm pretty sure Friendmom laid into the secretary pretty hard.
 
How that person got a job in any part of the medical field, I don't think I'll ever know.
 
(Yes, I know high cholesterol can go with being overweight, and often does, and that the mother might be trying to play the victim here, (internet stories, my guy) but a thing I do a bunch with the sister is pick her up and spin her around with my weak noodle arms. I could easily do that with this friend if I wanted to, I just do it more with her sister becaus it was easier when she was a baby and I was a Big Girl™ :D (meanwhile friend and i have been closer in age and size basically our whole lives))

Yes I am Poor materially
 
I come from a family of 6 being the first child, I studied Economics for my bachelors and worked hard to pay for my post graduate diploma in computer science.
 
During this program, my dad was retrenched without benefit from a bank where he worked for 16 years. My mum is a trader and my immediate younger brother is a very intelligent boy who is currently on a 4.5 GPA in his second year studying accounting.
 
His education is threatened as my father has no job. The other two younger once had to stall their tertiary education because of finances
 
I worked as a teacher and is still been owed a month wage, got another job although doesn't pay well, it keeps me busy
 
I love to learn, at this stage I don't really care for the money, I want the experience so I bought a power bank and a beat up laptop to learn how to program, I am still striving.
 
I want to intern, get relevant experience and learn but situation at home wouldn't allow. My wages goes straight to the family, no social life, I know that my sacrifices today will be rewarded in future.
 
But it is hard. My biggest fear is not having the opportunity to showcase my talent, to learn. I need to do things for myself but family over everything.
 
I am optimistic. I know I am poor materially that is and this has made me insecure, scared. What happens if I leave my family to pursue my dream. My younger ones such bright kids yearning for that opportunity to go to school but…………..
 
I can't deny them that, I have to work hard to make sure they realize their dream. If only things were better.

A mixed workout is the best way of training for me, and it might as well be the same case for you. As someone who has been working for long hours during the day, it is not possible for me to hit the gym every day of the week (although I want to). I can afford to go for 4 days at max, no matter how much I love working out, I understand that prioritizing gym before my work is not a good option for me, personally. This is why I try to cover my entire body during those 4 days.
At first, I struggled to find a workout split that would help me do all workouts in 4 days, but then I saw the push pull legs workout. I started following that, and the results were amazing. I even researched the whole mixed workout thing, and I understood that doing a mixed workout every day is better than the typical bro split, at least for me. You can easily target different muscles of your body and can focus more on compound lifts. These lifts help you burn more calories, build more muscle, and improve your strengths. Compound lifts also help you raise your testosterone levels, which is another advantage.
 
Not only does it saves time, but it also helps you target each muscle group in a short period of time. I have been following the mixed workout split for almost 3 years now, and I do not feel like going back to the same old bro split, as my body feels way better working out like this.

title: What is your gym routine?
article:
I start with a dynamic warm-up. Forget about just jogging on the treadmill; I’m talking about getting every muscle group ready for action. Think leg swings, arm circles, walking lunges, and hip openers.
 
The goal here is to get the blood flowing, the joints lubricated, and the nervous system primed. By the time I’m done with this, I’m in ignition mode - ready to dominate the workout ahead.

I start with a dynamic warm-up. Forget about just jogging on the treadmill; I’m talking about getting every muscle group ready for action. Think leg swings, arm circles, walking lunges, and hip openers.
 
The goal here is to get the blood flowing, the joints lubricated, and the nervous system primed. By the time I’m done with this, I’m in ignition mode - ready to dominate the workout ahead.
Strength is the foundation. Without it, everything else falls apart. I hit the gym four days a week, focusing on compound movements that target multiple muscle groups. Here’s how I break it down:
Day 1: Push Day (Chest, Shoulders, Triceps)
Bench presses, overhead presses, dips, and push-ups. I mix up the rep ranges - some days it’s heavy with lower reps, other days it’s lighter with higher reps. This keeps the muscles guessing and growing.
Day 2: Pull Day (Back, Biceps)
Deadlifts, pull-ups, rows, and bicep curls. The deadlift is my bread and butter here. It’s a full-body movement that’s as functional as it gets, teaching the body how to move a heavy load safely.
Day 3: Leg Day (Quads, Hamstrings, Glutes)
Squats, lunges, leg presses, and Romanian deadlifts. Leg day is sacred. I go hard here because strong legs are the foundation of a strong body. I finish with calf raises because, hey, balance is everything.
Day 4: Functional Day (Core, Mobility, Full Body)
Kettlebell swings, Turkish get-ups, farmer’s walks, and core work. This is the day where I mix it up. The goal is to build functional strength - strength that translates to real-life activities. I focus on stability, coordination, and mobility, making sure my body is not just strong but also agile.
I’m not about that endless treadmill grind, but cardio has its place. After my strength work, I like to finish with high-intensity interval training (HIIT). It could be sprints, battle ropes, or a quick circuit of burpees, box jumps, and mountain climbers.
 
The idea is to get the heart rate up, torch some calories, and build endurance. This usually lasts 15-20 minutes, but it’s enough to leave me drenched in sweat and feeling like a warrior.
 
Every session ends with a solid 10-15 minutes of stretching and mobility work. I focus on the areas I hit that day, making sure everything stays loose and limber. This is crucial for recovery, injury prevention, and keeping the body moving smoothly. I throw in some yoga-inspired moves because flexibility is just as important as strength.
 
Rest days are just as important as workout days. I take two full days off each week to let my body recover. This is when the magic happens - muscles repair, grow, and get stronger.
 
I stay active with light activities like walking or swimming, but nothing too intense. I also make sure to get plenty of sleep and fuel my body with the nutrition - testosterone booster, healthy fats, and carbs to keep my energy levels high.
 
My gym routine is a living thing. It evolves as I do. If something isn’t working or if I hit a plateau, I switch it up. I’m always learning, always pushing the boundaries of what my body can do. The gym isn’t just a place to work out; it’s a place to challenge myself, to grow, and to become the best version of me.
 
So, that’s my routine - a mix of strength, functionality, and a mindset that’s always hungry for more. It’s not just about building muscle; it’s about building a body that’s ready for anything. And trust me, when you approach the gym with this mindset, the results go way beyond the mirror.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was in this place:
Oxford University Museum of Natural History · Parks Rd, Oxford OX1 3PW, United Kingdom
★★★★★ · Natural history museum
https://maps.app.goo.gl/3Kco1zmo54vfKepx7
Utterly superb, the whole history of life on earth layed out for ease of understanding, supported by all of the academic rigour of one of the finest research and educational institutions in the world. A day was not enough!
 
There were three young Americans who walked in and hurried around in about 20 minutes, I initially assumed they were students, and then one turned to the others, and announced to the world:
 
“This place is so typically biased! It's all atheism and evolution! Nothing about creation or the designer!”

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was at Windsor castle in England showing a Japanese friend around. Windsor Castle is just a few miles west of Heathrow Airport so many planes can be seen starting their descent to Heathrow. An American tour group was nearby...A man in the tour group, on seeing a plane piped up "Gee, why did they build this castle so near the Airport?". Stunned Tour Guide replies "You do realise they started building this castle nearly a thousand years ago?" 
American man "Gee I thought it was a Disney Castle...."

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I never met these people, but I heard this story from a British person who had lived in Texas. A local person once said to him, “You’all speak English real good. What language do you all speak over there in England?”
 
I told this story to another British person who had also lived in Texas and expressed my surprise & disbelief. He confirmed that this had happened to him, too. I doubt if it was the same person.

I don't know why this question specifies Americans- perhaps the author has something against Americans? But nevertheless, as an American, I will answer.
 
My 12 year old son's father, by far! We split & he had full custody for a short time, before it graduated into joint custody. During this time, my son was enrolled into kindergarten. His father was telling me, quite proudly, about the process of enrolling him into kindergarten, ‘since I had never done so’. He was simply boasting at the fact that he had full custody (at that point in time), & telling me about how they require medical insurance information for enrollment.
 
I said “That's just a section on the form to fill in, in case there is a playground accident or something & he has to be taken to the hospital- so they have the info to present the hospital, or if there is a specific hospital that he needs to be taken to”. He adamantly rebutted what I said, since ‘I have never enrolled anybody in kindergarten, so I obviously wouldn't know what is necessary’. He truly thought/thinks that medical insurance was a necessary requirement to be enrolled in kindergarten! I tried to explain, saying “It is a federal requirement for children to attend school from 5-16 (+ or - in different states). With that being the case, how could the government possibly hold a 5yr old accountable for his parents’ having/not having medical insurance? That's insane! “.
 
He continued to insist that indeed it is necessary for every 5 year old to have medical insurance to be enrolled in kindergarten. I then said “What about illegal aliens?”. As we live in California, there are many illegal aliens enrolled in school, enrolled in University (many times with scholarship), working jobs, living in apartments, etc. He answered “Illegal aliens don't send their kids to school”. Crazy!! We live in the midst of a lot of them, from places near & far alike (Mexico, China, India, Guatemala, Cambodia, Vietnam, Korea, Eritrea, etc.).
 
No matter what I did, I could not convince him that 5yr olds can't be held accountable for making sure that their parents have provided medical insurance for them, so that they can go to a state-mandated institution.
 
The scary part? This man is vice president of Engineering in the tech company he works for. And this is not a mom & pop, fly-by-night company.

Ok sooooooooooooo I know a bunch of people did some stuff on Geography so I don’t really want to tell stories about that… Now I hope everyone knows what water is…
 
Now I haven’t physically met people but some people like me, who enjoy laughs by creating purely idiocy crap to see who will believe it… Created a website that was trying to ban “dihydrogen monoxide” or water. But, they never put the fact that it was water… they just used other terms and claimed all these funny facts (which actually are legitimate) like you can die from drowning or it can be combined to create lethal chemicals or is an ingredient in explosions.
 
Now here’s the funny part… One of my HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS threw this into class to show the kids (he knew what was up, I figured it out when he pulled out the page) and everyone was FREAKING OUT. Then our teacher shows us the magic of naming elements… and then he talks about people are SIGNING PETITIONS to ban this “dangerous” compound. Here’s the link to the website.
 
Facts About Dihydrogen Monoxide
 
Now granted people don’t know chemistry… but you have to admit… it’s pretty damn funny.
 
EDIT:
 
Sorry I realized I forgot of this one instance… I was working at one of those food places at games and this guy wanted 2 sodas (one for him and one for his wife). I give the sodas, and I confirm which one is which (I think one was like Coke and the other was dr pepper or something…) ANYWAYS he asks me if I’m sure which one is which. I say yes. Now normally I would let this pass because the pictures are flipped (so let’s say the image for rootbeer is on the far left when you face the cashier… It’s on the left for me (so it would seem like I’m putting in something else. BUT HE TASTED IT AFTER I GAVE IT TO HIM AND TOLD HIM WHICH WAS WHICH… like WTF if the sodas taste the same, then just get the same soda SMH

It's been two and an half year since I miss my family. I was rich when I was in India with my family. I was rich when I was doing a small pay scale job. My brother and I, were working for different MNCs and used to stay in same flat. Though we did not stay with my family during weekdays yet we used to travel home every p
Continue Reading
Poor…!!
 
The word poor, can be referred in many ways. So here is my view..
 
I am an Indian, came to USA for masters, completed and doing an IT job for an year now. I could buy a car and can start planning for a best life here but I am still poor..
 
Don't you believe? Read below then!
 
It's been two and an half year since I miss my family. I was rich when I was in India with my family. I was rich when I was doing a small pay scale job. My brother and I, were working for different MNCs and used to stay in same flat. Though we did not stay with my family during weekdays yet we used to travel home every possible weekend to spend time with my parents.
 
Imagine how beautiful it is to travel four hours to go home with an elder brother, halting bike at every food station to have food and to exchange the ride.
 
My parents do not expect money from us but presence with them. I didn't spend a single day here in USA that makes me feel rich. My parents are farmers, and most of my happiest moments are the moments that I spent time with my family.
 
I am from a completely rural village, I have a joint family with my parents, an elder brother, two sisters and their husbands, four nephews, and a niece. My life before coming to USA was like a daily festival since we don't use technology (smart tv/mobile, computer, and no internet) in our daily life. Our happiness was in being together, working together and living together which I am missing now.
 
So I am poor without their presence and those wonderful moments.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
I encourage a 4-day upper/lower split as a better option personally but if you really want to do a 5-day routine instead of 4 that has a 2x a week frequency per muscle group then you just move one upper/lower split to a push-pull-legs approach.
 
It’s pretty simple to execute but harder for most to adhere to, which is why I usually don’t bother. You can get enough volume with a 4-day upper/lower split, you’re just distributing 2 days into 3 shorter days.
Mon
 - Lower
Tues
 - Upper
Wed 
- Lower
Thur 
- Upper Push
Fri 
- Upper Pull
Or whatever variation of that you prefer.
 
Some people find this psychologically

I encourage a 4-day upper/lower split as a better option personally but if you really want to do a 5-day routine instead of 4 that has a 2x a week frequency per muscle group then you just move one upper/lower split to a push-pull-legs approach.
 
It’s pretty simple to execute but harder for most to adhere to, which is why I usually don’t bother. You can get enough volume with a 4-day upper/lower split, you’re just distributing 2 days into 3 shorter days.
Mon
 - Lower
Tues
 - Upper
Wed 
- Lower
Thur 
- Upper Push
Fri 
- Upper Pull
Or whatever variation of that you prefer.
 
Some people find this psychologically comforting or something, I assume because it aligns with their work week and they love going to the gym after work every day or before work every day consistently. I don’t know … I do know almost every time a client of mine insists on doing this within 3–6 months they invariably fall back to upper/lower 4x a week instead.
 
There isn’t much of an advantage in lifting 5x a week over 4x a week in my view, so save yourself one trip a week or do some cardio is usually what I tell people.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
“Contend makes poor man feel rich whereas discontend makes rich man feel poor.” - 
This is my One of the Principles which I read 6 times daily.
 
For some people who have big house, expensive gadgets and enough income, Yes I am poor. I don’t have my own source of income, I have to depend upon my mom.
 
But for many who don’t even have their own house, good food to eat, clothes to wear, Yes I am rich.
 
So, it depends. It depend a lot on where you live, how you live, and with whom you compare. And also how much contend are you.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Not only can you MAINTAIN muscle with this approach, you can GAIN a shit ton of it.
During the silver era, all the bros trained their full body 3x a week, and look at them!
 
You can bet your bottom dollar they’re all natural, as steroids hadn’t even been invented yet.
 
Back To You:
 
The question you should ask yourself is how long you want to spend in the gym.
 
If you’re willing to spend 2+ hours you can be sure you’ll maximise your muscle growth potential with a full body workout.
 
If you’re pressed for time however you can probably get about 80% of the gains in an about an hour if you train hard enough

Back To You:
 
The question you should ask yourself is how long you want to spend in the gym.
 
If you’re willing to spend 2+ hours you can be sure you’ll maximise your muscle growth potential with a full body workout.
 
If you’re pressed for time however you can probably get about 80% of the gains in an about an hour if you train hard enough.
 
Remember that a workout split is simply a method to distribute volume throughout the week.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In my ninth grade geography class, we were discussing New England and some historical events that happened there in pre and post revolutionary war times. The Boston Tea Party came up and I kid you not one student said, “I thought Boston was a state and Massachusetts was the town in England Puritans came from.”
 
The teacher had no words, bless his heart. He calmly corrected the student as he stifled his chuckling.
 
This kid went on to become a cop in the same town as my high school. Which, even 10 years after graduating, is a source of humor for me.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was working as a reference librarian in College Station, TX years ago. We would cooperate with the schools in providing materials for student assignments. This particular assignment was to write about a Medieval personage, with Joan of Arc being the most popular.
 
The evening before that assignment was due, a black woman walked in with her daughter looking for materials on Joan of Arc. As diplomatically as I could, I explained that all the materials on Joan of Arc were checked out, and recommended she pick someone else. The mother asked who, and I suggested St. Thomas Aquinas. When the woman a
