I was working as a reference librarian in College Station, TX years ago. We would cooperate with the schools in providing materials for student assignments. This particular assignment was to write about a Medieval personage, with Joan of Arc being the most popular.
 
The evening before that assignment was due, a black woman walked in with her daughter looking for materials on Joan of Arc. As diplomatically as I could, I explained that all the materials on Joan of Arc were checked out, and recommended she pick someone else. The mother asked who, and I suggested St. Thomas Aquinas. When the woman asked who he was, I explained that he was the greatest of the Catholic philosophers and theologians. Well, this woman looked at me like I had told her she stunk. She told me, “My daughter ain’t doin’ no paper on no Catholic!”. Then she said to her daughter, “c’mon honey, let’s go get you some books on Joan of Arc,” and stormed out.

I grew up in an above average suburban Southern community. Average house price: $400,000. All economic and education factors were in the top 10% nationally.
 
Unfortunately, my H.S. Geography class was a general haven of ignorance. I was dubbed a Satanist for referencing the Theory of Evolution in passing. The kid who led the class in the New Salem Witch Trials against me had failed 9th grade twice, and this was his third go-around.
 
The Poster-child for ignorance was a girl we’ll dub Susan. Susan was not particularly bright, a veritable Valley-girl stereotype, largely concerned with doing make-up, hair, and finding herself a man. Don’t get me wrong, she was nice enough and pleasant, but this girl had firmly established herself as an idiot over the course of the semester.
 
Eventually, as happens in Geography class, she was asked to locate 
Russia 
on the map, and couldn’t do it. Pretty embarrassing. Ok, locate 
China
. Couldn’t do it. Locate 
Canada
. Couldn’t do it. Pretty bad, huh?
 
Locate the US on the map.
 
Couldn’t do it.
 
This girl couldn’t locate her own country on a map.

Not sure I can answer because it did not happen to me but to my father.
 
I am French, and so is my father.
 
Now my father is retired, but in 1984 he was an urban planner. He went to Mission Viejo (California) for a professional travel, to learn how this new city was designed (it was designed and built during the 1970s and early 1980s following an innovative urban planning scheme).
 
During the travel, my father visited some brand new houses, the American guide showing to the group of visitors the wonderful home devices and appliances that made the happiness of American people.
 
Once, with pride showing the object next to him, the guide said “here, in the USA, we have microwave ovens”, as if it was a performance or an honour. This guide simply did not know that, in Europe, we also had microwaves in our homes.
 
Guess what, we also have vacuum cleaners, and even electricity and water! I’m kidding, but the guide was not, he seriously thought his country so much ahead of all others…
 
I remember this anecdote very well because, to ignorance, this guy added arrogance. That said, every country has a lot of stupid, ignorant and arrogant people, USA does not detain the exclusivity.

I recently followed the Mind pump guys on YouTube. Very smart longtime personal trainers and simalar experience as me in my career. I was doing bro split workouts forever and often fighting plateaus for my own progress. Yet I was often doing 2–3 full body workouts for my clients cause it fit best with their schedules and they were having great success with that. Why didn't I apply that to my own program???? Cause I just thought I could and should of been doing 5–6 workouts a week. The mind pump guys shared this also and said they started making a lot of progress themselves when they did 3 full body workouts a week. By hitting each muscle 3 times a week but giving your body more rest overall allows more muscle growth. Also I used to waste a lot of time working on isolation exercises and wasn't doing much the second half of the workouts anyways I still do a little mobility, stretching and walking on off days. I have made a lot of progress and the effort throughout the week is much less. It's crazy! With that being said it's still good to switch it up. I'll do an upper/lower or push/pull/legs split time to time.

At school I learnt to play rugby, something that I kept up for a few decades afterwards. After I left school I would usually drive myself to games, but from time to time we would take a coach and then out would come the rugby songs. Communal singing is a great way to build team spirit, but when you get lots of young men together the subject matter gets somewhat questionable.
 
It has been quite a few years now, but if I give you some of the titles I am sure you can find the lyrics somewhere on the internet if you want (and don’t care what is in your browser history).
Four and twenty virgins (came down from Inverness)
Prick of steel
Oh! Sir Jasper
Royal Marines (In the depths of deepest Africa)
Do your balls hang low? Can you swing them to and fro?
Of these the second is probably the dirtiest.

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?
article:
For best fitness, combine aerobic, strength, and flexibility workouts into your daily routine.
Cardio exercises include exercises like jogging, swimming, cycling, and dance.
Weightlifting, strengthening exercises work, or bodyweight exercises like pushups and squats are all examples of strength training.
Stretching, yoga, Pilates, and other flexibility activities can assist increase flexibility and lower the risk of injury.
>> Hope this will help. STAY FIT AND HAPPY.

One of the most rewarding moment in my life would be,that i get a great pump in my biceps also when I perform some back exercises.The exercises are
 
1)Chin-ups-(3 sets* 14,12,10 reps)
 
2)Barbell row under-hand grip -(3 sets* 14,12,10 reps)
 
3)One-arm Dumbbell rows-(3 sets* 14,12,10 reps)
 
4)Underhand or reverse grip Lat pull down-(3 sets* 14,12,10 reps)
 
5)Seated cable row-(3 sets* 14,12,10 reps)
 
These exercises works both my back and biceps alot. Lemme explain the form for theses exercises
 
1)chin-ups-*You grip the chin-up bar in a underhand close grip and bring your body up until your chin is above the bar and then come down again and repeat the form.
2)Barbell and dumbbell rows-*Both of these exercises should be done in a controlled manner,you should extend your arm to the full extent and then row again.
 
*Your back should in a proper position or you might face injuries and miss the benefits of these exercises.
 
*Barbell row should be done with Underhand grip.
 
3)Underhand or reverse grip Lat pull down-*These should be done with underhand close grip at the same width of your shoulder width or grip the bar at the end of the horizontal part.
 
*Pull the bar all the way to your upper chest and then fully extend your arms the way up in a controlled manner
4)Seated cable row-*You should pull the V-bar till you touch your torso while your arms are close to your body and extend your back and arms fully when you go back to the original position,
All these exercises should be done in a
 controlled manner and always breathing at the proper time will assists you to perform these exercises in a professional and beneficial manner.

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
My favorite is a combination of Pepato cheese and fresh mint. Pepato has got that bold, peppery flavor, adding depth that harmonizes awesomely with the refreshing zesty zest of the mint. Its unison creates a delicious contrasting mix of sharp and creamy cheese with the freshness of the mint. It is a great twist on a classic sandwich and something you must try if you want to elevate your level of sandwich making!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The word “ignorant” means a couple of things to me. One, about someone who might just not know about something. Maybe they’re not well-read or have experienced in something basic I take for granted. They’re willing to learn—maybe just shy.
 
Ignorant can also mean someone who is deliberately small-minded and always goes for the stupid response or the shortest solution.
First: I was on the phone recently about an order of our office supplies with a help desk person. She’s nice, patient, and always helpful. We had to unravel some glitch or something. My boss’s name was Cairo at the time. She said sh
Continue Reading
The word “ignorant” means a couple of things to me. One, about someone who might just not know about something. Maybe they’re not well-read or have experienced in something basic I take for granted. They’re willing to learn—maybe just shy.
 
Ignorant can also mean someone who is deliberately small-minded and always goes for the stupid response or the shortest solution.
First: I was on the phone recently about an order of our office supplies with a help desk person. She’s nice, patient, and always helpful. We had to unravel some glitch or something. My boss’s name was Cairo at the time. She said she couldn’t even try to say the name. What’s his name? she asked. How do I say that? I pronounced it and said it’s that big capital city in Egypt. The capital of Egypt. Cairo. My heart sank a bit, and part of my mind felt snarky; but I also remembered that the company we deal work employs handicapped people as a priority. She may not have traveled much out of her home state or read much. I have no idea. But I answered her question gently and helpfully.
Second: Several times in the Mid-West, service industry people suspected I might be dishonest because I was from New York City. Also, sometimes people thought I was some sort of person-not-to-be-messed-with, , i.e., some kind of thug or crook, because I was from NYC. Both types had me silently shaking my head, but it was frustrating
As for the second type of ignorant, which from anywhere—deliberately small-minded, nasty, in a hurry to put someone down. Small-minded mean. They relish how much they don’t know about something or someone. The kind of person who is just plain mean when they sense they have an opportunity: there are too many to mention. I don’t keep track and I’m older; so, I just try to figure out whether someone is just ignorant or, ignorant. I also try to maintain my calm and engage gently and decently. Humor helps.
I’ve witnessed a lot of ignorance (of both kinds) from non-US, supposedly educated folks, too. I don’t say that to shift blame, but it’s interesting how it goes.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Ignorance is relative, subjective, and tilts towards intolerance based on personal disposition.
 
I know more than my brother does about building a backyard deck; I have done it, he hasn’t. I also know about replacing a vehicle’s radiator, having done so, while my wife is ignorant of this know-how. That I manage my own stock portfolio puts me at a different knowledge advantage than a dear old friend of mine who makes a livelihood skillfully dissecting turkeys for packaging, a skill I lack.
 
These people in my life can easily point out a thing or two at which I’m hopelessly inept, making me perhaps 
Continue Reading
Ignorance is relative, subjective, and tilts towards intolerance based on personal disposition.
 
I know more than my brother does about building a backyard deck; I have done it, he hasn’t. I also know about replacing a vehicle’s radiator, having done so, while my wife is ignorant of this know-how. That I manage my own stock portfolio puts me at a different knowledge advantage than a dear old friend of mine who makes a livelihood skillfully dissecting turkeys for packaging, a skill I lack.
 
These people in my life can easily point out a thing or two at which I’m hopelessly inept, making me perhaps the most ignorant person at whatever their particular level of aptitude. But they are tolerant enough to not condemn me for falling short of their quantity of knowledge. I, too, am tolerant of their so-called ineptitude. And I resolve to be always tolerant of everyone in and outside of this great country, well aware that our America, one of the most livable places in our world, is home to some of the most able humans, each of whom may know or are adept at something that lifts them above being denigrated as knowing nothing.
 
Pointing out the most ignorant person among us? How full of self, unenlightened. How condescending. How dare you.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I have to answer this question because the conversation I am about to share destroyed any previous impression (basically good impressions) I had had towards US people.
 
I was an exchange student when I was a high school student. There was one day my host dad and I were talking about North Korea; then we were talking about nuclear weapon.
 
Then my host mom came and said,

4 refreshing and delicious sandwiches!
 
Nutritionally balanced, healthy, delicious and filling!
 
One bite is rich in layers, full of ingredients, so satisfying
 
Put your favorite ingredients and you can have breakfast in a few minutes~
 
-
 
🔺Ham and egg sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, ham slices, eggs, tomatoes, lettuce, cheese slices
 
[Method] Fry a poached egg, fry the ham slices with the remaining oil, put lettuce, tomatoes, poached eggs, ham slices, cheese slices on the toast in turn, cover with another piece of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Taro and pork floss sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, taro , purple potato flour, milk, seaweed meat floss
 
[Method] Steam the taro, add appropriate amount of purple potato flour, milk, sugar substitute, and beat into taro paste. Spread thick taro paste on both slices of toast, spread seaweed meat floss on one slice and press it, cover with another slice of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Mango and crab stick sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, mango, crab stick, tomato, lettuce, salad dressing
 
[Method] Tear crab stick into strips, slice mango, put lettuce, mango slices, crab stick, salad dressing on toast in order , tomato slices, cover with another piece of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Cheese and corn sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, corn, ham, meat floss, cheese slices
 
[Method] Squeeze the cooked corn kernels and ham cubes with salad dressing and mix well. Spread meat floss, cheese slices, and corn and ham salad on the toast in turn, cover with another piece of toast and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Mango yogurt sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, mango, solid yogurt
 
[Method] Pour the yogurt into gauze and suspend it in the air, refrigerate Filter out the whey overnight, take out the solid yogurt and stir it until smooth, spread a thick layer of yogurt on both slices of toast, put half a mango pulp on it, cover it with another slice of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Kimchi beef sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, beef, kimchi, eggs, cheese slices, seaweed shreds
 
[Method] Fry a poached egg, fry the beef slices with seasoning, put the poached egg, seaweed shreds, cheese slices, beef slices, kimchi on the toast in order, cover it with another slice of toast and wrap it with plastic wrap

According to the U.S. and Indiana state governments, I live several thousand dollars per year below the poverty level for a family of five.
 
You might have a hard time believing that when you look at my life.
 
I know I fit the label. I shrug, and accept the food stamps—every little bit helps—but I don’t make a big deal out of it. I live quite frugally, but life isn’t bad—a house, three healthy kids, two old, ugly, but reliable cars, and no credit card debt—I’m not stupid enough to get myself into that trap. I don’t get cable, I haven’t bothered to replace the flip phone I lost weeks ago, and I almost never go out to eat. My kids get free lunches at school, and the state covers them for health insurance.
 
I don’t care about the label much. My needs—and even a few of my wants!—are met, and I do my best to be content with it.

Assuming you mean financially poor, I would qualify. My social security, and only income, is below the U.S. poverty line for a family of three. That includes my wife and one of her grandsons who lives with us. If we lived in the U.S. I imagine it would be stressful. Here in Mexico, we are fine.
 
We live in a small (38 sq. meter/400+ sq. ft) house. My wife owns it, so we don’t pay rent. If we did, it would be the equivalent of less than $150 per month. We are in an area with good public transportation, so we don’t need/have a car. We pay what would be about $550 USD per *year* for health insurance via the government health system. Unlike most financially poor people, we have savings that amount to about $4,000 USD. Barring a real emergency, it is untouchable.
 
Twenty five years ago, I had a low six figure income. All things considered, my life now involves less stuff and less stress. I have no complaints… and I don’t feel poor.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
In working out a day, it shouldn’t take you more than 1hour for low-intensity workouts. Also, For high-intensity workouts, you shouldn’t take more than 30minutes.
 
The reason is that when you take longer than necessary time to workout hoping to get more achievement from it, it backfires because instead of your body releasing HGH hormones, the workout forces your body to perceives stress.
 
Then your adrenal glands make and release the hormone cortisol into your bloodstream. It is often called the “stress hormone,” and cortisol causes an increase in your heart rate and blood pressure.

This one I was told by my father and dates back to the ‘60s.
 
He was a researcher on high power cables at a major Italian manufacturer, actually one of the technological leaders, especially in the field of submarine cables (none of the leaders was American at the time).
 
During a business trip in the USA in the mid ‘60s he engaged in some small talk with a group of American businessmen, I can’t remember if it was at his hotel or at an airport. Hearing that he was Italian and working in the field of electric power they made some questions and were surprised to hear that electricity was available at almost all homes in the country, and in all western Europe, including small mountain villages and little islands. One commented that it must have been such big change in his (my father’s) life when the Americans brought electricity “after the war” (meaning WW2). It was hard for my father to convince them that Italy pioneered hydro power in Europe in the late 19th century and that the first thermal powerhouse in Europe (the fourth in the world) went in operation in his hometown. He still remembers how skeptically they took his words.

Hello!
 
A daily physical activity is the best. Depending on your fitness level, goals and schedule of course. If you’re trying to lose weight I always recommend at least 5 times per week/ 1 hr. If you’re trying to keep yourself fit and strong, from 4 to 5 times per week is good.
 
I don’t recommend exceeding 60 min per day and not less than 45 min if your intention is losing weight. I personally still do 1 hr of Nia 4 to 5 times per week and don’t need to lose more weight. This is only to stay in good shape. My personal experience has taught me that if you exceed 60 min every day you run the risk to hurt your body over time. You want to make sure you can keep workingout freely and effortlesly for the rest of your life :)
 
Choose a physical activity that is pleasurable for you. The body just wants to feel good! In this way you’re making sure you’re not going to get bored and then drop out. I suggest dancing, swimming, biking, hiking, fast walking, yoga, Nia and martial arts
 
Always make sure you pick a workout that is going to provide your body with the 5 sensations: agility, mobility, strength, flexibility and balance. Just as in nutrition, our bodies need from these 5 sensations in order to receive a whole physical conditioning that’s going to lead us to whole health and it’s the best way to stay fit
 
I hope this helps,
 
Emma

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
Here are some recommendations for a well-rounded weekly gym workout routine:
2-3 days of strength training, focusing on compound exercises that work multiple muscle groups like squats, deadlifts, bench press, pull-ups, etc. Aim for 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps per exercise.
2-3 days of cardiovascular exercise like running, cycling, rowing, or swimming. Aim for 30-60 minutes per session at a moderate to high intensity.
1-2 days of lower-impact exercise like yoga, Pilates, or light jogging/walking to allow for recovery.
Be sure to allow for 1-2 rest days per week where you do light activity or no exercise 
Continue Reading
Here are some recommendations for a well-rounded weekly gym workout routine:
2-3 days of strength training, focusing on compound exercises that work multiple muscle groups like squats, deadlifts, bench press, pull-ups, etc. Aim for 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps per exercise.
2-3 days of cardiovascular exercise like running, cycling, rowing, or swimming. Aim for 30-60 minutes per session at a moderate to high intensity.
1-2 days of lower-impact exercise like yoga, Pilates, or light jogging/walking to allow for recovery.
Be sure to allow for 1-2 rest days per week where you do light activity or no exercise at all. This is important for muscle recovery and injury prevention.
Vary the exercises, rep ranges, and intensity from workout to workout to continually challenge your body and avoid plateaus.
Don't forget to properly warm-up before each session and cool down/stretch afterwards.
The specific exercises and time allotments can be adjusted based on your fitness level, goals, and available time. The key is to have a balanced routine that hits all the major muscle groups and incorporates both strength and cardiovascular training.

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
That depends on three things:
 
1.) What state your body currently is at
 
2.) What state you’d like to be
 
3.) What you’re willing to do (time, energy, money, etc) to achieve those goals
 
How strong are you? How old are you? What ailments are you currently facing? What sports do you want to play? How strong do you want to be? What’s your body-fat percentage? What do you want to look like?
 
There’s absolutely no ONE BEST WORKOUT. There’s millions of good ways to do it, which is best for you depends on the above three questions.

It was not uncommon to see CNN personalities, rappers or aspiring actresses passing through the first floor lobby.

About 20 years ago I was working in the high-rise CNN building in Hollywood. There were numerous other businesses in the building including an ad agency, a record label and a casting office. It was not uncommon to see CNN personalities, rappers or aspiring actresses passing through the first floor lobby.
 
One day I walked up to the first floor elevator at the same time as one of the CNN anchors. Already standing there were two women in their early 20’s, actress types, most likely heading to the casting office on the 5th floor. They had already pushed the button for the elevator.
 
When the door opened, they both looked up at the number illuminated above the door, which read “1”. They looked at each other and didn’t make any effort to enter the elevator. Before we could walk around them, the door closed again.
 
They pressed the button again and the door reopened. They looked up at the number “1” - and again did nothing. The door closed and they once again pressed the button.
 
The door reopened and one of them finally said “Let’s just forget it and take the stairs.” As they turned, one of them looked at us and said “Who ever heard of an elevator that only goes to the first floor?”
 
When the elevator door reopened, the CNN anchor and I finally went in. There was dead silence for several floors while each of us undoubtedly tried to make sense of what they had just said. Finally, the CNN anchor said, “One of them I could maybe understand but NEITHER ONE of them knows how an elevator works? I wonder how often they lock themselves in their car.”

My husband and I once lived next to a very sweet girl (early 20s), who unfortunately, had very little exposure to other countries or cultures.
 
She once asked my husband: “So, what church do you go to?”
 
Hubby: “I’m Muslim.”
 
Neighbor: “You’re Mormon?”
 
Hubby: “No, I’m Muslim.”
 
Neighbor: “What does that mean?”
 
Hubby: “I believe in Islam.”
 
Neighbor: “What does that mean?”
 
Hubby: “It’s a religion. I’ll explain it to you later.”
 
Apparently, this young woman was not aware of the Islamic religion or of Muslims. You’d think that most Americans would have heard of Muslims at this point, but apparently, she had missed the memo.
 
Edit: Followup Conversation.
 
Many people have asked how the followup conversation went. When he tried to explain Islam to her, she was quite surprised to learn that there were other religions besides Christianity. She basically thought that religion and Christianity were synonymous.
 
We also explained Buddhism, Hinduism, and a few others. She had heard of Judaism, but she had thought that that was a branch of Christianity, like Catholicism. She had no idea that different people in the world believed different religions.

The Mental Battle
 
The battle to start a workout isn’t fought in the gym; it’s in your head. It’s like psyching yourself up before taking the stage to give a speech. The thought of exercise can be intimidating, but it’s the mental game that makes all the difference.
 
The Five-Minute Trick
 
Now, here’s the magic: just focus on the first five minutes. It’s like telling yourself, “I’m going to dip my toes in the water, and if I’m not feeling it, I’ll get out.” Those first five minutes are like a test run, a warm-up for your body and your motivation.
 
Starting Is Winning
 
Once you push through those initial five minutes, you’ve already won half the battle The momentum starts building, and the workout suddenly feels doable.
Setting Achievable Goals
 
The first five minutes are about setting achievable mini-goals. You’re not aiming for a marathon; you’re going for that first jog around the block. By breaking your workout into smaller, manageable chunks, you’ll find it much easier to tackle.
 
The Motivation Spiral
 
The fantastic thing about the first five minutes is that they trigger a motivation spiral. Once you start and feel your heart pumping, your body will often tell you, “Let’s keep going!”
 
Consistency Over Perfection
 
It’s not about having the perfect workout every time. The key is consistency. Even if your workout isn’t flawless, those first five minutes can be a consistent starting point.
So, here’s the secret: start with the first five minutes. It’s your secret weapon against workout procrastination. Once you dive in, you’ll often find the motivation and energy to complete your workout. It’s a mental game, and you’ve got the power to win it. Embrace those first five minutes, and soon, you’ll be the fitness stand-up hero you’ve always wanted to be! 🏃‍♀️🏋️‍♂️
 
If this helps you in anyway, please support me by upvoting sharing, and follow me for more!

So the night before my flight, exhausted from overworking myself and packing, I open my notebook that I had been practicing questions in and and quickly jot down the flight times, gates etc and rip it out. and flew out the very next day to the US, landing in Chicago.

I’m British-Indian and muslim. I flew to the US for the first time a few years ago. I had my final exam in Analogue Electronics and my flight was the next day. So the night before my flight, exhausted from overworking myself and packing, I open my notebook that I had been practicing questions in and and quickly jot down the flight times, gates etc and rip it out. and flew out the very next day to the US, landing in Chicago.
 
I land in the US and check in to immigration; empty my pockets along with the paper which coincidently had part of a circuit schematic and notes such as ‘pin 2 to ground’ at the back and forgot about. The officer gets suspicious and starts asking me about it and I explained why it’s there. I then get the ‘random search and interrogation’ by customs officers and interviewed about what countries I visited, he got really confused that I had a British passport and that I was telling him i’ve never been to Pakistan (he didn’t seem to be able to grasp that not all south asian people are from Pakistan). He carried on asking me how is it I’m from England and hold a British passport so I had to explain to him British history from the 60’s onwards. He also interrogated me about the circuit on the back of the paper, luckily I had my student ID card with me. I was convinced I was heading to Gitmo after they saw that.
 
My luggage got held up because of flights being cancelled so only had my hand luggage. Another officer escorts me to pick it up and check it; he was satisfied and proceeded to ask me “How is it you know such good English?”. It really puzzled him that I wasn’t white and from England - what shocks me more is that this is US immigration officers i’m talking about, let alone the public.
 
Edit: Also forgot to add my friend had flown out a few days prior and when he got interviewed, he was asked the question: “Have you ever had any military training?” he answered with “Does Call of Duty count?”, the officer wasn’t too impressed and replied “No, I mean any 
real
 military training”.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
The workouts are only as effective as you make them to be in terms of intensity and what your goals are. Also, consider time it takes for recovery. It’s difficult for muscles to become stronger and bigger if they do not have adequate recovery (nutrition/sleep included).
 
The days do not matter on which you train. I’d recommend a M/W/F split for full body if your schedule allows for it.
 
Just for some self-validation, I’ve trained for 8 years (currently 23), won a drug-tested physique competition, trained clients as a personal trainer, and have a bachelors degree in Kinesiology (“exercise science”)

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
There’s no straight answer to the question without considering your training experience, current goals, etc.
 
If by “maximum gains” you mean building the most amount of muscles possible (naturally), then you need to be the strongest version of yourself while taking care of the other parameters like nutrition, stress, recovery, etc. Full body training has been proven to aid in the process better than body part split routines in general because of factors like increased frequency of training each muscle, adequate rest & recovery, etc.
 
On the other hand, body part split/bro split routines have been 
Continue Reading
There’s no straight answer to the question without considering your training experience, current goals, etc.
 
If by “maximum gains” you mean building the most amount of muscles possible (naturally), then you need to be the strongest version of yourself while taking care of the other parameters like nutrition, stress, recovery, etc. Full body training has been proven to aid in the process better than body part split routines in general because of factors like increased frequency of training each muscle, adequate rest & recovery, etc.
 
On the other hand, body part split/bro split routines have been used by people over decades with great success with respect to building muscles; hence we cannot discard the process entirely. I feel the mind-muscle connection can be established in a bro-split routine better than a full body, strength focused routine.
 
In my opinion, there are just way too many variables in a bro-split routine to manage, track, and progress. It also requires way too training days to be effective. I would always recommend a well structured, well periodized full body routine to a beginner-intermediate lifter who seeks strength and muscle gains. It usually takes 3–4 training days a week to make excellent progress.
 
If you don’t mind spending some money, I would recommend 
Barbell Medicine
; they have excellent training templates for pretty much any goals that you have. If you’re looking for free resources, you can check out 
Brian Alsruhe’s
 YouTube channel; he has good guidelines to create your own program. If you’re an absolute beginner, you can go for 
Starting Strength Linear Progression
 or 
StrongLifts 5x5
.
@PallavPanda

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
The best workout routine depends on your individual goals, current fitness level, and personal preferences. Here are some general guidelines for an effective workout routine:
Aim for 3-5 days of exercise per week, with a mix of cardiovascular activity, strength training, and flexibility work.
For cardiovascular exercise, options include brisk walking, jogging, swimming, cycling, or using an elliptical machine. Aim for 150-300 minutes per week of moderate-intensity cardio.
Strength training 2-3 times per week, focusing on major muscle groups like the legs, back, chest, shoulders, and arms. You can
Continue Reading
The best workout routine depends on your individual goals, current fitness level, and personal preferences. Here are some general guidelines for an effective workout routine:
Aim for 3-5 days of exercise per week, with a mix of cardiovascular activity, strength training, and flexibility work.
For cardiovascular exercise, options include brisk walking, jogging, swimming, cycling, or using an elliptical machine. Aim for 150-300 minutes per week of moderate-intensity cardio.
Strength training 2-3 times per week, focusing on major muscle groups like the legs, back, chest, shoulders, and arms. You can use free weights, resistance bands, or bodyweight exercises.
Include 10-15 minutes of dynamic stretching and mobility work before workouts, and static stretching afterwards.
Progressive overload is key - gradually increase the intensity, duration, or weight over time to continually challenge your body.
Allow for rest and recovery days between sessions for the same muscle groups.
Consider your individual needs, such as any injuries or limitations, and adjust the routine accordingly.
The most important thing is finding a sustainable routine you enjoy that helps you work towards your fitness goals. Experiment to discover what works best for your body and lifestyle.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
To see results from your exercise routine, it is generally recommended to exercise at least three to four times per week. This frequency allows for sufficient stimulus to the muscles and cardiovascular system while still providing adequate rest and recovery. However, the optimal exercise frequency can vary depending on your goals, fitness level, and the type of exercises you're doing. Here are some general guidelines:
Cardiovascular exercise: Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week. This can be spread acro
Continue Reading
To see results from your exercise routine, it is generally recommended to exercise at least three to four times per week. This frequency allows for sufficient stimulus to the muscles and cardiovascular system while still providing adequate rest and recovery. However, the optimal exercise frequency can vary depending on your goals, fitness level, and the type of exercises you're doing. Here are some general guidelines:
Cardiovascular exercise: Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week. This can be spread across multiple days, such as 30 minutes of cardio on five days a week or 50 minutes on three days a week.
Strength training: Incorporate strength training exercises at least two to three times per week. Allow a day of rest between sessions to give your muscles time to recover and grow. Focus on targeting all major muscle groups with exercises like squats, lunges, push-ups, and rows.
Flexibility and mobility exercises: Include stretching and mobility exercises at least two to three times per week, or even daily if possible. This helps improve flexibility, range of motion, and prevents injury.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
This happened 12 years ago. I wanted to take my driver’s license and went to the DPS office. They asked me to fill-out a form. In it was a column for race. I checked the box for “Asian/Pacific Islander”. I gave the form along with my ID which was my Indian passport.
 
The lady at the counter called me and asked
 
“You ticked the wrong box in the race section”.
 
“No, that’s correct. I am Asian”.
 
Raises my passport “But your passport says India”.
 
“But India is in Asia”.
 
“Oh I thought Asia is in China”
 
True Story.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Back in the late 80's I took a road trip to see a famous
 faith healer 
and televangelist (I'll call him Reverend Saul David for this story.)
 
I was learning gospel stylings on the organ for theater, and this preacher-guy had one heck of a musical show to show me the ropes! Think of the 
church scene
 in the movie 
The Blues Brothers
, and you'll have a pretty good idea of the concert I attended that night! 
It rocked!
 
Amen!
 
I am not a believer in all that faith healing stuff. If you are, that's cool. I don't want to offend you, but probably will if you keep reading my answer.
 
Perhaps you should stop read
Continue Reading
Back in the late 80's I took a road trip to see a famous
 faith healer 
and televangelist (I'll call him Reverend Saul David for this story.)
 
I was learning gospel stylings on the organ for theater, and this preacher-guy had one heck of a musical show to show me the ropes! Think of the 
church scene
 in the movie 
The Blues Brothers
, and you'll have a pretty good idea of the concert I attended that night! 
It rocked!
 
Amen!
 
I am not a believer in all that faith healing stuff. If you are, that's cool. I don't want to offend you, but probably will if you keep reading my answer.
 
Perhaps you should stop reading my answer right now if you have ever:
Ordered Holy Prayer Water or similar products from a religious representative during any late-night, paid t.v. advertisement.
Sent your money to religious representatives who raise money for their ministry primarily through their television audience.
Previously been medically-proven paraplegic, had hands laid upon you, and were suddenly healed by the Holy Spirit, and were able to 
rise up
 and walk out of your chair in front of amazed congregants.
If any of these points resemble you, kindly switch over to someone else's answer, because what I am about to say may insult your core belief system. And I don't want to hurt your feelings. I respect that 
you
 believe what you believe. I just don't see eye-to-eye with you.
 
As for the rest of you who are still here, I'll get to describing the venue:
 
The Reverend had rented a large community center/gymnasium out in a rural area, beyond the subdivisions and where the busses stopped running after dark.
 
It was in Chico, California. At that time, Playboy magazine had named it college party city #1 in the USA, so I was a bit worried about how I was going to find my way back into town, in the dark, when I was at
 “ground zero”
 with all the 
freaks
 in town.
 
I entered the building. I was early, with plenty of time to kill, as I'd taken the last bus out on the route, and it was still two hours 'til “show time.”
 
I was met at a reception table
,
 and asked to fill out an information card.
 
It asked my name, address, ailments, worries, how many children I had, financial status, and basically all the information any reasonably “psychic” faith healer would need to know about a person in order to pull off a convincing show.
 
A-HA! Gotcha!
 
I got my seat assignment and sat down.
 
Front row. Next to a nice old couple. She, in a wheelchair. We had a couple hours to shoot the breeze as the room filled up.
 
Nice folks.
 
At one point she needed to use the facilities and asked that I wheel her to the Ladies Room.
 
I obliged.
 
Relieved, I watched her get up and 
walk
 out of her chair
,
 and enter the stall. At one point I worried I might have to go in there with her and help her out, but she was fine on her own.
 
She could walk.
 
The show started right on time.
 
The Reverend Saul David was introduced, as the band geared up and played some 
wonderful
 gospel tunes and he danced around, waving his arms, bobbing his blonde head, smiling (even as his eyebrows were scowling in a creepy way) and everybody clapped their hands and praised Jesus. That was the fun part!
 
The music was 
delicious
. Rich. Inspiring. I'm still a fan of gospel and learned a lot of technique that night. You wouldn't know if you heard me play piano, that I wasn't raised a Southern Baptist. I took to the style like a duck to water. It exudes essence, and soul, and truly touches me. I love the music!
 
But then the music 
stopped
.
 
The fun ended. I suddenly found myself being held hostage for 
hours
. A lot of 
boring
 talking.
 Preaching. Fire and Brimstone.
 
Blah blah blah. 
My eyes glazed over. I wanted to leave, but like I said, I was in the middle of nowhere, way out of town. It was dark, and I really didn't know exactly where I was.
 
The freakiest part of the evening came when the good 'ol Rev started picking people out of the audience.
 
“There is someone here,” he began, “someone who recently lost a son. And God wants you to know, 
Sully
, that 
Tony
 is beside him in Heaven and is just fine.”
 
And Sully would whoop and weep. Relieved that his kid was okay in the Afterlife.
 
“Someone here has been suffering from arthritis. 
Lily
 has owned a bakery for years and can no longer knead her bread!”
 
At which point, my seat neighbor, the one I'd taken to the Lady's room, let out a startled gasp, and put her hand over her lips in astonishment! She was eating that stuff up.
 
The Reverend made his way over to our row and grabbed onto the old woman's head and started speaking gibberish, 
“Loobagoda Brigga Nighga Shwopa-fumanigha poo Veggie lool roog bon FWEEEEEE!”
 
(My eyes went wide. I was suddenly frightened.)
 
“IN THE NAME OF JEEEZUS-AH, YOU WILL BE HEEEEELED, NOWA! Stand up and WALK!” 
He 
screamed
 directly into her face, and I watched, bird's eye view, as 
spittle
 flew from his mouth, into her open eyes and drenched her face.
 
She was weeping as she stood, wobbly at first, then raising her arms started walking up and down the aisles!
 
The congregation erupted. Talking in tongues, arms raised, standing, stomping
,
 as the organ chimed in and accompanied such an amazing “
miracle” 
taking place!
 
The Reverend took her wheelchair
,
 and kicked it, 
actually kicked it, 
away (I was hoping the old lady got it back later.)
 
Oh, the tears did flow!
 
At the end of the evening, the Reverend, tired of making fake predictions by getting information fed to him in his secreted earpiece from the cards we'd filled out before the “show” started, had us all line up and went down the queue, “healing” us one-by-one.
 
He was grabbing heads and 
literally
 pushing people backwards into the arms of his assistants. When he got to me I didn't fall over, I 
resisted, held my ground
 and I laughed in his face.
 
He looked pissed off.
 
Luckily, he didn't point out I was possessed by the devil or anything, or I might have been torn to shreds by the fanatics in that room!
 
Finally, after four hours of exhausting bullshit, it was over.
 
People were gladly handing over a good portion of their paychecks at the reception table as they filed out of the room.
 
Leaving the show, I ended up collecting my jacket from my seat. I met the old couple there, and said farewell.
 
I watched them as they slowly began to walk away, the husband escorting his fragile wife as she painfully took each step and leaned heavily on his arm.
 
“Don't you want your wheelchair?” I asked, as I pointed to it, still sitting in the corner, where the Reverend had kicked it earlier during his sermon.
 
She looked me straight in the eye and said:
 
“Oh no! I've been 
healed by our Lord, Jesus Christ!
 I will never sit in 
that
 thing again!”
 
..And off toddled the most ignorant American I've ever met.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
Yes, we exist! And we are economically poor but mentally rich.
 
I will try to keep it short. I am sharing my story here because I believe it will motivate many depressed souls struggling in life. I didn't know about this platform until yesterday when my colleague told me about it. Thanks to him.
So, my name is Aniket Bharadwaj. I have been brought up in Wardha, Maharashtra and belong to a poor family (not BPL though). Basically, my dad is a farmer. We don't own any land and therefore, my dad works on big farmers and landlords’ field as a laborer. We used to own some land in the countryside Wardha
Continue Reading
Yes, we exist! And we are economically poor but mentally rich.
 
I will try to keep it short. I am sharing my story here because I believe it will motivate many depressed souls struggling in life. I didn't know about this platform until yesterday when my colleague told me about it. Thanks to him.
So, my name is Aniket Bharadwaj. I have been brought up in Wardha, Maharashtra and belong to a poor family (not BPL though). Basically, my dad is a farmer. We don't own any land and therefore, my dad works on big farmers and landlords’ field as a laborer. We used to own some land in the countryside Wardha but we had to sell every inch of our land as my dad was indebted by my grandfather who was cheated by moneylenders .
 
My dad is illiterate and he knows the importance of education. He never let my studies get hampered. One time meal could be sacrificed but not my education.
 
I attended village primary school which was 8 km away and we ( my younger sister ) had to walk up and down. I remember how my dad used to motivate me during my Maharashtra board papers.
 
I have also seen days when we had to sleep empty stomach. Due to bad pricing of sugar in market or a bad produce, there were days on which we had nothing to eat.
 
I specifically remember one day , on which my father was abused by moneylender as he wanted money to finance my education but they said ,
 “education is unnecessary. Take your son to field with you and repay our loan ASAP".
 
But, since my father knew the importance of education, and hence he took loan of double interest , and 
since then I never looked back
.
I am indebted to my father for making me realise importance of education and he stressed that education is the only thing which can change our family's condition and take us out of misery. Finally, today, I can proudly say that we are in a much better condition. I studied at a good University in Pune. Thanks for my school headmaster's son for helping me. He was sent by God, literally! Such souls still exist on this cruel planet.
 
I have given almost every exam and cleared them but sadly, neither my dad nor my friends could support me more. I couldn't go to Kota for JEE preparations. But I had decided that
 I will, someday, join some premier institute as a faculty to help out poor students (economically) like me. 
And I started earning at a coaching from last month.
 
I am still economically poor but I believe in myself. I believe God is not that merciless. I have seen my Dad struggle and I promised him that he doesn't have to work anymore. I will pay back all the loans and shut the mouth of money lenders.
I would like to share some pics of my village with you:
 
My Dad working ❤️
My eldest brother. Yeah, he is quite older than me.
 
 
 
 
My 5 star room :)
My dad threw a party. Yes, after many days, we got a reason to celebrate.
Our house is not so big. This scene is from a neighbor's veranda.
My library where I used to study as there was no light or fan in my house. Took this pic with my new phone. Bought a second hand Redmi. This pic makes me feel rich. Never thought I would own such mobile phone. Love you father. Had he pushed me into farming, I won't be writing answer on this site today.
My old phone.
These are my nephews. I gifted them these clothes from my first salary.
 
This is my favorite spot. I used to come here with my village head's cattles. Thankfully, I don't have to do this anymore. But it was an exciting thing.
I hope this answer motivates you. And I am here to help you all.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I can’t say she’s the most ignorant American I ever met but certainly she didn’t pay attention in school.
 
I worked with this young woman and one day we were discussing the Pacific Northwest. I was stating that my parents lived in Washington state, and that that whole area was one of my favorite places in the world. She asked if I meant Washington DC and I said no, that’s in the eastern United States. Washington state is on the north West Coast. Up until that moment she did not know that the US included Washington state AND Washington DC. I don’t know how she graduated high school.

Sadly I cannot answer with ‘the most’ but rather it’s a ton of Americans who have asked me the exact same question! First I must say that I am Canadian, living in Canada. It started the first time that I went to Mexico on vacation with a bunch of friends. A group of guys asked us if we all lived in different size igloos, are all igloos the same? WHATTTT? SERIOUSLY? So, for the longest time my friends and I would actually contemplate as to whether or not they were just pulling our legs or not.
 
Fast forward 15 yrs. later and I’m living just outside of Seattle. Again, I was repeatedly asked this same question from time to time :-O . What was even more surprising about being asked from the Americans from the Seattle area is that it’s so close to the Canadian border into Vancouver! Then again, I also couldn’t believe how many people I came across that had lived in that area their whole entire lives but had NEVER crossed the border into Canada. I will say that they were some of the nicest people I’d met though :-).

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: First time in the States (eek , 28 years ago now), I took my first summer out of college to visit friends who’d gone to work in the US. I’m staying with a friend in Seattle and we went shopping with his a girlfriend. An absolutely lovely girl (I believe they’re still married). We’re in a mall somewhere, and we step on to the escalator. With a totally straight face she turns to us and says “do you guys have escalators in England?” All I can remember is my mouth opening and closing like a fish all the way up that escalator.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
What makes a workout a good workout?
 
When you completed the last rep, or the last lap, or the last submission or whichever sport you train for, how did you feel?
 
Did you feel like a million bucks?
 
Like you have a weight lifted off your shoulders?
 
Does it feel like you tested yourself?
 
Yes?
 
Good.
 
No?
 
Good.
 
Listen…
 
It doesn't matter how you feel, good or bad, motivated or lazy, strong or weak. What matters is that you 
got shit done.
 
You did the workout.
 
Given that you are on a proven program that will elicit changes in body composition and strength. What makes a workout good or even great is doing it.
 
There 
Continue Reading
What makes a workout a good workout?
 
When you completed the last rep, or the last lap, or the last submission or whichever sport you train for, how did you feel?
 
Did you feel like a million bucks?
 
Like you have a weight lifted off your shoulders?
 
Does it feel like you tested yourself?
 
Yes?
 
Good.
 
No?
 
Good.
 
Listen…
 
It doesn't matter how you feel, good or bad, motivated or lazy, strong or weak. What matters is that you 
got shit done.
 
You did the workout.
 
Given that you are on a proven program that will elicit changes in body composition and strength. What makes a workout good or even great is doing it.
 
There are days you 
feel 
like a million bucks. You are excited to step forth and challenge yourself that day.
 
Those are the easy days.
 
Then, there are days you 
feel 
weak. Your sick of the day to day grind. You want to stay in bed.
 
Those days…
 
Those days are the ones that count. Those days are your TEST DAYS.
 
No matter the day, if you can get yourself to the gym and finish your workout, it was a great workout. Even if you just go through the motions.
 
Do it, go through the motions.
 
Those feelings after a workout are great and in many ways that is why we workout. The chemical release feels good, pushing oursleves feels good. Im not trying to downplay those factors.
 
You see the 
feelings
 will come and go. You can't trust them to get you to the gym. You can't trust them to keep you on track.
 
You need to keep yourself on track.
 
That little whisper in your head -
 
“Not today, I could use the rest”
 
“But I have so many other things to do, I can skip today”
 
Shut them down.
 
Feeling lazy? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
Feeling tired? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
Feeling depressed? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
You have the only vote.
 
And that vote shall and always will be towards 
getting shit done.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was a 22 year old engineering student. I was taking circuits and electronics with a guy in his thirties. He seemed to think anyone younger than him was an idiot.
 
My favorite exchange:
 
Him: No offense, but what's wrong with kids your age? Do you even know about Chernobyl?
 
Me: …I think lots of people do. It was a huge disaster.
 
Him: Well, I met a girl the other day who didn't know about the Hindenburg.
 
How old did this guy think he was? It was the weirdest thing that has ever happened to me, and I have some weird stories.

BTW the word ignorant simply means lack of knowledge.
 
I worked with a woman who was taught only by using only specific text books, movies and so on that were written or made by her narrow-minded, very strict church.
 
Her belief system included nothing that is taught in the regular school system and did not teach math past the addition and subtraction level as all other math was a lie. Any and all information otherwise taught in the regular texts books was written by the devil. They even have their own version of the bible which I found frightening. So much blood and death. Anything good was replaced by something bad.
 
When their daughter was 17, she had the SAT and other state required tests to take. She had not learned most of the necessary knowledge to pass any of them.
 
Plus this was her first exposure to the outsider and “normal” people. She knew nothing that the others knew as her education was so strictly regulated. When tested by the school system, her knowledge of standard information was that of a very young child. Although in her school she was considered an A+ student.
 
She was unable to be admitted to college and but somehow managed to befriend a neighbor outside of her faith who helped her get her GED.
 
She ran away from home and lived a “normal” and continued her education. She has just received her license as a physicians assistant.
 
Thank you Andreas Schwab for the edits, guess I'll have to proofread better.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
When we decide to exercise , three fundamental questions arise: which is the most appropriate, how many weekly sessions we need and, above all, when we will see some effect. The best option is the circuits in which four or five different types of activities alternate with rest periods between series and series . Coaches say that without killing themselves and choosing the activity table, the body will notice in 66 days.
Plan the session; Exhausting is not a guarantee of good results
 
What is better, to train strength or resistance? We are facing the eternal question when it comes to exercising. W
Continue Reading
When we decide to exercise , three fundamental questions arise: which is the most appropriate, how many weekly sessions we need and, above all, when we will see some effect. The best option is the circuits in which four or five different types of activities alternate with rest periods between series and series . Coaches say that without killing themselves and choosing the activity table, the body will notice in 66 days.
Plan the session; Exhausting is not a guarantee of good results
 
What is better, to train strength or resistance? We are facing the eternal question when it comes to exercising. We arise because we have little time in day to day and we want, logically, to get the most out of our activity. But choosing between both is a wrong view, since it leads us in most cases to the mistake of hitting an aerobic bludgeon, thinking that with it we will burn more fats , or routines with a lot of weight in order to gain more muscle.
 
The reality is that people who manage to train continuously do so on average twice a week and no more than forty minutes each time . With this average, if we want to generate significant changes in our body to improve health and aesthetics, we have to change our perspective. By focusing one day on muscle mass and another on aerobic exercises, the stimulus to which the body is subjected is insignificant, even if we end up exhausted.
The reason is that the organism does not know if it runs in front of a lion to survive - and is making an extra effort for it - or if it trains for a healthy goal. So, if you are sitting for eight hours or so many hours standing up and suddenly an intense and unordered physical activity is imposed, your tendency will be to protect yourself. It will neither burn more fat, nor generate more muscle; on the contrary, it will try to reserve itself and spend as little as possible, in case the effort is prolonged in time. Your reaction is biologically logical.
 
So, what is the ideal dynamic? The answer is very simple: combine the two modalities in the same session or at different times but within the same day. The professionals call it concurrent training. However, after answering the first question, at least two more questions arise. The first: how much time is necessary to use to notice significant changes in the body? And the second: how to combine strength and resistance exercises in each session?
 
The magic figure: nine and a half weeks
 
The University College of London sets at 66 the days necessary to generate or change a habit or to achieve the goal that we set. You rarely get to the ten weeks of training followed. Most of us move by peaks of intensity. There are two periods that are key: the beginning of the year, when many people join a gym or start running; and towards the month of May, coinciding with the fact that the first hot days make us see summer around the corner.
Many coaches propose that we divide our goals into blocks of 66 days. This will not only help us see results, but also motivate us with a goal that has a beginning and an end. Once you have made the decision, you have to plan the exercise with realism. How much time do I train? The American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate intensity exercise every week spread over five days - a half hour a day - or three sessions of between twenty minutes and one hour of vigorous activity .
 
This is ideal, however, the perfect dose is one that is compatible with the activities of daily and working life in the medium and long term. To achieve the goal, you have to be practical. Therefore, every session we take, even if it is ten minutes, should be used to the maximum and have all the necessary components so that our health improves little by little.
A circuit with which we could start today would be this:
 
1) 200 meters running or walking ;
 
2) Ten squats;
 
3) Eight push-ups.
 
4) Six vertical jumps and return to run or walk 200 meters.
 
We should do it twice, with thirty seconds of rest between each exercise and two minutes of rest between circuit and circuit. The training lasts between twenty-five and thirty minutes.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I can’t say either of these people qualify as the most ignorant person in America, but sometimes a person will ask me a question that shocks me.
 
Once a woman checked me out at a grocery store and she asked me what vegetable I had so she could find the code. It was an ordinary green cabbage. I don’t understand not being able to identify a green cabbage on sight, but working at a grocery store in a checkout line and not knowing a cabbage when you see one is pretty bad.
 
Another woman who worked in my office at the time asked me if England was part of Germany. She wanted to know because she had to m
Continue Reading
I can’t say either of these people qualify as the most ignorant person in America, but sometimes a person will ask me a question that shocks me.
 
Once a woman checked me out at a grocery store and she asked me what vegetable I had so she could find the code. It was an ordinary green cabbage. I don’t understand not being able to identify a green cabbage on sight, but working at a grocery store in a checkout line and not knowing a cabbage when you see one is pretty bad.
 
Another woman who worked in my office at the time asked me if England was part of Germany. She wanted to know because she had to make an international call for one of the engineers and she already knew the country code for Germany.
 
Questions like this make me long for the conversation of someone who just doesn’t know what year the Declaration of Independence was signed.
 
My husband cheerfully answers questions like this without hesitation, but I hesitate because it confuses me that people have the jobs they have and don’t know these things. I think they can’t possibly be asking me the question I heard. But yes, they are.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
That's kinda like asking what's the best car to own. Depends. If you want something really fast and sporty, a corvette. If you want to haul material and tow a boat, a pick up truck. If you want a reliable car that'll always get you to work on time, a Honda accord.
 
Most people don't know specifically what they want, fitness wise, they just want to be “better.” Slimmer, stronger, more energetic and less pained. They want the Honda Accord body.
 
Which means a routine that has cardio, strength and mobility. Emphasis should be on cardio, since it's longer to build and quicker to lose. Try for three 30
Continue Reading
That's kinda like asking what's the best car to own. Depends. If you want something really fast and sporty, a corvette. If you want to haul material and tow a boat, a pick up truck. If you want a reliable car that'll always get you to work on time, a Honda accord.
 
Most people don't know specifically what they want, fitness wise, they just want to be “better.” Slimmer, stronger, more energetic and less pained. They want the Honda Accord body.
 
Which means a routine that has cardio, strength and mobility. Emphasis should be on cardio, since it's longer to build and quicker to lose. Try for three 30 minute cardio sessions a week. Running, biking, swimming, whatever gets your heart rate up. If you can't go 30 minutes, slow down until you can.
 
Supplement this with strength and mobility exercises, either after the cardio or a different day. If you have access to weights, then stick with the major lifts: bench press, squat, deadlift, overhead press, lat pull down. If you don't, then use bodyweight exercises: push ups, pull ups, squats, planks and glute bridges. Finish up with stretches for mobility. Yoga is good for this too.
 
Once you know more about fitness and your body, you might decide you want the pick up truck body (weightlifters) the sprinter body (sports car) the long distance body (hybrid) or the obstacle course body (jeep). All are worthy goals, but if you're not sure, then start with the Accord.

article:

As I traveled around the world during my military service, one of the first things I did, even before arriving, was to get out a map to see where I was going to be (I did have a pretty good handle on basic world geography). I was interested in the culture of the country and its history. I also tried to learn a few phrases in the language of the country. I will confess that my French and German were far better than my Vietnamese, Korean, and Tagalog. While at a military dinner at Ft. Leavenwort
Continue Reading
I was saddened to read these responses concerning American ignorance of other countries and cultures. As I traveled around the world during my military service, one of the first things I did, even before arriving, was to get out a map to see where I was going to be (I did have a pretty good handle on basic world geography). I was interested in the culture of the country and its history. I also tried to learn a few phrases in the language of the country. I will confess that my French and German were far better than my Vietnamese, Korean, and Tagalog. While at a military dinner at Ft. Leavenworth KS, my wife and I were seated across from an Afghanistan officer. When the main course was served, he asked what it was, and it was either chicken or veal cordon bleu. As I said that, I commented, “You’re Muslim, aren’t you?” He replied, “Yes” I reached out to the host with the problem, and the officer got a T-bone steak replacement.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

Continue Reading
I’ve been debating for a while whether or not to post this because I’m still having a hard time believing it happened, but what the hell, a story’s a story.
 
Right about 2000 I had these friends, a married couple that I knew from community college and with whom I had reconnected when I moved to a new town for a job. We became rather close friends, hanging out quite a bit. One day as I was leaving their place something came up in conversation (I don’t remember what, exactly) and I mentioned seeing the moon during the day.
 
“What do you mean?” he said.
 
“The Moon. When it comes out at daytime. You know,” I responded.
 
“I don’t understand,” he said, a blank look on his face that puzzled me. He seemed to be serious.
 
“What do you mean you don’t understand. Surely you’ve seen the moon during the day?” I asked, unable to believe he had never seen the moon during the day and that he must be trolling me (even though “trolling” wasn’t a thing yet).
 
“No,” he said, completely seriously. “The moon is never out at daytime. You can only see it at night.”
 
“Of course,” she said. “You know that.”
 
I was dumbstruck. I literally stammered for words. These were not stupid people. They had many faults, but blind stupidity was not, I thought, one of them. I was quickly revising that opinion.
 
“No… But… Seriously… You can’t… Um…” I tried to gather my thoughts. “You’re telling me you have never seen the moon during the day?”
 
“Never,” they both said.
 
“So, when the moon sets and goes to the other side of the planet, where it’s daytime…” My disbelief inhibited me from forming a complete sentence.
 
“When the moon sets, the sun rises. Everybody knows that,” he retorted.
 
“So what about solar eclipses? The moon has to be out during the day for that, right?” I said, thinking I had to convince him with that.
 
“I’ve never seen the moon during an eclipse, have you,” he asked his wife.
 
“No, never,” she responded.
 
“But the moon is what causes a solar eclipse, right?” I asked, desperate to reach some working logic center of their brains.
 
“I don’t know, I’ve never really thought about it,” he said offhandedly.
 
I considered this for a moment and realized the moon would have to be at the new moon phase during an eclipse, so It’s reasonable they wouldn’t have seen the moon then, and eclipses are rather rare anyway. I was stuck. Short of dragging them outside when the moon and sun both occupied the sky I didn’t think I would be able to crack this breathtaking level of ignorance. I then realized that they were both recovering from substance abuse and they might have been too high most of their lives to ever notice the moon in the daytime sky.
 
It was at that moment I realized I needed a higher caliber or friends.

There might be multiple reasons for using 
PyCharm, an Integrated Development Environment (IDE)
 for Python. Maybe the first question is “Why should one use an IDE at all?”
 
An IDE can help you code faster and become much more productive if you devote some time to learning the tool in the first place. “What is an IDE?”, you might ask. IDEs integrate multiple development tools, including a code editor, version control systems, a debugger, run configurations, a terminal, database tooling, and much more.
 
As an IDE for Python and other languages, PyCharm gives you 
highly accurate code completion 
that helps you write less code and avoid bugs. With its 
smart code navigation
, you can quickly navigate around your code to inspect, for instance, the implementation of a class you are about to instantiate. PyCharm’s 
project-wide refactorings
 will ensure you won’t break any code when, for instance, renaming a variable or changing a method signature, and much more.
 
Together, all this makes you more productive as a developer and increases your overall ergonomics. When using PyCharm, you can avoid writing boilerplate code over and over again, feel more confident when exploring code bases, and have the ability to work with technologies you are not fully experienced with.
 
PyCharm comes in two editions. The free and open-source Community Edition is designed for Python development only. The paid Professional Edition offers support for remote interpreters, frontend technologies including popular JavaScript frameworks, databases (SQL and noSQL), and Python web frameworks such as Django, Flask, and FastAPI.
 
Some people say IDEs have a tough learning curve. It’s true that you will need to devote some time to learning the shortcuts and commands and configuring your environment to get the most from using PyCharm. Be aware, though, that unlike some other IDEs on the market, PyCharm has everything you need to start coding – right out of the box.
 
The good news is that you can try PyCharm Professional for 30 days, completely free of charge. 
Download PyCharm
 and see if it works for you!

article:

Then find a suitable area of the apartment big enough for you to lie flat, and do classic push-ups, 10 of them per set, for 3 sets. Continue Reading
For someone like me, living in an apartment building, I would say to start with walking down all 9 flights of stairs from the top floor to the bottom, and then back up again as step 1 (do the circuit twice, when the first circuit becomes easier).
 
Then find a suitable area of the apartment big enough for you to lie flat, and do classic push-ups, 10 of them per set, for 3 sets. If you cannot manage the push-ups, then drop your knees to the ground and push from there. Another starting progression if you cannot complete a “full” push-up is to just focus on doing the downward part of the movement - usually, you will reach a point where you end up just flopping down the rest of the way… try to avoid banging your nose on the floor, it will hurt… but if you put as much effort into the downward part as you can and get as low as you can on every rep, and then finish with the flop every rep, and just reset back to the top of the movement, you will eventually manage to get all the way down without flopping. Then you just have to do the push, which will be hard, but give it 100% and then stop and reset as needed.
 
Next, bodyweight squats. Sit on a kitchen chair, or the toilet, or a comfortable chair if you really want to. Without using your arms, lean forward and stand up. Once you are fully upright, sit back down again but do not let your weight sink into the chair - just sit down until you feel contact between your body and the material of the seat. Now stand up again. Remember, no hands! Also, your feet should not move at all. Repeat for 10 reps per set, 3 sets.
 
Lunges - from a standing position, take a step forward with one foot. Drive your front knee forward and bend it, until your hip is as close to the heel of your front foot as you can manage, ideally with your rear leg being straight. Now move back up to your starting position and repeat the motion with the other leg. Repeat 10 times per set, for 3 sets.
 
As a beginner workout routine, that would usually be enough to start with.

article:

As a Canadian, it's sometimes fun to mess with southerners. My favourite trick, pull out a toonie (Canadian $2 coin- google it if you don't know it). Tell them it isn't a single coin, but 2. When we use it, we only spend the middle coin. It's just so small, we hold it in the outer coin.
 
Then ask them to pop it out for you. It's funny how many fall for this.
 
Also, there are many Canadian jokes about Americans, many of which may paint them as the butt of a blonde joke (mean, I know) to things like tourists crossing the boarder with skis strapped to the roof of their cars. In summer! It doesn't help that some Americans reinforce these stereotypes when visiting.
 
There's a joke around Niagara about Americans thinking that the Niagara Falla are turned off at night. The funny part is the number of Americans that actually think this is true.
 
A friend of mine was working at a classy restaurant in downtown Niagara, right along the falls. It was 9:50, 10 minutes to closing. The last customers were finishing up and leaving when in walk a loud group of Americans demanding to be seating. She has no choice and decided to seat them anyways.
 
They were there eating and talking for over an hour.
 
When 11:15 rolled around, she was pretty pissed that they were still there, slowly meandering their way through dessert. When she asked how everything once, one of the tourists asked “So, when do they turn off the Falls?”
 
“The Niagara Falls?”
 
“Of course the Niagara Falls!”
 
Felling like having some playful revenge, she said, “Oh, I'm so sorry. They turn them off at 10:30. You've missed them for the evening.”
 
Extremely dejected, the group left.
 
The irony: their seat was along a window overlooking the falls. All they had to do was turn their heads and see it.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The most ignorant American I've met lived on the same floor of the dorm as I did when I was doing my undergraduate degree. She was a Texan who’d been living in Missouri and her parents were computer programmers who bred tropical fish as a hobby.
 
This lady loved her technology. She’d buy every new Macbook and iPad that came out, had about five different cameras including a DSLR and several Go-Pros with attachments. She also bought her one year old son three hundred, yes, 
three hundred 
present for his first Christmas! She’d also been given a car for her birthday, drove a scooter here in Australia
Continue Reading
The most ignorant American I've met lived on the same floor of the dorm as I did when I was doing my undergraduate degree. She was a Texan who’d been living in Missouri and her parents were computer programmers who bred tropical fish as a hobby.
 
This lady loved her technology. She’d buy every new Macbook and iPad that came out, had about five different cameras including a DSLR and several Go-Pros with attachments. She also bought her one year old son three hundred, yes, 
three hundred 
present for his first Christmas! She’d also been given a car for her birthday, drove a scooter here in Australia, and had several other cars in her garage back home.
 
She came to me one day complaining how unfair life was because she couldn't get a scholarship even though she was poor because her parents made too much money.
 
Now, my family sponsors several children in poverished areas around the world and I've had the huge privilege to be able to visit two of them who lived in slums in Thailand. I've seen abject poverty with my own eyes and have been close to it myself, having at times had only a few dollars to my name.
 
Her complaint, therefore, absolutely floored me. I told her so, straight to her face and her only argument was that she has the right to have nice things and she has the right to spoil her son if she wants.
 
I still boggle over that incident even seven years later. It's the sheerest, completest ignorance I've ever encountered.

Him:but it's across the ocean.
 
Me: it's still a US state.
 
Him : but you need a passport to go to the Caribbean ( where in the Caribbean ? He didn't seem to know)
 
Me : no hawaii is part of the us.
 
Him: but how can it be part of the US if it is across an ocean?
 
I didn't even want to go into explaining about the US occupation of hawaii, military bases in hawaii, it's strategic position in the Pacific during World War 2 and so forth. At least he knew of the existence of the Pacific ocean…
 
Another person I met who seemed like a very smart guy in general but then he said something very ignorant related to geography:
 
We were watching something on tv about someone visiting Morocco.
 
Me: I would like to go to Morocco.
 
Him: I don't know what that is.
 
Me : the country Morocco in North Africa?
 
Him: I've never heard of that.
 
Apparently he had never in his life heard that there was a country in Africa called Morocco, and also had not been paying attention to the TV show we were watching for about half an hour which was about Morocco !!! I guess he was in his own little world
 
Edit: I thought of another one:
 
This was at a cosmetology school in Memphis, TN. One of the other students was from a very small town in Tennessee and was driving about 40 minutes everyday to go to the school. Somehow someone was also from a small town near Memphis was saying they were planning on moving to Memphis, and she said : “my grandmother said you have to register when you move to memphis.” Everyone in the class was very confused, register how ? With who?Register to vote? Register your vehicle at the dmv? We tried to explain to her that you don't have to go through immigration to move to a different town. I still don't know what she was talking about.
