I realize I’m not sticking to the question, but I feel I need to offer a counter point.
 
I’m a California native with generic western looks and when travelling in the East (20 years ago) have encountered plenty of funny ignorance about the US and Americans like the idea that we all carry guns and shoot at other people at the drop of a hat.
 
I was in Singapore when that American kid was caned for vandalizing cars. Everyone was shocked there that the President of the US would actually step in to intervene, to prevent a juvenile delinquent from getting a simple punishment, the equivalent to our making a kid spend a couple of days in juvenile detention. No wonder America is so lawless and crime ridden, if you can do anything without fear of punishment.
 
I’ve received shocked comments regarding the fact that I can eat with chopsticks, or that I actually like sushi. I once had a host refuse to tell me what kind of soup I was eating (fermented sour fish belly) for fear I would freak out and throw up (I happily asked for another bowl). In general, most locals thought I ate nothing but fried chicken, steak, hamburgers, and meatloaf everyday. (Actually, that might not be far off for some Americans).
 
In Perth, Australia, everyone seemed to believe that I ran into movie stars on a daily basis and many people, complete strangers, asked if they could stay at my house if they were ever lucky enough to be able to make it to LA, which they considered to be some kind of paradise.
 
On the other hand, on my first visit to London, I asked the locals where I could get some fish and chips, only to be told that I would have to search out a tourist oriented place as mostly they were the only ones that ate it. The locals preferred pizza and Chinese.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
Everyday, before going to the gym, I listen to Time by Hans Zimmer on blast and intensely stare at my self in the mirror, while visualising every exercise I’m going to do that day.
 
When the song is done, I scream “Yeah!!!” loudly, startling my roommates and neighbours, as I, now fully pumped up, pick up my training bag, beat my chest like a silverback gorilla, and storm out the door, ready to take the world by storm.

Continue Reading
Everyday, before going to the gym, I listen to Time by Hans Zimmer on blast and intensely stare at my self in the mirror, while visualising every exercise I’m going to do that day.
 
When the song is done, I scream “Yeah!!!” loudly, startling my roommates and neighbours, as I, now fully pumped up, pick up my training bag, beat my chest like a silverback gorilla, and storm out the door, ready to take the world by storm.
“Dude, did you take the picture yet? Holding my arms up like this is exhausting.”
 
…
 
I hope you know none of that’s true.
 
I do pump myself up before a big lift sometimes.
 
It can indeed be awkward.
 
Slaps are given. Music is played. Grunts are, embarrassing as it is in retrospect, made.
 
But while I use it as a tool, I don’t rely on feelings of motivation, for reasons we’re about to get to.
 
The term motivation is used and abused too much and too vaguely. Before we can talk about it, we need to firmly define what it means.
 
When discussing others, most agree that motivation is 
the desire that drives their actions.
 
Simple, right?
 
But when we’re talking about ourselves—and perhaps most specifically when we speak of notoriously hard to improve aspects of our lives—that’s 
not
 the meaning we give it.
 
We then start mixing it up, with this mythical 
feeling 
that will be able to generate the energy required for us to behave in a particular way.
 
We tend to also treat it as a prerequisite; as if this feeling has to be present before we do a given thing.
 
“I’m not motivated today.”
 
“When am I going to be motivated again?”
 
“I need some motivation before I start.”
 
Notice however, that nowhere in the first definition does it say that one has to 
feel
 motivation. It only speaks of the desire driving action. If I told you Usain Bolt was motivated to train for the Olympics, that only means he has a goal he values in his sights—not that every moment of his experience is filled with feelings of motivation. Point being, that 
these two definitions of motivation are not the same thing.
 
And that is a 
very
 good thing.
Contrary to how we treat them, feelings aren’t instructions we should follow, sent from the deep, all-knowing core inside of us.
 
There is at least no evidence of that.
 
The unsexy, best guess of a truth we currently have is that
 feelings are our brains best interpretations of outward stimuli 
based on our personal biology, history, personality, expectations and culture.
[1]
 
[2]
 
[3]
 
[4]
 
Also, as the high-school version of me would tell you: feelings are fickle beasts.
 
Not constant, but fluctuating.
 
Not rational, but irrational.
 
No one feels pulsating motivation 
all the time,
 just like no one feels constant anger, happiness or joy.
 
Doing something you’re not used to doing, it’s in fact very likely you’ll not 
feel
 much motivation—at least at first. Rarely do we like doing that we’re bad at.
 
So 
“motivation the feeling”
 shouldn’t matter.
 
What should is the 
overarching desire
 that drives our actions, even—and perhaps especially—when we don’t particularly feel like performing those actions.
 
What drives people to train everyday and what we need isn’t 
motivation
, but 
dedication
.
 
Dedication, to a goal we’ve set ourselves.
 
Dedication, to being who we want to be.
 
Dedication, to what 
motivates us
.
 
No one wants to eat vegetables, drag themselves to the gym and go to bed early. These are not sexy, fun or appealing things to do. The only reason why some do them is because they’re dedicated to an overarching goal, desire or way of life they value.
 
But is doing whatever you want to do going to be a constant uphill battle? Are you never going to like it?
 
The good news is that’s highly unlikely.
 
If you’re anything like most people, you’ll enjoy it more and more the more time you spend doing it.
 
As stated, we like doing things we’re good at and we become good at that which we do. It’s a 
positive feedback loop.
One action spurs another, which again spurs the original action.
 
Furthermore, we mostly don’t operate based on momentary desire. Virtually no one contemplates how they feel about brushing their teeth or weighs the pros and cons of cutting their nails.
 
Doing so would be exhausting and extremely inefficient.
 
Most of our decisions are made blindly, out of habit. That which we do everyday is treated just as things to be done. Exercise becomes very much the same way.
 
It’s also important to notice how motivation and dedication are not on opposite sides of the spectrum. One does not take away from the other. In fact, they’re symbiotic, feeding off of each other.
 
The stronger your motivation—being the 
thing
, the 
goal
, the 
desire
 that motivates you—the easier it is to dedicate yourself to it. The more you’re able to dedicate yourself to something, the more motivated you’ll feel, because you’re now accomplishing what motivates you, and few things are more motivating than sensing progress towards a goal we value.
 
Most often, it works like this in practice:
Find something that motivates you.
 As we’ve gone over, this doesn’t mean something you’ll enjoy doing 100% of the time, but simply something that’ll make you happy/successful in the long run.
Dedicate yourself to it.
 You’ll inevitably, for a moment or 100, not want to do it. Do it anyway.
Do it for a long enough time that it becomes ingrained. 
You’ll have to fight less and less to do it. Some days, you’ll still have to though. That’s life.
Too many people accept blindly the idea that they need to feel motivated to do something. That which we decide as true shape our vision of the world.
 
If reaching your goal is something that’s important to you, I strongly recommend leaving that crowd and the idea that feelings of motivation are a prerequisite for action behind.
 
Don’t depend on a fleeting feeling. Depend on what will make you happiest in the long run.
 
Motivation will come and go.
 
It rises, like the ocean, then it sinks again.
 
And you’ll be there. Still going strong. Still working.
 
With it.
 
Without it.
To answer your question directly: No one feels motivated to workout every day. People simply do so because of their habits, environment and identity. If you want to be more consistent in the gym, those are the things you should aim to change, not your feelings of motivation.
Footnotes
[1] 
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/feeling-our-emotions/
[2] 
Why Your Biology Runs on Feelings - Issue 56: Perspective - Nautilus
[3] 
https://humdev.uchicago.edu/sites/humdev.uchicago.edu/files/uploads/shweder/2008--The%20Cultural%20Psychology%20of%20the%20Emotions%20-%20Ancient%20and%20Renewed.PDF
[4] 
http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.577.4057&rep=rep1&type=pdf

Not exactly an American, but this person hopes to get a US citizenship. Sorry, I just can't resist.
 
This happened about a week ago.
 
First, some background: I am a first year Physics student at a Swiss university, and I just happened to have met my ex-classmate in a train. After a brief chitchat, he eventually asks me:
 
“So, what’re ya studying?”
 
“I think I’ve told you before”, I replied; “its sciency stuff.”
 
“Math?” (if this doesn’t already ring any bells), he asks.
 
“No, but we rely on it heavily”, I reply. “You’re ‘pretty close’ ”.
 
After a few seconds of hesitation, he asks:
 
“Trigonometry?”
 
Now what the ****, seriously. A first year university student, who has previously been in an ‘advanced’ physics class for a few years, while also studying calculus is unable to differentiate between a branch of a subject and the subject itself.
 
Damn, I felt alone on that train. And damn, was I tempted to reply: “Nope, arithmetic.”

Back when I was working in a multinational US company, one of their managers went to Italy. He was in the team coordinating the Y2K worldwide project. His name and family name were both Italians, so, during a conversation, I asked him where he was born.” Actually in the USA” was his reply, “but my parents were born in Italy, in Abruzzo”. Then he went on explaining to me (an Italian) that Abruzzo is a region of Sicily. (Which it’s not)
 
For those of you who are not familiar with Italy (the majority, I'd assume) it is like saying that Alaska is part of California. I tried to change his view on the subject, but nope, he would rather believe what his dad and mom told him. Good son.
 
And, of course, I don't think it was his duty to know that, but maybe to have some doubts and check…
 
And, as others have already said, this case doesn't mean all US people are the same.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Well on that score - knowing about American history and geography factoids, probably anyone not raised in the USA, me included. Concerning those with a privilege of education, reasonable food, shelter, protection when asked about general knowledge of the world we all share..... many Americans.
 
When visiting from Australia, I had the usual questions (do you all have Koalas and Kangaroos for pets.... of course we all do ;-) but also some that stumped me because I thought they were joking:
 You come from Australia - you speak really good English.
 Did it take long to drive to America from there?
 
Wh
Continue Reading
Well on that score - knowing about American history and geography factoids, probably anyone not raised in the USA, me included. Concerning those with a privilege of education, reasonable food, shelter, protection when asked about general knowledge of the world we all share..... many Americans.
 
When visiting from Australia, I had the usual questions (do you all have Koalas and Kangaroos for pets.... of course we all do ;-) but also some that stumped me because I thought they were joking:
 You come from Australia - you speak really good English.
 Did it take long to drive to America from there?
 
When I asked about American factoids like in the question above, I was amazed at the understanding that citizens have about their own history and country. Most Australian's don't know or care about the history of our origins, at least in the patriotic way done in the USA. I think we have a pretty good idea of where all the Aussies live, and I'd like it if we were a little more knowledgeable and proud of our origins and development path.
 
When I scratched the surface of understanding of about World politics, history, geography, current events etc, in the U.S. I was appalled. Professionals who didn't know a European country, any capitals, when WWII actually started, who the leader of any other countries were etc. I realized when in the U.S. on business that the news is totally about U.S. affairs, while in Australia it is 30/30 local and foreign with 40% for sport.
The Americans who I found more realistic and interesting were those who had travelled and could compare other countries with the USA.
 
While it's true that we're all ignorant about lots of things, the truly inept revel in their ignorance. The Dunning Kruger effect is a human cognitive bias that says that ignorant people are ignorant of their ignorance and so trust in their own opinion more than someone of knowledge does. They are often more believed in committees too - because they are sure of their (ill informed) opinions, whereas an expert will know the limit of certainty of their answers. I believe the democratisation of publishing through the internet and the D-K effect are responsible for the rise of "the endarkenment", where ignorance is celebrated, and all opinions are thought equally true.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: Five friends and I ran into Marjorie Taylor Greene (MTG) in North Georgia. Talking to her was like talking to a blank stare with a smile. We knew who she was, but she didn't know us. She acted as if we were old acquaintances, recalling past meetings with us as if they had happened before. We tried to have a conversation, but it was like we were discussing one thing and she would randomly jump in with something bizarre and totally unrelated. We were left bewildered, wondering, "What just happened to us?" I’ve called her Empty (MT)Green ever since.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: My first roommate in college was from a small town in Oregon. We lived in the dorms my freshman year. We were assigned to the same room at random by the dorm enrollment process. One day he told me that he thought God created white people and black people evolved from monkeys. He truely believed it too. It wasnt just a joke or an off-hand racist comment, he had been thinking about it a lot. He went into a long explanation on how he came to his ephimey. He dropped out of college later that year.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article: When gain weight, you mean build muscle, it depends. If you're talking about a full body mass building program, which you probably are, then yes I'd say that it is. You are breaking down a lot of muscle at once and all of it rebuilds at the same time and then you repeat that, you'll gain weight much faster than a split. Personally, I do think that full body workouts are best. Just be sure you don't do deadlift more than twice a week.

title: How to workout
article:
To workout properly you have to find out what works for you. Each body is different and what works for me it might not work for you. What's your goal? To build muscles, andurance, weight losse? Set your goal first and if you want to build muscles you have to train each muscle at least one time per week. An example for 5 workout days per week:
 
Monday: Chest
 
Tuesday: Back
 
Wednesday: Legs+abs
 
Thursday: Shoulders+traps
 
Friday: Arms

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
I follow ‘Yoga with Adrienne’ online. She posts a new video every few days, currently she is doing a 30 days yoga revolution.
 
I started off with doing the 30 days of yoga videos (over about 2 months) and she explains the moves and gives options for people who are at different levels. The videos go for 15 - 30 minutes and are always a good workout.
 
I hope that you check it out and that you enjoy it.

I thought it would be nice to meet one of m

Maybe not ignorant, just totally crazy.
 
Okay, so I was visiting with my grandmother, who lives in 
Snohomish, Washington
 an awesome little town with a lot of character and culture.
 
I once thought that everyone there was just great. They were always nice, respectful, and I’d even been able to strike up some very intelligent conversations with total strangers around town. But on this one day, we were walking down the street and my grandma pointed to a woman waiting for a bus “Look Jon! I see my friend!” (she speaks poor english and often exclaims loudly). I thought it would be nice to meet one of my grandma’s friends, especially one who lived in Snohomish. WRONG!
 
This woman literally thought she was a prophet. She believed that she was speaking with god on a daily basis.
 
“Hello, this must be your grandson!”
 
normal enough
 
“I’m riding the bus, I have to go to a party with my bible study group. I’m going to Israel next month, you know.”
 
Ok, still normal
 
“I’m selling all my things for this trip! Selling everything and going to Israel because the lord commanded me to go”
 
Um…
 
“I’m a Prophetess you know! God speaks to me! Always has. I’m going to Israel and staying there while these secular people destroy America! Things are going downhill from here, me and my group know it! You know why? Because the lord speaketh!”
 
Wait, did she just say speaketh?
 
“When Donald Trump was a young man, he prayed to god, ‘Dear god, make me a successful businessman!’ and look where he is now! And he’s said some things in the past, but now he’s become humble and GOD WILL USE A HUMBLE MAN I TELL YOU!”
 
dafuq?
 
“I’m an evangelist you know and a prophetess, did I tell you that? I can speaketh with the lord himself! And I’m going to Israel. I know this Televangelist who’s going with me and his son, well he’s the prodigal son, THE PRODIGAL SON from the bible. And he strayeth from the lord, but the lord forgiveth him! He and I put posters up, all over the city and BY THE MIGHT OF GOD we marched the ENTIRE TOWN OF SNOHOMISH down to Olympia (the state capitol, 90 miles away) and DE-E-E-E-MANDED they obey god! This year we’re going bigger, WE’RE GOING TO SUMMON THE ENTIRE COUNTY!”
 
People are starting to stare as she screams “the will of god” at me and my grandma, and I am thoroughly terrified of this woman. She then 
PUTS HER HANDS ON ME, AND STARES AT ME WITH HER PIERCING EYES.
 
“Dear lord I pray for this man that you’d touch his life and turn him away from the E-E-E-EVIL ways of sin! I pray you guide him through the apocalypse which is soon to come, and I pray you FORCE THE DEVIL OUT OF THIS MAN’S LIFE! In JE-E-E-ESUS NAME A-A-A-AMEN!”
 
Probably the most terrifying experience of my life.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

This was a 30-something year old woman with kids.

We made outbound calls to doctors offices around the US, so we had to be mindful of time zones.

She didn’t know they existed, or how they worked.
 
It took me hours of explaining before she began to understa

I fear for humanity.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
My guess is that if you’re asking that question, you are a 
beginner 
at the gym, that is 
less than 1 year of weight lifting
 under your belt.
 
OK, so I would say that any given workout should 
not last longer then 50–75 minutes
. And that would include all the weight training exercises along with the rest periods between the various sets. I’m assuming that you won’t be spending tons of time on your phone or yakking to other people on the floor! And it could also include 
10 minutes or so of aerobic exercise
 following your weight lifting - the stair climber, rowing machine, stationary bike or stepper 
Continue Reading
My guess is that if you’re asking that question, you are a 
beginner 
at the gym, that is 
less than 1 year of weight lifting
 under your belt.
 
OK, so I would say that any given workout should 
not last longer then 50–75 minutes
. And that would include all the weight training exercises along with the rest periods between the various sets. I’m assuming that you won’t be spending tons of time on your phone or yakking to other people on the floor! And it could also include 
10 minutes or so of aerobic exercise
 following your weight lifting - the stair climber, rowing machine, stationary bike or stepper machine - to be done AFTER your weight lifting workout.
 
This timeline does not include any stretching, dynamic or static. 
If you’re somebody who insists on stretching at the outset, then do only 
dynamic
 stretching. 
Static
 stretching should only be done after the workout and ONLY for the muscles you worked on that day - no pain should be involved. You will have stretched your muscles on the gym floor anyway because lengthening and shortening a muscle is what movement is all about! Personally I NEVER stretch and certainly never with static stuff.
 
Exercise 4–6 days weekly and never over-train your muscles.
 That would mean that if you train your chest on one day, you would rest at least one day before doing the chest again - that allows those muscle to be repaired and rebuilt and to get stronger. That doesn’t necessarily mean that you can’t exercise the day after your chest workout, just that it should involve another muscle group.
 
You can google tons of suggestions on this but an example with a 5-day schedule might be the following:
 
Day 1 = quads, calves
 
Day 2 = chest, triceps, anterior delts
 
Day 3 = back, traps, abs
 
Day 4 = hamstrings, calves
 
Day 5 = chest, biceps, forearms
 
For more free tips and suggestions on diet and exercise, check out my videos on Instagram or YouTube.
 
IG = 
calorieburningat72

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I live here in Amurka. I hang out with the non-ignorant whenever possible. Every now and then I wind up standing next to a real beauty, though. Some favorites:
 
1) Woman at my church, 1993: “Isn’t it true that Bill Clinton is going to put gays in our schools?” I had to choke and leave, fast, before I started pointing all the ways that is a screwed up statement. (POTUS doesn’t meddle in a local jurisdiction, they’re already there for Pete’s sake, etc.) I was inside a church and didn’t feel like it was a good place to use words like “dumbfuck”.
 
2) I am visiting the Temple grounds in Salt Lake City,
Continue Reading
I live here in Amurka. I hang out with the non-ignorant whenever possible. Every now and then I wind up standing next to a real beauty, though. Some favorites:
 
1) Woman at my church, 1993: “Isn’t it true that Bill Clinton is going to put gays in our schools?” I had to choke and leave, fast, before I started pointing all the ways that is a screwed up statement. (POTUS doesn’t meddle in a local jurisdiction, they’re already there for Pete’s sake, etc.) I was inside a church and didn’t feel like it was a good place to use words like “dumbfuck”.
 
2) I am visiting the Temple grounds in Salt Lake City, in April of 2002, and very aware that I am an Unwashed Heathen. I am being very polite, which I suggest as a basic approach when you don’t understand what you are seeing. I get done listening to the Choir practice (Practices are open for free listening, or they were then, and it was GREAT).
 
I decide to go look at this other building with dioramas in it. I figure out they are based on Scenes From Scripture, and I can identify the Old and New Testament scenes, but I’m quite lost on the ones from the Book of Mormon.
 
I am stopped in front of a scene. A man is sitting in a chair, at a desk, with a flip-a-page desk calendar on it, model about 1930 to 1970, sheets mounted on central U brads, but made of something like a brassy version of tinfoil rather than paper. He is dressed as a Mayan, and there are cubbyholes built into a wall behind him, filled with clay tablets covered in cuneiform writing. There are patterns like Mayan glyphs painted on the wall to mark the cubbyholes. This looks to me like a complete archaeological mash-up.
 
At this point, one of the local insiders walks up with a friend, gestures to the scene, and proclaims, “See? This proves everything in (Scripture) is true!”
 
She means that the written scripture, first published in English in the 1800s, is proved scientifically verifiable by a diorama constructed in the late 1900s. Now, if she were talking about something I know about, and expect has a historical basis, say the destruction of the Temple in Jerusalem, it wouldn’t be proved to have happened because somebody put together a museum exhibit about it after the fact. I am not familiar with the story she is referencing, but it will follow the same rules as to evidence. It will take archaeology and cross references, not just a realistic looking artist’s conception 
based on the book itself
, to 
start
 into evidence territory.
 
This stunning display of literal minded concrete thinking has me almost physically dizzy. If I were a cartoon character, springs would be sticking out of my head, waving about and making accordion noises.
 
I stand there thinking, she is probably a nice person to her family and neighbors. For the love of Mike, keep your trap shut. I manage to reel back outside, without speaking, fortunately, and try to figure out all the self-referential permutations of wackiness in her statement. I’m still not sure I have a grasp on that.
 
It isn’t that it was about a religion I don’t understand that made the statement so staggering to me, but the utter lack of understanding of how to establish whether something is real. It was a 3 year old sort of statement coming out of a middle aged person.
 
I wonder if I sound similar to physicists. I know my grasp of physics sometimes seems to be based on Road Runner cartoons.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
A writer (I’ll call her Primadonna)who was attending a convention in the UK. She was travelling to Britain for ‘research’ and was invited—no pay, but her room was free, and she could sell her books, meet the celeb guests etc. Now, when I say writer here, let it be known that although her books were professionally published, they were essentially fanfic—based on a tv show and licensed as such. Not exactly deep or original stuff…I’d consider having my room paid for all weekend a pretty good deal tbh.
 
Anyway, someone in our group had been penfriends with her and even met her once or twice, and we 
Continue Reading
A writer (I’ll call her Primadonna)who was attending a convention in the UK. She was travelling to Britain for ‘research’ and was invited—no pay, but her room was free, and she could sell her books, meet the celeb guests etc. Now, when I say writer here, let it be known that although her books were professionally published, they were essentially fanfic—based on a tv show and licensed as such. Not exactly deep or original stuff…I’d consider having my room paid for all weekend a pretty good deal tbh.
 
Anyway, someone in our group had been penfriends with her and even met her once or twice, and we arranged a meal with about 10 people attending. When time for the meal came, Ms Primadonna had not shown up. She sent a message she was still coming. Everyone sat down, but didn’t order as it would be rude if we started before she got there. Time goes by…lots of time. Another message comes—she has a migraine, but she’s still coming. We wait. And wait. Another half hour or more goes by. We are now all starving and not sure what to do. Then ta-da, Primadonna finally swans into the room and plonks herself at the head of the table like a queen. No hello for anyone, a miserable, sour face. (OK, she had a migraine—why not just cancel if she felt that bad? I am a migraineur myself—doesn’t turn me into a jerk.)
 
She grabs the menu, more facial grimaces. “Ugh, I don’t like any of this…and guess what, when I went to the drugstore they don’t have the same painkillers as in America! I’m not taking anything foreign! I can’t believe i can’t get proper drugs!”
 
Silence started to fall over the table. Her tone was petulant, unfriendly and accusatory. Being mostly Brits/Canadians and a little more reserved than she was, no one said, “Why would you think you’d get the same painkillers?’ although you could tell everyone was thinking it.
 
She continued to moan about the menu and didn’t order; the rest of us finally ordered food. Primadonna didn’t seem to like the fact no one was continuously fussing about her headache/lack of drugs and suddenly said, “I have to go’ and disappeared from the restaurant. We tried to make excuses for her because she felt unwell but…
 
She was back at it the next day. I was going to buy her book but ahead of me, I saw a fan go up to her table, buy her stuff then ask for a photograph of her. She flung up a hand to her head in a melodramatic way like some dame in a panto. “Go on but I’ve had a headache…” she whined, all passive aggressive, making her FAN seriously uncomfortable and embarrassed.( There are nicer ways to say ‘no’, and if you are attending an event, you are in the public eye. Not one of the real celebs attending were anything like this.)
 
Later on Primadonna cornered my friend ( the penfriend) while she was walking in the hall with me and another lady. Now came the really cringey stuff. “There…there is DUST in my room,” she said, almost tremulously as if about to cry. Her lower lip was so outthrust in a pout, I thought she might trip on it. “I ran my finger along the ledge and saw it on my fingertip.”
 
(This was an old building, her room was free, and if there was dust in her room, it wasn’t in mine or anyone else’s!)
 
“Couldn’t you ask housekeeping to clean it?” my friend mumbled.
 
Primadonna rolled her eyes to heaven. “This is terrible! Dust! They can’t treat me like this! They can’t do this to me-I’M AN AMERICAN!”
 
There were three of us there besides Primadonna. A stunned silence fell. No one quite knew where to look after this cringe-worthy outburst.
 
Me and one other English girl hastily made our excuses and left the hall, unable to bear it anymore. The girl looked at me once we were out of earshot and started to laugh, “What a horrible, entitled, rude person!”
 
We avoided Primadonna after that but heard her tell people she was a black belt in karate, which seemed pretty implausible given her rather, um, unfit physique and the fact that every ache, pain or inconvenience was a big issue.
 
Later we heard she could not cope with the U.K. and cut her whole ‘research’ trip short and went home to the US early, losing loads of money! I guess she couldn’t handle the fact no one was falling all over her, catering to every whim just because she was American and wrote some fanfics.
 
Later the friend who’d met her in the past said, “I have no idea why she was freaking out about the dust. Her own house is full of brimming cigarette trays and she has about 20 cats!”

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Doing full-body workouts every day can have both benefits and drawbacks, depending on several factors such as your fitness level, workout intensity, and recovery practices. Here’s a breakdown:
 
Benefits:
Efficiency
: Full-body workouts allow you to target all major muscle groups in a single session, which can be time-efficient.
Increased Frequency
: Training each muscle group more frequently can lead to better muscle growth and strength gains, especially for beginners.
Caloric Burn
: More frequent workouts can help with weight management and improving cardiovascular fitness.
Drawbacks:
Recovery
: Muscles
Continue Reading
Doing full-body workouts every day can have both benefits and drawbacks, depending on several factors such as your fitness level, workout intensity, and recovery practices. Here’s a breakdown:
 
Benefits:
Efficiency
: Full-body workouts allow you to target all major muscle groups in a single session, which can be time-efficient.
Increased Frequency
: Training each muscle group more frequently can lead to better muscle growth and strength gains, especially for beginners.
Caloric Burn
: More frequent workouts can help with weight management and improving cardiovascular fitness.
Drawbacks:
Recovery
: Muscles need time to recover after workouts. Daily full-body training can lead to fatigue and overtraining, especially if the workouts are intense.
Injury Risk
: Without adequate recovery, the risk of injury increases due to wear and tear on muscles and joints.
Plateaus
: Constantly doing full-body workouts without variation may lead to plateaus in strength and muscle gains.
Recommendations:
Listen to Your Body
: If you feel fatigued or sore, consider taking rest days or alternating with lighter workouts.
Vary Intensity
: You might do high-intensity workouts a few times a week and lighter sessions or active recovery on other days.
Incorporate Rest Days
: Aim for at least one or two rest days per week to allow for muscle recovery.
Ultimately, the best approach depends on your individual goals, fitness level, and how your body responds to training. If you’re unsure, consulting a fitness professional can provide personalized guidance.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: After a long night of work, covering the liquor bar, because my regular bartender called out sick, I counted up my tips (which I usually didn’t receive as the manager). I decided to hit taco bell on the way home and get rid of some of the small bills I had received. In particular the $10 in $2 bills. When I went to pay at the drive thru, the cashier explained to me that $2 bills didn’t exist, and that they were fake. I pointed out that she was wrong, and asked her to get her manager. The manager proceeded to argue with me that they were fake money, gave it back, and gave me my meal for free.

Oh dear, where to start?
 
“So, you are Australian? That’s great! Do you ski in the Alps?”
 
“There are no “Alps” in Australia.”
 
“Yes there are, I’ve seen photos, and what about Hitler? He was originally from Australia, you know.”
 
While struggling to work out how to explain that Australia, and Austria, are just a little bit different, it went on:
 
“You know, it always upsets me when people know so little about where they come from.”
 
One more and I will stop, I promise. I used to live on a little island on the West coast of Canada that also happened to be a Port of Entry for marine traffic. So we saw a lot of vacationing boats coming up from Washington State. The rented 41 ft motor boats were the worst. They would come into the pub and look bewildered at the Canadian small change. Since the one dollar coin is one colour, and the two dollar coin is two colours, it was helpfully pointed out to them that this was universal across Canadian currency, and, if you counted the colours on a $50 bill, you would find fifty colours. Twenty minutes later, there they are, counting the colours.
 
Enough already! Ignorant American stories are like shooting ducks in a barrel. There are many clever and well informed people in America.
 
And there are those who voted for Donald Trump.
 
And of course, there is this young lady.

(which is a good choice btw) then you need a exercise that target all muscles at the same time.

Pull ups/chin ups(When you are able to do 20 pull ups, then you would be ready to do them with weights)
(Don’t think of other exercises than these two)
 
Now, you may ask how to do you do it. You do it by using progressive overload.
 
Progressive overload
 
It means you add 2,5 kg per week in your workouts. Let’s say you sumo-deadlift 20 kg. Next week 22,5 kg. next week 25 kg ,27,5kg, 30 kg and so on.
 
If it’s pull-up/chin up then you add 1 reps every week. Fx 2 pull up in week 1. 3 pull up in week 2. 4 pull up in week 5. 6 pull up in week 6. Simple, right?
 
2–3 times a week
 
See which one works best for you.
 
Diet:
 
Potatoes/brown rice(high carb= insulin better muscle growth)
 
All kinds of meat(just eat till you are full) It’s a myth that you need a lot of it.
 
Don’t run marathons
 
Running is great but more than 3 miles is unnescarry. HIIT or sprinting is better for fat loss and athlisme.
 
If you choose muscle building
 
Then you have to do a so called chest day, tricep day. Fx.
 
Monday: Chest & tricep
 
Thursaday: Back and biceps
 
Wednesday: Legs and shoulders
 
Thursday: abs
 
Friday: Idk, you choose
 
You choose isolation exercises like bicep curls and tricep extension.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It really has nothing to do with knowledge… ignorance is a mindset. I live in ‘America,’ and I’ve met my share of ignorant people, but the first person I’ve met who totally fit the bill was when I was in Canada, of all places, in Waterton National Park.
 
Back in the 1970s, our family vacationed in the Glacier/Waterton area. I was photographing a particularly friendly chipmunk when a man approached. “Amazing, isn’t it?”
 
“Yep,” I replied, scanning the near-overwhelming beauty of the mountains that surrounded us, “it sure is beautiful.”
 
“Not that. It’s amazing that all this was created only 7,542 (I’
Continue Reading
It really has nothing to do with knowledge… ignorance is a mindset. I live in ‘America,’ and I’ve met my share of ignorant people, but the first person I’ve met who totally fit the bill was when I was in Canada, of all places, in Waterton National Park.
 
Back in the 1970s, our family vacationed in the Glacier/Waterton area. I was photographing a particularly friendly chipmunk when a man approached. “Amazing, isn’t it?”
 
“Yep,” I replied, scanning the near-overwhelming beauty of the mountains that surrounded us, “it sure is beautiful.”
 
“Not that. It’s amazing that all this was created only 7,542 (I’m guessing here; don't recall the exact date) years ago, by God’s hand.”
 
I was stunned. How on Earth could anyone believe such drivel in an age of so much information? I asked him then, “If that’s so, where did the dinosaurs come from?”
 
“They weren’t dinosaurs, they were dragons that God decided couldn’t go on the Ark.”
 
Here’s an otherwise intelligent person who was convinced by others to swallow this bit of silliness.
 
The encounter has stayed with me since then.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I overheard a woman at a meeting tell another woman that she doesn’t drink milk when it’s hot outside. She said, “When it’s 90 degrees Fahrenheit outside or more, milk will curdle and spoil inside of your body.”
 
I wanted to correct the lady. However, I knew it would be of no use. She continued to talk to the other woman about milk going bad inside the body when it’s hot outside for a few more minutes.
 
Update: The average normal body temperature is 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit.

Let me clear this one thing out from here. fitness is not just about the gym and weight lifting and all that. Its anything that keeps you healthy. So here, I am going to share a few fun things to do which will also keep you fit and healthy.
 
1. Take a walking tour of your city.
On any other normal day, or a weekend, take a mere ride of your city, but wait! No vehicles please.
 
Walking through your city will bring you two benefits – One, it will give you time to explore your city and its people and Second, you will burn down on your calories. You see, A walk for keeping your mind and body healthy.
 
2. Zumba
 
Well, one can call it a fitness club party where you won’t even need drinks to dance. With Zumba, the workout doesn’t even look like a workout. An average person can burn up to a 1000 calorie in a Zumba class. And please call it a heaven for the people who love to dance.
 
3. Trekking
Who wouldn’t like burning down the calories to a beautiful view. You can just pin some treks to your bucket list and hit the mountains and those jungles every weekend. You will burn down a lot of calories as you reach that awesome view. Additionally, you will be above all the city chaos and bring peace to your mind. A Healthy mind leads to a healthy life.
 
4. Hit the ground
You won’t see fitness coming to you when you are a sports enthusiast. Exercise and sports can burn significant calories. The number of calories you burn depends on your weight and physical capabilities, the sport or activity and intensity level. Apart from burning the calories, Sports keeps your heart healthy and boosts your self-esteem.
 
5. Try something new.
 
This can be the best way to keep yourself healthy. The world is full of activities which can be fun and can keep you healthy at the same time. You can plan on doing things that you haven’t done before. You can ride horses, go hiking, get involved in some community service, or you can even play pokemon go if you haven’t played this awesome calorie burning game.
 
Easy, Isn’t it? Now you know how to plan your fun road to fitness.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
If you are looking forward to working out to make changes to your body (gaining muscles, losing fat…) it doesn’t make a lot of sense.
 
Your muscles will not be able to recover properly, which results in them not growing (or even getting weaker and smaller).
 
You should give your muscles a pause of 48 hours before exercising again.
 
This means that you can exercise two different muscle groups the day after, but you shouldn’t exercise twice a day, as your whole body will still not be recovered.
 
I hope this helps :)

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Lack of curiosity is the root of much ignorance. Here’s the story of my encounter with someone who demonstrated that point to me.
 
I was 29 and recently divorced. My ex and I had been regulars at a couple of local restaurants, and I kept going to one of them - a family-owned Thai restaurant. The owners had always treated us nicely, and knowing the situation they went out of their way to make me feel at home there. The restaurant had an open kitchen set off by a counter. I could sit there on my own without feeling self-conscious about it, and talk with the owners.
 
The owners’ oldest son went off t
Continue Reading
Lack of curiosity is the root of much ignorance. Here’s the story of my encounter with someone who demonstrated that point to me.
 
I was 29 and recently divorced. My ex and I had been regulars at a couple of local restaurants, and I kept going to one of them - a family-owned Thai restaurant. The owners had always treated us nicely, and knowing the situation they went out of their way to make me feel at home there. The restaurant had an open kitchen set off by a counter. I could sit there on my own without feeling self-conscious about it, and talk with the owners.
 
The owners’ oldest son went off to college so they had hired a young woman, 19 or 20 years old, to work as a waitress. After a couple of months, the owners started talking about setting us up. I treated it as a joke, but the third or fourth time the owners brought it up the young lady said she would be interested. I got the feeling she was being a good employee and just playing along. and I didn’t feel ready to start dating. The age difference seemed a bit much to me, too, so I made excuses.
 
I couldn’t deny, though, that she was very, very pretty, and in our limited interaction she was very friendly, and the owners were very, very persistent… So I finally asked her out to a movie and then afterward we went to a pub for a drink and dessert. That’s when we actually tried to have a real conversation.
 
It quickly became apparent that not only did we had very little in common, she didn’t know much about the world we live in either - outside of the confines of our small city, and outside of the interests of her circle of teenage friends. Trying to find something that we could talk about was painful!
 
Eventually, I did mention where I worked, and it turned out that her father worked for the same company. He had worked there all her life. Finally, there was an opening to ask a follow-up question! It was a big computer company, and I didn’t recognize her father’s name, so I asked what kind of work he did. She had no idea! I tried to lead her through it: engineering, sales, finance, HR, legal, manufacturing, hardware, software… Nothing rang a bell! She did know that the company made computers, but that was the extent of it. She had never seen her father’s office, never absorbed or asked any questions about what he did. It boggled my mind that someone could live to 19 or 20 years old without having even the slightest clue about what their parent did for work.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:

Continue Reading
Whether running every day is better than going to the gym every day depends on several factors, including your fitness goals, preferences, and physical condition. Here are some considerations for each option:
 
Running Every Day
 
Pros:
- 
Cardiovascular Benefits:
 Running improves cardiovascular health, increases lung capacity, and can enhance endurance.
- 
Weight Management:
 It is effective for burning calories and can help in weight loss or maintenance.
- 
Convenience:
 Running can be done almost anywhere and often requires minimal equipment (just a good pair of running shoes).
- 
Mental Health:
 Many people find running to be a great way to relieve stress and improve mood.
 
Cons:
- 
Injury Risk:
 Daily running can increase the risk of overuse injuries, such as shin splints or runner’s knee.
- 
Lack of Variety:
 Running alone may not provide a balanced workout for strength and flexibility.
 
Going to the Gym Every Day
 
Pros:
- 
Variety of Workouts:
 Gyms offer access to various equipment and classes, allowing for a balanced approach that includes strength training, cardio, and flexibility exercises.
- 
Strength Training:
 Resistance training helps build muscle, which can improve metabolism and overall strength.
- 
Social Interaction:
 Gyms can provide a social environment that may motivate some individuals.
 
Cons:
- 
Time Commitment:
 Going to the gym may require more time for travel and preparation.
- 
Cost:
 Gym memberships can be expensive compared to running, which is usually free.
 
Conclusion
 
Ultimately, the best choice depends on your individual goals. If your primary aim is to improve cardiovascular health and you enjoy running, then running every day might be better for you. If you’re looking for a more balanced fitness routine that includes strength training and flexibility, then going to the gym might be the way to go. 
 
Consider mixing both activities for a well-rounded fitness regimen, ensuring you also include rest days to prevent injury and allow for recovery.

There isn't that one best workout for everyone. Of course there are standard routines available but it really depends on a number of factors to come up with what works best for you. If your primary interest is enhancing muscle strength and size, here are a few factors you need to consider before committing to any rotuine:
Your primary goal: Are you purely interested in gaining more muscle strength, or simply to put on some more muscle? Are you looking to squezze in some Aerobics for your cardiovascular endurance?
Time: How much time are you willing to put in per week?
Focus areas: Are there anything specific areas of particular interest? Are you looking to get a more defined upper body/lower body? or just want a good six pack to take your physique to the next level?
Now having looked at that, let's go through a quick wrap-up of some of the most effective routines for strength and hypertrophy conditioning:
 
Full-body workout routine
 
This aims at hitting all the major muscle groups in one session. It's widely considered as one of the best approaches for beginners looking to up their general body strength before taking up some more specific approaches. Each workout day is typically followed by a rest day to allow for muscle recovery.
 
Split Routines
 
This approach emphasizes a particular body region or a group of muscles per workout day. Good examples include the Upper/Lower Body and Push/Pull/Legs (PPL) Split Routines. The former typically alternates between upper and lower body Workouts in the first 2 days followed by a rest/recovery day. The latter alternates Push and pull workouts in the first 2 days followed by a leg day.
 
Check out this comprehensive read for more details on workout routines and how you can go about choosing what should work best for you:
https://healthnuggetdotcom.wordpress.com/2021/07/07/workout-routines/

A good workout routine at home should be creative, detailed, and concise to ensure maximum efficiency and effectiveness.
 
Here's a comprehensive plan that requires minimal equipment while targeting all major muscle groups:
 
1. Warm-up (5-10 minutes):Start with light cardiovascular exercises such as jogging in place, jumping jacks, or high knees to increase heart rate and prepare muscles for activity.
 
2. Upper body strength training (15-20 minutes):
 
a) Push-ups: Perform 3 sets of 12 reps for chest, shoulders, and triceps.
 
b) Dips: Use a sturdy chair or elevated surface to perform 3 sets of 10 reps for triceps and chest.
 
c) Superman Pose: Lie face down on the floor with arms extended forward; lift your chest off the ground along with your legs simultaneously. Do 3 sets of 15 reps to target back muscles.
 
3. Lower body strength training (15-20 minutes):
 
a) Squats: Stand with feet hip-width apart and lower into a sitting position while keeping your weight on heels; do 4 sets of 12 reps for glutes, quads, hamstrings.
 
b) Lunges: Step forward with one foot until both knees are at a right angle then push back up; repeat alternating legs for a total of 3 sets of 12 reps per leg focusing on glutes and quads.c) Calf raises: Stand on an elevated surface like stairs or use dumbbells if available; perform calf raises by raising heels as high as possible then lowering them below the step level. Aim for three sets of fifteen repetitions.
 
4. Core exercises (10-15 minutes):
 
a) Plank: Assume push-up position but rest forearms instead of palms on the ground; hold this position engaging core muscles for three sets lasting thirty seconds each.
 
b) Bicycle crunches: Lie flat on your back with hands behind head, bring one knee towards your chest while simultaneously touching it with the opposite elbow. Repeat for 3 sets of 15 reps per side to engage abs and obliques.
 
c) Russian twists: Sit on the floor with knees bent and feet elevated off the ground; twist your torso from side to side, touching hands to the ground each time. Aim for three sets of twenty repetitions.
 
5. Cardiovascular exercise (20-30 minutes):Choose activities that elevate heart rate such as jumping rope, jogging in place, or performing high-intensity interval training exercises like burpees or mountain climbers. Alternate between high-intensity bursts and short rest periods for an effective cardio workout.
 
6. Cool-down & Stretching (5-10 minutes):
 
Finish your routine by gradually slowing down movements and stretching major muscle groups like hamstrings, quadriceps, calves, shoulders, and chest.Remember to stay hydrated throughout your workout routine by drinking water regularly. Modify exercises based on fitness levels and always listen to your body's signals - if any pain or discomfort arises during a particular exercise, consult a professional before continuing. Stay motivated by setting goals and tracking progress regularly!

Oh my goodness…where do I start…
 
I am not an american btw…
 
My ex-boyfriend (from the U.S) asked my dad once if Ontario was a state, or a country.
 
My friend (from Texas) told me she doesn’t know how she is alive because she never drinks water. She said she drinks gatorade after track, but was genuinely amazed she was still alive because she didn’t drink plain old water.
 
One time, our Canadian hockey team was playing against a Michigan team… over the phone I asked a customer at work (from Michigan) if he watched the game. He said he did, but he wasn’t sure where British Columbia was in the U.S.A, and assumed it was somewhere near New York.
 
A Montana server asked me if i lived in an igloo, and later, if I knew what Walmart was.
 
A police officer who stopped me in Utah asked me who our president was in canada, I said we have a prime minister. He said “No, I said CANADA… not England”. I just agreed with him, i didn’t want to end up in Provo prison for being a smart ass.
 
In Wyoming, I once was asked what language we speak in Canada. When I said “english” the woman responded “You must know we hate French people, otherwise you wouldn’t be lying about your native tongue!” and then winked at me. I still don’t know if she was being sarcastic or genuinely thought i was lying. I don’t even know how to ask for directions in french…why would I speak french when i sound like I talk through my nose and say ‘eh’ after every question… Even Quebec people don’t even sound french…
 
My south african cousin asked a woman in best buy for “iphone hook-ups” and she thought he was hitting on her. All he wanted was a charger for his phone, she asked him why he didn’t just say that in the first place. She also said she liked his British accent, he said he was South African, and she laughed and said he was funny.
 
During a visit in 2015, one woman on the NYC subway loudly asked her friend why ISIS named themselves after an Americas Next Top Model Contestant. I’ve seen that season… although momunental for the LTBTQ crowd, it certainly wouldn’t have influenced muslim extremists. What made it worse was her friend said “I think they did it to mislead the public or something…” and when a helpful commuter said quietly “its an acronym actually” they both looked at him as if he had two heads and said “we don’t really need your help thanks…”
 
NOTE: most of these people were so so lovely, but i was just surprised at the small world some people live in. I’m sure this rings true in other places in the world, but man… i’ve had a lot of run-ins with ignorance.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The most ignorant American I have ever met is a man who once worked with my Vietnamese husband, who actually believed that the refugees who poured into the United States and Europe during the 1970’s were Northern Vietnamese Communists, aka “Viet Cong.”
 
As a war veteran, this guy believed it was his right and duty to harass, verbally abuse, and basically make my husband’s already difficult life a living hell. What made it especially awful is that my husband had an uncle who spent 16 years in a “re-education camp” for working directly with American soldiers during the war.

article:

I have two daughters I should earn a minimum of $2200 a month to pay my rents, office rent $250, car rent $350, house rent $450, children school $115, staff salary 270, food and other expenses the rest.
 
No saving,no house. This is upper muddle class in Ethiopia. This is poverty, we rarely do what we want with this income.
 
Second question “Internet is cheap?”
 
We pay $5.89 to get a one month package of 1GB. Which runs out as fast as a jet.

I’m 41, spend on average 15 minutes a day exercising, yet have a resting heart rate of 38–44 beats per minute.
 
That’s in line with many athletes!
 
But I’m a middle-aged entrepreneur?
 
Your resting heart rate broadly tells you how fit you are - the lower the better. Anything below 60 is very good.
 
You can measure yours now.
 
So how have I got mine so low?
 
By simply following the advice from studies.
 
Plenty show that the most effective way to get fit is to do 
a minute or two of exercise a day at maximum capacity 
a few days a week.
 
That’s it!
 
No need to run for hours.
 
So here’s what I’ve incorporated in my life…
I live on the 40th floor, so I often run up the stairs. It takes me around 7 minutes.
At home I skip with a skipping/jump rope for 3–5 mins, and do quick sets of press-ups or bar pulls. Total workout time less than 10 minutes.
Play squash - intense 30 minutes.
Runs - 7 - 10 minutes.
I try to do something everyday. And yes, I don’t do only a minute or two - it doesn’t feel satisfying enough.
 
I’ve got my son using these techniques. I’m not making this shit up, but his coach did some Cooper Test which says he’s almost fit enough to be a Premiership footballer, and he’s just turned 11.
That’s him on the left.
 
For more information Google “HIIT” or watch this video.
Anyway, so there you have it…

Yes, I am poor and I am on Quora. I am on Quora not because I could access internet for cheap but because I would like to explore myself and improve my personality. I might be facing poverty now, but I am damn sure that I am not going to die with that.
 
Let me tell you my story......My father is a farmer. Till my 10th standard I was not mature enough to understand my parents' hardwork. After that I stayed in hostel in Hyderabad for my Intermediate. And by god's grace I got free seat in one of the top 10 engineering Colleges in Hyderabad. Then I moved to another hostel at Uppal in Hyderabad. I chose that hostel so that my father would pay the less amount of rent(Rs.3000/- per month, which is the minimum amount of rent in that area). I teach home tuitions for two hours in the evening after returning from the college to support my father somewhat financially. Now, due to corona I am not doing that and I came to my hometown. These days, I came to know how hard my father works daily to lead our family. He always tries his best to provide us with all we want. I am happy to say that I am blessed with lovable parents and supportive sibling. I feel rich to have them.
 
I am going to enter into the final year of my bachelors very soon. I wish I could get placed in one of the reputed companies and overcome our poverty and make my parents happy.
And ofcourse I could use this platform since I could get internet for cheap. Thanks to Ambani 
:)

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Oh many many…
 
But some years back I went on a first date. After dinner, we were parked, looking at the stars, my arm around her shoulder. The conversation gradually disclosed the astounding fact that she thought scientists and technicians in white lab coats with computers and clipboards devoted themselves solely to the arduous task of counting as high as they possibly could.
 
Just counting!
 
“Have they been able to count to a billion yet?” she asked me—her blonde hair shining in the moonlight. Flummoxed…I knew I would regret any possible relationship this led to, and took her home.
 
.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
The issue is that if you train your full body to your maximum effort every day, you won’t be able to recover properly and suffer from over training and will actually make less progress.
 
This is why it is recommended to split your exercises and focus on different muscle groups everyday so that whilst you workout one set of muscle groups, the others get a chance to recover which is important for growth.

It happened many years ago, in Spain, with an exchange student still in his teens.
I had never realized before to which extent some folks from a relatively new country lack historical perspective, as compared to what we are used to in Europe.
 
I will always remember two unconnected questions in particular, from the same person:
The guy once asked me, in the middle of a conversation about Jesus and Palestine, whether the Romans did use rifles. Yes, like you read it. I am not sure what he thought the Romans were actually and where to locate them on a timeline.
A few days later, while visiting a museum of baroque wooden sculptures from the 18th century, he went to touch one of those religious sculptures (which you obviously shouldn’t) and claimed these felt like there were made of… plastic!! I remained speechless, obviously.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article: A full body routine 3 days a week is definitely your best bet to get results without spending a ton of time at the gym. Working each muscle group 3 times a week is adequate to properly train your body. However, the one downside to this plan is that you may be fatigued at the end of your full body workouts and the muscle groups you work last may start to fall behind. To combat this, be sure to mix up which groups you work first at the gym!

She was passed a handful of coins . . . every one of them a British coin!
 
When she pointed out that the dispensers required U.S. Quarters, the woman responded by asking:
 
"Oh! Does it have to be American money?".

article:

’s speeches during which she has proven to be about the dumbest, most ignorant public persona, I have ever heard butcher her own native language. Trump, as bad as he is, is only a distant 2nd to Palin in incoherent commentary.
She’s a great example of where our nation is heading in the immediate future. However, I fear her Stupidity, Dogmatism, and & Anti-Intellectualism will pass as “intelligent musings” under a Trump Presidency. “Oh, youbetcha’” Maybe a White House position, 
“Secretary of Bad Speeches?”
I’ll let her

Though I’ve never met her in person, I have listened carefully to 
Sarah Palin
’s speeches during which she has proven to be about the dumbest, most ignorant public persona, I have ever heard butcher her own native language. Trump, as bad as he is, is only a distant 2nd to Palin in incoherent commentary.
She’s a great example of where our nation is heading in the immediate future. However, I fear her Stupidity, Dogmatism, and & Anti-Intellectualism will pass as “intelligent musings” under a Trump Presidency. “Oh, youbetcha’” Maybe a White House position, 
“Secretary of Bad Speeches?”
I’ll let her insipid words demonstrate my point:
 
“We believe that the best of America is in these small towns that we get to visit, and in these wonderful little pockets of what I call the real America, being here with all of you hardworking, very patriotic, um, very, um, pro-America areas of this great nation.”
 
“You mentioned education, and I'm glad that you did. I know education you are passionate about with your wife being a teacher for 30 years, and God bless her. Her reward is in heaven, right?” 
Doh? Heaven? How about a livable paycheck?
 
When Katie Couric asked Palin the “complex trick question” of where she gets her news, the two women had the following exchange:
 
Couric: “And when it comes to establishing your world view, I was curious, what newspapers and magazines did you regularly read before you were tapped for this -- to stay informed and to understand the world?”
 
Palin: “I've read most of them again with a great appreciation for the press, for the media…”
 
Couric: “But what ones specifically? I'm curious.”
 
Palin: “Um, all of them, any of them that have been in front of me over all these years.” 
Where, in the dentist’s office?
 
Couric: “Can you name any of them?
 
Palin: 
“I have a vast variety of sources where we get our news.”
 
One sure sign of an imbecile is referring oneself in the plural, “we.”
 
In 2010, while speaking at a fundraiser at California State University. Sarah Palin made the mistake of claiming that Eureka College, which is in Illinois, was in California.
 "This is Reagan country. Yeah! And perhaps it was destiny that the man who went to California's Eureka College would become so woven within and inter-linked to the Golden State." 
Doh?
 
In 2010, Sarah Palin referred to Kodiak Island as the largest island in the United States. 
"As we work and sightsee on America's largest island, we'll get to view more majestic bears, so now is a good time to draw attention to the political equivalent of the species.” 
Sorry Sarah, but that would be Hawaii, and what is the “political equivalent of species?”
 
“Hey, the more they’re pouring it on, the more I’m going to bug the crap out of them by being out there, with a voice, with the message, Hopefully running for office in the future too … Bless their hearts, those haters out there. They don’t understand that it invigorates me. It wants me to get out there and defend the innocent…”
 
While at a motorcycle rally in 2011. Sarah Palin dropped this unforgettable quote,
 “
I love that smell of the emissions!” 
How about the taste? A little viscous and salty, I hear.
 
“Maybe our kids could be defended against criminals on the spot if more Mama Grizzlies carried [guns]. And [the] Obama administration wants you ID’d for that? Well, then go ahead and carry a sign too. A sign that says ‘Yeah, I carry a gun because a cop is too heavy.’” Then, 
saying that creating gun-free zone schools and other public buildings is “stupid on steroids.”
 Yes, she’s truly an expert on stupid.
 
In 2011, while, on the O’Reilly Factor, Sarah Palin was asked how she’d fix the Oil spill in the Gulf. Her insightful response was, 
“The Dutch and the Norwegians, they are known for dikes and for cleaning up water and for dealing with spills.”
 
In 2010, while, on the Glenn Beck Show, Palin was asked how she would deal with rising tensions between North and South Korea. Her response, 
"
But obviously, we've got to stand with our North Korean allies."
 
And my personal favorite: In 2011, when asked about Paul Revere’s midnight ride, Palin had this to say. 
"He who warned, uh, the British that they weren't gonna be takin' away our arms, uh, by ringing those bells, and um, makin' sure as he's riding his horse through town to send those warning shots and bells that we were going to be sure and we were going to be free, and we were going to be armed."
 
Ms. Palin is a stunning example of the 
“Dunning-Kruger Effect”
 in action, which basically maintains that 
there are people so stupid that they don’t even realize they are stupid
, and see themselves as clever.
 
“The Dunning–Kruger effect is a cognitive bias in which low-ability individuals suffer from illusory superiority, mistakenly assessing their ability as much higher than it really is. Dunning and Kruger attributed this bias to a metacognitive incapacity, on the part of those with low ability, to recognize their ineptitude and evaluate their competence accurately.” 
Dunning–Kruger effect - Wikipedia
 
See also: 
The Psychological Quirk That Explains Why You Love Donald Trump
 
Nuff said? “You Betcha!”

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?

Like, you could do a push/pull split, meaning that one day you do excercises that you push away from you to perform, and the next day you do exercises that you pull towards you to perform. Examples of pushing exercises could be bench press, shoulder/military press, or tricep push downs. Then for pulling you could do pull downs, rows, bicep curls and whatnot. You’d want to have a day where you trained legs, too. Or if you 
Continue Reading
It depends on what you’re doing, and what you’re looking for. If you want to get big, don’t do full body workouts. Split your workout into muscle groups or types of movement. Like, you could do a push/pull split, meaning that one day you do excercises that you push away from you to perform, and the next day you do exercises that you pull towards you to perform. Examples of pushing exercises could be bench press, shoulder/military press, or tricep push downs. Then for pulling you could do pull downs, rows, bicep curls and whatnot. You’d want to have a day where you trained legs, too. Or if you split it into muscle groups, which is what I do, you would do chest one day, another day do back, another day do shoulders, another day do arms. If you’re dead set on doing full body workouts, keep it to three days a week so your body can recover properly.

I studied abroad in a well-known Northern American university two years ago. I had the whole experience, as a foreign student, and lived on campus, met people with different background. I took English and linguistics classes and in one of them, I was talking about American Sign Language (ASL) and how similar it was from the French Sign Language since it is largely based on it and the two are quite intelligible.
 
I had to explain to this American young woman, about my age, that there is indeed numerous sign languages in the world, as there is spoken languages. She just couldn't believe there was more than one language — and that it was not ‘gesturing’. Also, did not believe me when I said they developed naturally. I have no idea if I made her change her mind but I made my point nonetheless.

title: How workout exercises?
article:
Muscles grow when you push them beyond their limits, either by metabolic stress (many reps and high lactic acid levels), or by mechanical stress (lifting heavy weights that tear up muscle cell tissue). So if you want big and strong muscles that can withstand the test of time and whatever life throws at you, I recommend you do both. Follow a varied routine that challenges your body in both ways, one week of each, constantly alternating. Doing the same workout every week is both boring and not productive. There is no magical number of sets. When going for mechanical stress it is possible to achi
Continue Reading
Muscles grow when you push them beyond their limits, either by metabolic stress (many reps and high lactic acid levels), or by mechanical stress (lifting heavy weights that tear up muscle cell tissue). So if you want big and strong muscles that can withstand the test of time and whatever life throws at you, I recommend you do both. Follow a varied routine that challenges your body in both ways, one week of each, constantly alternating. Doing the same workout every week is both boring and not productive. There is no magical number of sets. When going for mechanical stress it is possible to achieve the desired effect after only 1 set, just make sure warming up properly. When the muscle tissue is torn and damaged, it will start a regenerating process that rebuilds and reinforces the damaged area. Normally it is ok to perform 2 and even 3 sets of this kind of tissue-breaking training, and 2 exercises will be plenty, making sure to hit the muscle from different angles and causing growth in a large area. 
 
For the metabolical stress effect you will need more reps and less weights, but again- there is no magical number of exercises. Do as many as you want to, and I recommend you superset them or giantset them, in order to hit the same muscle from many different angles, all in one highrep round of exercises. I like to do 3 exercises on each musclegroup, for 3 rounds of trisets, when doing this kind of training. It can come up to a total of 45 reps on one round, doing 15 reps on 3 exercises with no rest in between, on the same muscle. it will give you the most insane feeling of pump, and surely cause a very good environment for growth. The levels of natural growth hormones is highly affected by this, and this is the reason why people call the high-rep range hypertrophy training. It usually takes 3 exercises to train a muscle from all the relevant angles/lengths, so that answers your question I guess.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
Conventional wisdom says beginners should do full body workouts 2–3 days a week and advanced lifters should do splits.
 
My lifting “career” however has gone the other way around. As a teenager I was influenced by bodybuilding magazines and always tried to train like the pros, which meant splits, going to the gym five times a week and training different muscle groups on each day.
 
These days, in my late thirties, I do mostly full body workouts. When you have a family and a job, you don’t have a lot of time to train and the reality is that you will skip workouts. For this reason, I always do full bo
Continue Reading
Conventional wisdom says beginners should do full body workouts 2–3 days a week and advanced lifters should do splits.
 
My lifting “career” however has gone the other way around. As a teenager I was influenced by bodybuilding magazines and always tried to train like the pros, which meant splits, going to the gym five times a week and training different muscle groups on each day.
 
These days, in my late thirties, I do mostly full body workouts. When you have a family and a job, you don’t have a lot of time to train and the reality is that you will skip workouts. For this reason, I always do full body although I try to accentuate certain muscle groups.
 
As an individual, you need to consider that theory isn’t everything. For me, a full body workout gives me so much more satisfaction, as I get a feeling of all around tiredness and I feel like I’ve done something good for the whole body. When I do get sore it feels so much more natural. Having only sore arms for example feels kind of weird. I prefer an overall feeling of slight soreness.
 
My advice is to just do what feels right to you and keeps you motivated.

article:
My mum’s hairdresser. My parents were living in D.C., I was visiting from The Netherlands. He asked me where I was from - so I told him, “The Netherlands”. The conversation that followed was so uninformed about geography and history that I can’t even recall correctly what the line of conversation was, but it involved questions about whether the country Amsterdam was near The Netherlands, what it was like to live in a “former Soviet Union block country”, what it’s like to “have your own language” (after he heard me speak Dutch to my mother), whether Paris is in Germany, and it got worse after t

My mum’s hairdresser. My parents were living in D.C., I was visiting from The Netherlands. He asked me where I was from - so I told him, “The Netherlands”. The conversation that followed was so uninformed about geography and history that I can’t even recall correctly what the line of conversation was, but it involved questions about whether the country Amsterdam was near The Netherlands, what it was like to live in a “former Soviet Union block country”, what it’s like to “have your own language” (after he heard me speak Dutch to my mother), whether Paris is in Germany, and it got worse after that.
 
He was a nice guy and I couldn’t blame him for not caring about the details of European countries, but it did teach me that the US itself is two very different countries, and in some cases it only takes a 10 mile drive from Bethesda to Virginia to understand this.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
So technically yes but with a major caveat.
 
Here is the thing, what you’re talking about isn’t “working out”. In order to strengthen muscles, we need to WORK OUT hard enough to cause microscopic tears in the muscle. Then, with adequate nutrition and rest, the fibers repair themselves and we end up stronger. You can’t do this three times a day.
 
If you’re messing around with light weights 3 times a day, you’re not adequately stressing the muscle to cause these microscopic tears.
 
A better plan is increase the intensity of the workout to the point that you’ve exhausted the muscles. Then get good slee
Continue Reading
So technically yes but with a major caveat.
 
Here is the thing, what you’re talking about isn’t “working out”. In order to strengthen muscles, we need to WORK OUT hard enough to cause microscopic tears in the muscle. Then, with adequate nutrition and rest, the fibers repair themselves and we end up stronger. You can’t do this three times a day.
 
If you’re messing around with light weights 3 times a day, you’re not adequately stressing the muscle to cause these microscopic tears.
 
A better plan is increase the intensity of the workout to the point that you’ve exhausted the muscles. Then get good sleep, good nutrition and let your muscles get strong. So either heavier weights, more reps, slower movement to keep your muscles stressed for a longer amount of time. Pick all of these if you want.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
A2A.
 
I don’t work out at home and never have.
 
I go to a powerlifting club I started 3 times a week and train and coach for about two hours.
 
My routine has varied a lot over the years but in general I squat 2–3 times a week, deadlift 1–2 times a week, bench press 2–3 times a week and do various other exercises to assist, chins, pull-ups, rows, power cleans, front squats, presses and curls. I usually do 1–5 work sets of each after 3–5 warmup sets.
 
I walk or ride a bike to work five days a week.

My 
hairdresser
 didn’t know the difference between 
a millimeter
 and 
an inch
!!
 
I normally keep my hair very short. Commonly called a ‘No. 1’ hair clipper.
This is a No. 1 attachment on most US hair clippers.
 
So I go in for a routine hair cut and told her that I would like - A No. 1 all over.
 
For those who haven’t gotten this done, this is how short it looks on the head.
So, you see how short that is? Now, you would wonder who could possibly confuse that with the measurement of 1 inch right?
 
Not this lady. When I asked her for a No. 1, she replies “So a 1 inch all over?”
 
I replied slightly surprised “Umm, no, I would like a No.1 all over, that is not 1 inch, its about 3 millimeters around 1/8th of an inch.”
 
She looked at me as though I insulted her ancestors.
 
She proceeds to lecture me about how in the US hair measurements are all in inches and no one uses millimeters. Then she proceeds to tell me how she has never seen a millimeter measurement on any of the hair clippers and adds that maybe in my country that is how they do. And then tops it all off by asking me “Is this how they teach how to cut hair in your country?”
 
Now, at this point, I was offended. I had half a mind to tell her to look at the freaking attachment which says 1/8 inch (3mm) and complain to her manager that she was making remarks using terms like “In this country”. But, I decided against it, not to make a big fuss about it, and let her cut my hair with the correct attachment by pointing to it.
 
I understand that in the US, the metric system is not followed but come on, its right there on the clipper.
 
Sure enough, I’m not going there again.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
Assuming that you have proper range of motion and basic working knowledge of exercising, breathing, and good nutrition.
 
Saturday and Wednesday: 5 -10 min cardio(work up a sweat)
 
2–3 dynamic stretches
 
A set or three of warm up sets before each exercise(e.g. warm up set of 135 lbs for 10–12 reps, then working set of 225 lbs for 8–10 reps)
 
Working Compound Sets:
 
3 sets of 8–10 reps of squats, 4 sets of 8–10 reps on the bench press, 2 sets of 8–10 reps of dead-lifts
