Climb a tree - Unorthodox I know but it covers pushing, pulling, flexibility, balance, coordination, fun, well being, and it will hit you in a million different angles so it will make you rounded, functional, and strong in your muscles, joints, and connective tissue. Just don’t fall!
 
Sprints - Sprints cover cardio of course but also build powerful and strong legs and hips. They’ll help you build muscle throughout your body from the hormonal benefits. They’ll give you tons of explosiveness and power. And they only take a few minutes out of the day.
 
Swimming- Sprints are great cardio but they can really beat you up if that’s all you do. Swimming can be slower paced, it burns tons of calories, its easier on your joints, and its fun!
 
That’s my three. What do you guys think?

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
A great deal depends on your current state of fitness, and what it is you’re trying to accomplish.
 
Pro athletes, Olympic competitors… May spend 4–6 hours in training per day. However, these are elite athletes and all training is done under the watchful eyes of professional coaches and trainers.
 
For the average person who’s in fair-decent shape, most authorities recommend a minimum of 1.5 hours of aerobic exercise per week. That ain’t much…Several half-hour workouts weekly.
 
Much better, if you have the time, is a 45-minute to 0ne hour aerobic workout daily. That’s 10 minutes of warm up, 10 minutes
Continue Reading
A great deal depends on your current state of fitness, and what it is you’re trying to accomplish.
 
Pro athletes, Olympic competitors… May spend 4–6 hours in training per day. However, these are elite athletes and all training is done under the watchful eyes of professional coaches and trainers.
 
For the average person who’s in fair-decent shape, most authorities recommend a minimum of 1.5 hours of aerobic exercise per week. That ain’t much…Several half-hour workouts weekly.
 
Much better, if you have the time, is a 45-minute to 0ne hour aerobic workout daily. That’s 10 minutes of warm up, 10 minutes of cool down, and 35–40 minutes of work with your heart-rate in the “aerobic training” zone.
 
If you’re doing calisthenic/bodyweight training, then a good, full-body workout that takes about an hour 4–5 times a week is decent.
 
If you’re doing weight training, then a full-body workout 3 times a week should take you 1.5 hours or so….. And if you’re more advanced and doing “split” routines, then your 5-times a week (usually) workout should take around an hour.

Years ago I was working for a temp agency. I was sent on a long assignment and found myself working next to a young woman. The first day, she mentioned that she was a born again Christian, which I usually dread because every conversation leads to Jesus. But she didn’t mention it again that day, even though we had lunch together, so I thought she might be okay. The next day she started talking. Anyone sitting next to her got the hard sell, and she never stopped chattering. After a couple of days, she told me how the Bible in English is the eyewitness account and absolute word of god. I took the opportunity and asked if that was true of the Quran as well. She said it was. After a pause, she said, “That’s the first five books of the Bible, right?”

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was in a pub in Ennis, in County Clare, Ireland in September 2022, enjoying an early evening session that included a harpist. An American tourist walked in, pointed at the harp, and loudly exclaimed, “Oh look, she’s playing the Guinness symbol! I wonder what that’s called?”.
 
Being ignorant is one thing - displaying your ignorance at the top of your voice while a group of five talented musicians are playing is truly something else.

Continue Reading
Fourth of July parades are an excellent way to learn about American society.
 
This year, I had the luck of being the only foreigner at a Rhode Island boat parade. We were riding a beautiful white motor boat decorated in stripes and stars, followed by 10 other boats and an even bigger US flag, with full-volume Souza marches coming from 6 huge speakers, echoing over the lake. The men were wearing stripy - starry swimming shorts and the women were dressed in matching bikinis. Waterbombs would be fired from the boats and the shore, aiming at the passengers of the other boats passing by. The smell of barbecue filled the air. The atmosphere was so exaggeratedly festive and typical, I had to rub my eyes to check if it's still there when my vision becomes clear.
 
The bikini women cheered and soon everyone began shouting ‘Happy birthday, America!’ This is when a smug look appeared on my face. I just had to do the experiment.
 
The following conversation occurred between me and one of the stripy ladies yelling ‘Happy birthday America!’:
 
‘How old is she?’
 
‘Who?’
 
‘America.’
 
‘Uhh…I was never really good at History.’
 
Then she just turned away from me and I did my best not to laugh while picturing an exceptionally well organized, awesome birthday party where the majority of the guests have no idea how old the birthday person actually is.

article:
So there's this story of a Greek man who bought an ox. Everyday he had to carry it up mountain to let it drink from a spring. I think the movie Holes showed this to some extent. Anyway, as the ox got heavier, the man carried it. Eventually when the ox was a big mature ox, the man had very big muscles and could lift an ox. Which weighs a few hundred pounds. He went from carrying a baby ox to something huge.

Continue Reading
So there's this story of a Greek man who bought an ox. Everyday he had to carry it up mountain to let it drink from a spring. I think the movie Holes showed this to some extent. Anyway, as the ox got heavier, the man carried it. Eventually when the ox was a big mature ox, the man had very big muscles and could lift an ox. Which weighs a few hundred pounds. He went from carrying a baby ox to something huge. 
 
This story is a simplified example of the principle of overload, specificity, and profession. 
 
To grow muscles you need to overload them. To an extent. Small micro tears from training will stimulate new repairs and extra bulk be added to the muscle fibers. So if you had to carry or life a 50 pound object everyday, at first it will be hard, eventually it would get easier until it'll be no effort at all.  But eventually the body will adapt to the point where you need to add more weight if you want to get stronger or bigger. 
 
That's the principle of overload and profession. 
 
The principle of specificity basically says, if you want to get good at running, run more. Specify in what you want to achieve in. If you want to be able to life more weight, life more weight. If you want to be a good mountain climber, climb more mountains etc.
 
So there you have it. To get stronger you need to do more. Stress the body more. 
 
Look into nutrition. Much of "reaping the benefits" of training occur in the kitchen. Consume healthy fats and proteins. Limit carbs but keep in mind that carbs are needed for insulin which help stimulate muscle growth. 
 
Also if you ever do get back into the gym. 
1-5 reps = strength 7-10 = mass 11+ = endurance 
 
As for now, purchase some body weights and train with those. Doing pull-ups with an extra twenty pound weight on your chest is hard! Good luck.

title: How to workout
article:
When we decide to exercise , three fundamental questions arise: which is the most appropriate, how many weekly sessions we need and, above all, when we will see some effect. The best option is the circuits in which four or five different types of activities alternate with rest periods between series and series . Coaches say that without killing themselves and choosing the activity table, the body will notice in 66 days.
Plan the session; Exhausting is not a guarantee of good results
 
What is better, to train strength or resistance? We are facing the eternal question when it comes to exercising. W
Continue Reading
When we decide to exercise , three fundamental questions arise: which is the most appropriate, how many weekly sessions we need and, above all, when we will see some effect. The best option is the circuits in which four or five different types of activities alternate with rest periods between series and series . Coaches say that without killing themselves and choosing the activity table, the body will notice in 66 days.
Plan the session; Exhausting is not a guarantee of good results
 
What is better, to train strength or resistance? We are facing the eternal question when it comes to exercising. We arise because we have little time in day to day and we want, logically, to get the most out of our activity. But choosing between both is a wrong view, since it leads us in most cases to the mistake of hitting an aerobic bludgeon, thinking that with it we will burn more fats , or routines with a lot of weight in order to gain more muscle.
 
The reality is that people who manage to train continuously do so on average twice a week and no more than forty minutes each time . With this average, if we want to generate significant changes in our body to improve health and aesthetics, we have to change our perspective. By focusing one day on muscle mass and another on aerobic exercises, the stimulus to which the body is subjected is insignificant, even if we end up exhausted.
The reason is that the organism does not know if it runs in front of a lion to survive - and is making an extra effort for it - or if it trains for a healthy goal. So, if you are sitting for eight hours or so many hours standing up and suddenly an intense and unordered physical activity is imposed, your tendency will be to protect yourself. It will neither burn more fat, nor generate more muscle; on the contrary, it will try to reserve itself and spend as little as possible, in case the effort is prolonged in time. Your reaction is biologically logical.
 
So, what is the ideal dynamic? The answer is very simple: combine the two modalities in the same session or at different times but within the same day. The professionals call it concurrent training. However, after answering the first question, at least two more questions arise. The first: how much time is necessary to use to notice significant changes in the body? And the second: how to combine strength and resistance exercises in each session?
 
The magic figure: nine and a half weeks
 
The University College of London sets at 66 the days necessary to generate or change a habit or to achieve the goal that we set. You rarely get to the ten weeks of training followed. Most of us move by peaks of intensity. There are two periods that are key: the beginning of the year, when many people join a gym or start running; and towards the month of May, coinciding with the fact that the first hot days make us see summer around the corner.
Many coaches propose that we divide our goals into blocks of 66 days. This will not only help us see results, but also motivate us with a goal that has a beginning and an end. Once you have made the decision, you have to plan the exercise with realism. How much time do I train? The American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate intensity exercise every week spread over five days - a half hour a day - or three sessions of between twenty minutes and one hour of vigorous activity .
 
This is ideal, however, the perfect dose is one that is compatible with the activities of daily and working life in the medium and long term. To achieve the goal, you have to be practical. Therefore, every session we take, even if it is ten minutes, should be used to the maximum and have all the necessary components so that our health improves little by little.
A circuit with which we could start today would be this:
 
1) 200 meters running or walking ;
 
2) Ten squats;
 
3) Eight push-ups.
 
4) Six vertical jumps and return to run or walk 200 meters.
 
We should do it twice, with thirty seconds of rest between each exercise and two minutes of rest between circuit and circuit. The training lasts between twenty-five and thirty minutes.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My mum was visiting New York and she had an accident so went to the hospital to get some stitches.
 
When the nurse asked for her address my mum said she’s visiting from Cyprus. She didn’t expect the nurse to know it, it’s only a small island at the other side of the planet, so when the nurse asked where it is, my mum said “it’s in Europe”.
 
So the nurse said: 
“That’s fine, we’ll send the bill there. Could you please spell Europe?
”

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I’m in high school, and I just overhead two girls having this debate:
 
Girl 1: What are you talking about? There are countries in Africa.
 
Girl 2: No way. There are only states, It has eight of them.
 
Girl 1: Have you heard of Egypt? Thats a country.
 
Girl 2: But thats in Asia. There are no countries in America, only states, so it’s the same way in Africa.
 
This argument went on and on for around five minutes until they both eventually gave up.
 
It is true that we have had very learned very little geography in school, but I assumed that
 
the fact that there are countries in Africa is common knowledge.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
When I was the anchorman for the weekly news magazine program European Journal, (produced by Germany’s international broadcaster Deutsche Welle) a chief producer was hired from LA. His MO was, if the US doesn’t touch or influence our reports they wouldn’t get on the air. At the second staff meeting I asked him a number of questions: where is Serajevo (he’d never heard of it), what is the capital of Germany (he said Berlin … at the time it was Bonn), name the allied countries in wwii (he told us the US single handedly won wwii). He had to make a one day lay over in Vancouver, the first time he 
Continue Reading
When I was the anchorman for the weekly news magazine program European Journal, (produced by Germany’s international broadcaster Deutsche Welle) a chief producer was hired from LA. His MO was, if the US doesn’t touch or influence our reports they wouldn’t get on the air. At the second staff meeting I asked him a number of questions: where is Serajevo (he’d never heard of it), what is the capital of Germany (he said Berlin … at the time it was Bonn), name the allied countries in wwii (he told us the US single handedly won wwii). He had to make a one day lay over in Vancouver, the first time he had been to Canada. He was in disbelief that the city had skyscrapers. How did this ignorant jerk get the job? We found out he lied on his CV. I led a staff rebellion and he was neutralized.

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
Ham, cheese and egg sandwich
 
The toast is fried on the outside and soft on the inside, with ham and cheese
 
It's delicious, try it if you like it~
Ingredients:
 
2 slices of toast
 
4 eggs
 
3 slices of cheese
 
Some tomato sauce
 
Some black pepper and salt
Method:
 
1. Beat the eggs and mix well with salt and black pepper
 
2. Put butter in the pan, turn on low heat, pour half of the egg liquid and put the toast
 
3. Wait for the egg liquid to solidify, turn it over and fold it four times
 
4. Put a slice of cheese and ham on it, and then put half of the cheese slice on it
 
Squeeze tomato sauce on it, fold the toast in half 
Continue Reading
Ham, cheese and egg sandwich
 
The toast is fried on the outside and soft on the inside, with ham and cheese
 
It's delicious, try it if you like it~
Ingredients:
 
2 slices of toast
 
4 eggs
 
3 slices of cheese
 
Some tomato sauce
 
Some black pepper and salt
Method:
 
1. Beat the eggs and mix well with salt and black pepper
 
2. Put butter in the pan, turn on low heat, pour half of the egg liquid and put the toast
 
3. Wait for the egg liquid to solidify, turn it over and fold it four times
 
4. Put a slice of cheese and ham on it, and then put half of the cheese slice on it
 
Squeeze tomato sauce on it, fold the toast in half and sprinkle some chopped parsley

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
Quite contrary to most of the answers here, I would say 
NO, 
you 
Shouldn’t and you Needn’t 
do mixed workouts everyday.
 
Most Full body workouts( mixed workouts) are very taxing( tiring) for your body and you need atleast 
48 hours to recover. 
So prefer doing only 3 mixed workouts a week.
 
Working out full body everyday could lead to Muscle soreness, Little muscle growth, Lack of rest etc. So prefer 3 times a week.
 
Goodluck!

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article: Basically, laborers work out all day long. Depending on the kind of labor, just like the kind of workout, they will have varying amounts of strength and muscular endurance. Eventually, you would adapt. You would be tired at the end of the day and would accumulate fatigue over the week if you worked out every day, but you would eventually recover more quickly, maybe in a day or two. You would become strong and be able to work harder longer, but you would not likely develop your potential peak strength or hypertrophy.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
In a nutshell: work out early, make it short, and eat for energy!
 
Here’s how:
 
Create a morning routine so you can work out early.
 
A morning routine is a simple life hack that makes you feel super productive at the start of the day, gives you focus, and provides you with a sense of achievement early, so that you already feel you've made progress. A 
morning routine
 gives you time to do what you consider important to your personal development, and gets you closer to achieving your goals.
 
Make it short.
 
What’s the best way to build a habit from scratch? Make it easy to do on a regular basis. The benefi
Continue Reading
In a nutshell: work out early, make it short, and eat for energy!
 
Here’s how:
 
Create a morning routine so you can work out early.
 
A morning routine is a simple life hack that makes you feel super productive at the start of the day, gives you focus, and provides you with a sense of achievement early, so that you already feel you've made progress. A 
morning routine
 gives you time to do what you consider important to your personal development, and gets you closer to achieving your goals.
 
Make it short.
 
What’s the best way to build a habit from scratch? Make it easy to do on a regular basis. The benefits? Instead of making it intimidating, you make a workout routine doable. Instead of aiming too high and telling yourself you must spend two hours at the gym, you opt for taking baby steps and aim for 15-30 minutes. To get started, just pick a shorter activity that requires your body to move, such as:
a 
morning yoga routine
a 
15 minute bootcamp session
a set of hindu pushups
a set of 
sun salutation poses
a set of lunges and squats
a 20-minute power walk
a quick run through the neighborhood
Eat for energy.
 
Always start your day with breakfast. It's your fuel for starting the day and it helps you to feel alert, energized, and motivated. Choose something that is balanced, light, yet filling, such as a combination of protein, healthy fats, fresh fruit. For example:
Overnight oats 
(no cooking needed): mix a few spoonfuls of oats, 1 teaspoon each of chia seeds and flax seeds, some walnuts, almonds, raisins; add a bit of almond milk or water to blend; leave in fridge overnight and top it off in the morning with some fresh fruit.
Parfait
: 
layer Greek yogurt with granola, nuts (walnuts, almonds, cashews) and diced or sliced fresh fruit (papaya, banana, strawberries, oranges, grapefruit, apples, pears, mango).
Oatmeal 
with chia seeds, flax seeds, walnuts, almonds, dates, shredded coconut, raisins or cranberries; blend with a spoon of peanut butter and add fresh fruit on top.
Get more tips on starting positive habits early.
 
There’s a podcast that will seriously get you to rethink the way you look at mornings. It's called 
Achieve Your Goals
 and it's hosted by Hal Elrod, the author of a book called 
The Miracle Morning.
 It is an in depth guide to structuring your mornings so that you can achieve more in less time, and you have time to work consistently on getting closer to your personal goals.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?

Continue Reading
I've never been to America but I have met a few ignorant americans overseas. In fact, this group of people happens to be the most ignorant people I have ever encountered.
 
I am a Singaporean and was in Germany for a little study exchange where I happened to meet a bunch of Americans (about 20ish years old) and I complied the many ignorant questions they have asked.
 
(1) Who is Angela Merkel?
 
I was genuinely shocked when he asked that question since we are supposed to be stationed in Germany for a few months and she is one of the most influential and longest standing politician in the world.
 
(2) Is that the West Side Gallery? Oh it's the wall I see on instagram.
 
He meant the East Side Gallery which is a huge landmark in Berlin and honestly, anyone who has remotely read about the WW2 (which i assume was thought in school, would have known about the Berlin wall and the many historical backstories it comes with)
 
(After i've said i'm from Singapore)
 
(3) Wait so is that part of China?
 
No. In fact, Singapore is 6 hours away from Beijing, which is not exactly near. But I wouldn't fault him for this. Singapore has many Chinese and is tiny so it's easy to misunderstand.
 
(4) So you are Chinese?
 
Yes I am ethically Chinese. I look 100% Chinese so I don't really understand the point of this question. It is like asking a very obvious white, Are you white?
 
at this point i realise their mind is a bit blown, how can a chinese that speaks chinese not be from China?
 
(5) How could you speak English so well?
 
English is the first and official language of all Singaporeans. English was the first language I was taught, english is the language i work and study in. And this seems to confused them.
 
(6) What English is your first language? That can't be it, what “asian language” do you speak?
 
at this point i'm already a bit pissed. What do you meant by “asian language”? I already told you i speak english (in fact we converse in english) and that they heard me speak a bit of chinese. They could have just asked “so do you speak any other languages?” in which i would have politely replied no, i only speak english and chinese, instead of asking me what other “asian” language do i speak? lol and he had that condenscening tone which makes it worst.
 
To be fair, Singapore is a fairly small country and I wouldn't expect everybody to know much about our country but even my French roommate chip in and agreed that she too had met many ignorant americans. In fact, she said an american she knew thought that Paris and France were two different countries!
 
p.s. not throwing shade, probably sure there are ignorant people all around the world in different countries just sharing my experiences.

article:

As of this moment in time, I prefer running first and yoga second. I hated running in middle and high school (anything before, I probably enjoyed, but don't remember much), mostly because it was forced upon me by the school administration in the form of pacers and the infamous 1 mile runs. 
 
Once college hit and I began to realize that my health is actually on my shoulders, I ventured into the world of yoga, mainly because it doesn't involve any kind of traditional cardio (i.e. running). I never tried bikram, but hard-core classes like power yoga or advanced vinyasa flow made you sweat and toned and super freakishly flexible. I began jogging when I realized that my heart rate wasn't going as fast as when I first started, and weirdly enough it didn't feel like a work-out without breathing hard. 
 
The first time I ran more than 2 miles was mind-boggling. And then I ran a 5k (on my own, not in a race and rather slowly), I literally thought I was dreaming and pinched myself. Compared to other avid runners, I'm quite slow, I average probably 10min/mile to 12min/mile depending on the day, but each time I hit another distance (like 5 miles, etc) or time goals (like 5k in 30min, etc), it hooked me. Of course I have days where I absolutely loath putting my running shoes, so I substitute yoga. 
 
One thing that I have noticed with running more often for longer times and distances is that you can get extremely tight quadriceps, hamstrings, glutes, gastrocnemius, essentially all your leg muscles and your abs. So I'm not as stretchy and yoga is actually a bit more painful (I appreciate wooden people's yoga feats more now), which in turn led me to more running. So lots of stretching and sprinkling of yoga along with some healthy goals and good running shoes resulted in this weird love for running. :)

(This story is not embellished by even one word)
 
It was the middle of summer and I had just finished a large cabling job in the ceiling of an industrial building. I was parched so I pulled into a McDonalds drive thru and the following conversation occurred:
 
Worker:
 
Hello. welcome to McDonalds may I take your order?
 
Me:
 
Yes. I would like a large Coke.
 
Worker:
 
Would you like anything to drink with that?
 
Me:
 
Ma’am, I ordered a drink…..a large Coke.
 
Worker:
 
I know you did sir, would you like anything to drink with that?
 
Me:
 
Ma’am, would you please read my order back to me?
 
Worker:
 
Sure, you ordered a large Coke. …… Would you like anything to drink with that?
 
Me:
 
Ok, now you are just irritating me….I won’t answer such a question.
 
Worker:
 
Sir, for the last time….would you like anything to drink with your Coke?
 
Me:
 
Ma’am…..I am at a loss here. Is there a manager I can speak with?
 
The speaker went silent and in about 15 seconds the worker came storming out of the McDonalds and threw her apron in the air. She jumped in her car and sped off. I guess I was the straw that broke the camel’s back.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I met a woman in the food court of my neighbourhood mall. We started chatting while eating our lunch. She mentioned she was from Florida, USA, and was visiting Canada to see an old friend. I was taken aback when she asked, “Aren’t you afraid in Canada?”
 
“Why would we be scared?”I asked.
 
“I’m scared here myself, no one carries a gun,” she added.
 
“That’s exactly why we aren’t scared,” I almost laughed out loud.

article:
I usually train 3 days a week, usually for about 2 hours. I occasionally take a 4th day, especially if I’ve been coaching a lot and so missed some of my own work.

I usually train 3 days a week, usually for about 2 hours. I occasionally take a 4th day, especially if I’ve been coaching a lot and so missed some of my own work.
 
Of course, I also walk a bit every day and take a longer walk or bike ride most weeks but I don’t really count that as training.

I have a friend, Candy. She’s a pretty okay person.
 
But the thing is, Candy is a little… slow. I think her mother was on something when she was pregnant with Candy.
 
She’s usually pretty nice, but sometimes she can have pretty bad judgement. And sometimes say pretty… weird… things.
 
For example, one time we were talking and she brought up her boyfriend. I was surprised to find out she had a boyfriend because
 
a) She didn’t have the most interesting personality
 
b) She wasn’t super intelligent
 
c) She wasn’t astonishingly pretty, I think whatever her mom was taking also affected her development looks-wise
 
d) We were in eighth grade, and most people weren’t dating yet.
 
But I acted interested to be polite, and we started chatting about him. Apparently, he is fifteen (she was thirteen at the time), but that was okay because he was still in eighth grade as he was held back. He also lived in Ohio, while we lived in Connecticut but she went on vacation every holiday to see him.
 
Twice.
 
He had also cheated on her a few times, and seemed to me like a bit of a jerk, but I decided that it wasn’t my place to tell her who she should and shouldn’t date.
 
She then asked me if I had a boyfriend, and I went on my usual “eww boys suck” immature 7 year old girl spiel. In reality, I hadn’t really met anyone I hit off with that much, but I was just joking.
 
Candy laughed, 
then literally said, “
Oh yeah, I totally know what you mean! In fact, 
I was lesbian for a year
 
one time
.”
^My reaction but not really because we were in art class and I wasn’t actually drinking tea^
 
But, 
really
??
 
I was lesbian 
for a year
?
 
Like, what?
 
That’s not really something that changes, no?

Weight is only one metric you should be following.
 
Your weight can remain constant, but your body composition can change. Look at this example:
In all 3 pictures this lady is the same weight. But her composition is very different.
 
Here is a picture that illustrates why:
Get rid of enough fat, and gain enough muscle and you can change shape dramatically without the equally dramatic change displayed on the scales.
 
Take measurements of key areas fortnightly; Arms, thighs, chest and waist. Take pictures at the same time from the front and side, back too if you can. Use the pictures and measurements to gauge your progress.
 
Here’s my first 8 weeks, at times my weight was static and it could have demoralised me without seeing it myself:
Finally, eating ‘healthy’ isn’t a guarantee. It’s possible to still be in calorie surplus on a healthy diet. Also, are you really sure what you are eating is really “healthy”?
 
Too often people believe they are eating healthily stating they eat salad daily so that should be enough. But:
Do they use dressing? How much? Which one?
Do they have Mayonnaise?
Are they adding cheese to the salad?
How much Carrot did they eat?
Do they have several tomatoes too?
Are they adding eggs including yokes? How many?
Do they add “bacon bits” or “crunchy onion”?
Even a salad can quickly end up with too much sodium, fat or sugar.
 
At the very least if you still aren’t seeing progress, keep an honest food diary for a few days. Don’t alter your eating because you are now writing it down, be honest. After a few days calculate your calories and macros.
 
Plain and simple, if you are in a calorie deficit, you will lose weight. There is no other possible outcome.
 
Here’s an example of how quick changes can happen when your diet is carefully controlled:
 
Stuart Cross's answer to What are some example meal plans for a male full body transformation when combined with exercise?

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The first time I visited the United States was as a teenager, with a band of friends on a vacation trip. It was in 2002.
One of my friends is named Manuel Garcia Lopez. He doesn’t speak a single word of spanish. His family name comes from his great-grandfather, and his first name is quite common in France. He has a French passport, and he is one of the palest guys I’ve ever seen in my life.
 
Upon landing at JFK airport, we have to fill a sheet of paper to declare our names, ages, reason for travel and all that stuff. Upon those fields, one stands out that leaves us all a bit confused : “Ethnicit
Continue Reading
The first time I visited the United States was as a teenager, with a band of friends on a vacation trip. It was in 2002.
One of my friends is named Manuel Garcia Lopez. He doesn’t speak a single word of spanish. His family name comes from his great-grandfather, and his first name is quite common in France. He has a French passport, and he is one of the palest guys I’ve ever seen in my life.
 
Upon landing at JFK airport, we have to fill a sheet of paper to declare our names, ages, reason for travel and all that stuff. Upon those fields, one stands out that leaves us all a bit confused : “Ethnicity”. Confused because in France, authorities cannot ask about your ethnicity or your religion. It is actually completely forbidden since 1872 (thanks Wikipedia).
 
Anyway, after a bit of explaining, we begrudgingly tick down “caucasian” (which, again, makes absolutely no sense, but let’s not argue further) and give back our sheets.
 
Almost half an hour passes and our group is still not allowed to get past the barrier. Okay, this is just after 9/11 so we get that they must be extra careful, but come on, we don’t even have a guy of Algerian or Morrocan descent in our group, so what’s going on?
 
A female black police officer finally shows up. She asks with an assertive tone :
“
Who is Manuel Garcia Lopez?
”
My friend raises his hand timidly, not really sure what’s going on.
“
Why did you make a false declaration?
”
We all look at him in shock. He just stands there, mouth open, unable to speak. He’s the nicest guy I can think of and always very honest, why would he make such a thing?
 
The woman continues, and by the look on her face you can tell she’s not joking at all :
“
You declared your ethnicity was caucasian. If your name is Manuel Garcia Lopez, you have to declare that you are hispanic.
”
 
And there you have it. The most ignorant and insulting person I met in the US was also the very first one. And a police officer, to top it all.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: In the UK, The Sun newspaper has a reading age of eight years and is better known for its history of Page 3 barely dressed models than serious journalism. It’s aimed at the non-college educated. Closer to National Enquirer than Wall Street Journal. Was out one evening with the owner of an LA defence contractor and one of his British managers. We tried our best but he was unable to accept that Brits do not regard articles in The Sun as the height of informed political opinion.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article: The biggest fitness myth is that you can “get abs" by doing abs exercises. The main reason people cannot see their abs muscles is because their body fat percentage is too high. As a guy, you will start to see your abs at a certain body fat percentage, ball park figure of 12%. At that point, you could do an exercises to make certain muscles more prominent but for most people ab exercises will do absolutely nothing without weight loss.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article: Yes. There are 1.2B people in the world who live on less than $1.50 per day. Given the number of people openly begging for money on Quora, it would seem a lot higher. Most truly poor people do not have computers or internet access, so they would of course not be on Quora. The “working poor” with jobs and some money do appear to be on Quora. The number of people from India and countries in Africa would support the idea that at least some of those in that 1.2B of really poor people have some access to public computers and internet.

Earlier I was very lean. My weight was around 45 kg and I tried everything but it remained same. So I decided to change my routine and started hitting the gym and now I can see the changes in my body.
 
My daily routine is this :
I wake up at 5 am, drink 2 glasses of water. Water fires up your metabolism and hydrates you.
Pre workout : 2 bananas ( it will give you around 242 calories)
Go to gym at 5:30 am and workout for 90 minutes.
Post workout : whey protein powder.
At 8, I take my breakfast ( 4 slices of brown bread + 1 spoon peanut butter + 3 eggs’ white + 1 whole egg + 1 glass milk )
At 9:30, I leave for college.
Around 10:30, I take my snack (fruit salad)
Around 1 pm, I take lunch (4 chapati+any green vegetable+pulse+salad)
Around 4 pm, snack time(oats)
Dinner : 4 chapati + any pulse+ chicken+salad
At 11 pm go to sleep
Now I am around 65 kg and following this routine for past 6 months.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The person I am talking about was an American though he was in Australia at the time.
 
I used to work in the drawing office of a large steel mill which was doing some major upgrades, and the contractors were from an American company. My main job was taking care of the tens of thousands of drawings and making prints of them when necessary. There were some serious problems with the new installations and so the American CEO turned up to try to get it all sorted out.
 
One morning my boss came into my office with the CEO and asked me to print some of the drawings, which I did. When I came back, the CEO
Continue Reading
The person I am talking about was an American though he was in Australia at the time.
 
I used to work in the drawing office of a large steel mill which was doing some major upgrades, and the contractors were from an American company. My main job was taking care of the tens of thousands of drawings and making prints of them when necessary. There were some serious problems with the new installations and so the American CEO turned up to try to get it all sorted out.
 
One morning my boss came into my office with the CEO and asked me to print some of the drawings, which I did. When I came back, the CEO was parked in MY chair at MY desk. I stood there waiting for them to leave so I could continue with my work. There was literally nothing I could do until the CEO moved out of my workspace.
 
The CEO looked at me and then at my boss and said “Why isn’t she working? Isn’t there something she should be doing?” (So far this guy had not said a word to me, not even a distant “Good morning”). My boss said there wasn’t actually anything I could do just at that moment. CEO gives me another dirty look and says, “Get rid of her then!”
 
Now for all I know this guy might have been able recite the whole declaration of independence, name every state and state capital, and known the whole of the constitution by heart. But one thing he was definitely ignorant about was plain good manners.

She picks up a can of the Sumatran coffee and looks at it. She appeared to be looking for something in particular on the label.
 
“Can I help you?” I asked. I also work at a super market and sometimes can’t help but interject and offer customer service, even when I’m not working.
 
“Is this Colombian coffee?” she asked.
 
“No, this is Sumatran coffee,” I answered.
 
“Oh. What does th
Continue Reading
Jumping off of Arundhati Srinath’s answer, I was in a super market near a coffee sample station, enjoying a blend from Sumatra with a few other patrons and the employee supervising the station, when this woman walks up to us. She picks up a can of the Sumatran coffee and looks at it. She appeared to be looking for something in particular on the label.
 
“Can I help you?” I asked. I also work at a super market and sometimes can’t help but interject and offer customer service, even when I’m not working.
 
“Is this Colombian coffee?” she asked.
 
“No, this is Sumatran coffee,” I answered.
 
“Oh. What does that mean?”
 
“It means the coffee comes from Sumatra.”
 
“What’s that?”
 
“An island in Indonesia.”
 
“Oh. So, it’s definitely not Colombian?”
 
“No, it isn’t. Are you looking for Colombian coffee specifically?”
 
“Yes, my husband asked me to buy Colombian coffee.”
 
I asked her to follow me, and I took her to the coffee section and pointed out the Colombian coffee. She thanked me and picked up the can to read it. I showed her where it said “Colombian”. She thanked me again, but then paused as she noticed another type of coffee on the shelf. She picked up a Costa Rican coffee.
 
“What about this? Is this Colombian?” she asked.
 
“No, but it’s close. This is Costa Rican,” I answered.
 
“What does ‘Colombian’ even mean?” she asked.
 
“It means the coffee comes from Colombia,” I said. “That’s a country in South America.”
 
“Oh, I didn’t know that.”
 
It went back and forth like this for a while. She truly had no idea that Colombia and Indonesia and Costa Rica were countries, or where they were in the world. This woman had to be in her late forties, early fifties. I helped her as much as I could, but she didn’t end up leaving with the Colombian coffee; she bought the Costa Rican coffee because there was a “pretty, colorful bird” on the label and she’d rather have that sitting on the counter for the next two weeks rather than the Colombian can with no pretty picture on it.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
“Who was the most ignorant person you have ever met in America?”
 
When I was an undergrad, I worked as a tutor for Mass Rehab 
Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commission
 
One of my students was a man in his late 20s, confined to a wheelchair. His fund of common knowledge was astoundingly impoverished.
 
He didn’t know what ocean we Bostonians live on, or the states that border Massachusetts. He didn’t know that there were other countries to the north or south of the United States. He could not distinguish between cities, states, and nations. He could not tell time or use the calendar. He didn’t know what
Continue Reading
“Who was the most ignorant person you have ever met in America?”
 
When I was an undergrad, I worked as a tutor for Mass Rehab 
Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commission
 
One of my students was a man in his late 20s, confined to a wheelchair. His fund of common knowledge was astoundingly impoverished.
 
He didn’t know what ocean we Bostonians live on, or the states that border Massachusetts. He didn’t know that there were other countries to the north or south of the United States. He could not distinguish between cities, states, and nations. He could not tell time or use the calendar. He didn’t know what a sign saying “10% off” meant. He did not know the relationship between the earth and the sun or the moon. He didn’t know what causes day or night. He didn’t know that rain comes from clouds. (He thought that killing a spider caused rain.) He didn’t know what the moon was. He couldn’t name the president or the mayor. (He did know that the Boston police were different from the Cambridge police, but he didn’t know why.) He could not add or subtract fluently. He could not multiply at all. He did not know that the world was a globe.
 
He had been a gangbanger as a young teen, so he effectively stopped paying attention in school around the age of 12. He stopped attending school around the age of 14. He was paralyzed by a bullet in a gang-related shooting at the age of 19. Whatever he had learned in school had evaporated during the 16 years since he stopped paying attention.

Thanks for the ATA.
 
Short answer is YES.
 
Long answer is still YES but I would go further and say you wouldn’t need to do the full body in each session.
 
Especially if you are lifting heavy and with intensity each session you might find it tough, instead I would recommend a 3 day split using 2 alternating workouts.
 
You can make great strength and muscle gains with this type of split, espeically if you nutrition is dialled in.
 
For example:
 
Workout A - Chest, shoulders, triceps & abs
 
Workout B - Legs, back, biceps & calves
 
You would rotate the workouts each week performing one once and one twice i.e…
 
Week 1
 
Mon - Workout A
 
Tues - Rest
 
Wed - Workout B
 
Thur - Rest
 
Fri - Workout A
 
Sat - Rest
 
Sun - Rest
 
Week 2
 
Mon - Workout B
 
Tues - Rest
 
Wed - Workout A
 
Thur - Rest
 
Fri - Workout B
 
Sat - Rest
 
Sun - Rest
 
Notes:
Focus primarily on compound movements with a few isolation thrown in to round out your physique.
Aim to work using 75 - 85% of your 1RM and lifting the 4 - 8 rep range for compound and 8 - 12 for isolation.
Apply progressive overload and stay consistent
Cardio is optional and is best done as high intensity sessions of 20mins
I hope this helps.
 
Good luck on your fitness journey.

Crossing the parking lot of the Madonna Inn in California, I passed a lady in her 30s, staring at a German sports car. She was circling it with a look of puzzlement and borderline bewilderment. As I passed her she said “Excuse me sir? Could you tell me what kind of car this is?”. I knew exactly what make and model of car it was. It was an Audi TT and I told her. She seemed somewhat annoyed that I knew this for some reason and she fired back quite quickly with “How do you know that?”.
 
“Because it says so right here on the rear” I replied, pointing to the clearly visible “Audi TT” emblazoned on the car. Maybe she overlooked it due to a neurological condition or perhaps she was illiterate.
 
She then asked “Are you Australian?”.
 
No harm in that except I've a rather strong Irish accent. “No, I'm irish” I answered.
 
“Is that near Sweden?”.

He sti

Whilst driving a taxi in the UK I had an awful American chap who was insistent on paying for his taxi in American dollars and would not believe that dollars were not legal tender.
 
His taxi cost £10, short trip, without tip, so I explained with much patience that to accept the dollars I would have to charge him the additional costs involved to take them to the bank the next day; an hour of my time, parking up, and the fuel involved. The £10 taxi then became $50. He still refused to pay so had to be convinced with the threat of dumping him back at his starting point or involving the police.
 
He still couldn’t understand why I wouldn’t accept dollars in the UK.
 
To redress Karma some years later the day after Trump was elected I picked up an American couple who immediately apologised for being American. They explained they were embarrassed democrats ashamed by the actions of Mr Trump: I halved their taxi fare and wished them well.
 
I have chatted to some lovely North Americans but in my experience they usually turn out to be Canadians.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
It depends on what you’re doing, and what you’re looking for. If you want to get big, don’t do full body workouts. Split your workout into muscle groups or types of movement. Like, you could do a push/pull split, meaning that one day you do excercises that you push away from you to perform, and the next day you do exercises that you pull towards you to perform. Examples of pushing exercises could be bench press, shoulder/military press, or tricep push downs. Then for pulling you could do pull downs, rows, bicep curls and whatnot. You’d want to have a day where you trained legs, too. Or if you 
Continue Reading
It depends on what you’re doing, and what you’re looking for. If you want to get big, don’t do full body workouts. Split your workout into muscle groups or types of movement. Like, you could do a push/pull split, meaning that one day you do excercises that you push away from you to perform, and the next day you do exercises that you pull towards you to perform. Examples of pushing exercises could be bench press, shoulder/military press, or tricep push downs. Then for pulling you could do pull downs, rows, bicep curls and whatnot. You’d want to have a day where you trained legs, too. Or if you split it into muscle groups, which is what I do, you would do chest one day, another day do back, another day do shoulders, another day do arms. If you’re dead set on doing full body workouts, keep it to three days a week so your body can recover properly.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
For what outcome?
To get bigger muscles?
To get fat off?
To train for endurance running?
To improve sport performance?
To become more flexible?
I could go on. Here are some general tips
Eating before / after is not as essential as people on here believe. That’s because they are not looking at the science of the bidy
Right now as you read Quora the average person has 2,000 ‘‘calories” of stored sugar energy and 40,000 calories of stored fat energy.
 
So with that in mind you’re not really ever short of energy to work out. In fact training in a “fasted state” (that means with no food eaten for at least 12 
Continue Reading
For what outcome?
To get bigger muscles?
To get fat off?
To train for endurance running?
To improve sport performance?
To become more flexible?
I could go on. Here are some general tips
Eating before / after is not as essential as people on here believe. That’s because they are not looking at the science of the bidy
Right now as you read Quora the average person has 2,000 ‘‘calories” of stored sugar energy and 40,000 calories of stored fat energy.
 
So with that in mind you’re not really ever short of energy to work out. In fact training in a “fasted state” (that means with no food eaten for at least 12 hours or more) is probably the 
most beneficial for weight loss.
 
The body has finite storage capacity and will 
never use fat while you still have stored glucose energy (glycogen for those that love the science)
 
It just would not do that.
 
If you are trying to 
build muscle while staying lean 
then you need to keep a close eye on protein. 
High protein is pointless 
(unless your are selling protein shakes and bars!) The body can not store excess protein. Again it’s the body having finite storage capacity. Anything over roughly 2 chicken legs worth of protein per meal is simply going be turned to glucose or even worse; fat. 
So moderate protein intake is required. THERE IS NO BEST TIME TO EAT ONLY BEST TIME TO NOT EAT! 
Leaving at least an hour before and after is best.
 
Sidebar: everyone has heard of human growth hormone, it’s the bodys ‘repair and rebuild’ hormone. When you wake up HGH is high, and lowers when you start eating. If you buzz to the gym and take some water with a pinch of pink Himalayan salt with you then you can workout with the elevated human growth hormone still circulating. The salted water is the best for rehydration.
 
Hydration is often thought of as loss of water, it’s actually loss of electrolytes that’s the issue. Hence the pink salt.
 
Lastly some think water increases metabolic rate. It does, temporarily. But this is only because the body works to bring the temperature of the cold water up to body temperature. If you really want to be geeky about training 
never drink cold water unless it is to bring your temperature down. It’s a 3% lose of workout energy while it raise the water temperature up.
 
It’s really minimal though.
 
But to answer your question in a more basic way
 
The best time to go is when suits you best. All that above might scientifically help but if you FEEL better at night then you’ll probably get more out of it then dragging yourself there reluctantly in the morning.
 
If you don’t mind either then you need to focus on what your goal is. I’m qualified in nutrition for sports performance and exercise. If you have an actual goal just drop me a comment and I’ll answer specifics
 
Step Away From The Carbs: The science behind weight loss, the recipes to make it happen. Beautiful colour photographs of every breakfast, lunch, dinner, snack and even drinks.

When I started on Quora, my salary was the equivalent of about one thousand american dollars, not great but I was able to buy things, maintain my house and cars and doing some travel. I have thought of leaving my country for safety issues but my main concern is my age, 52, a little old to start again in another country. I use Quora mostly to practice my English and to learn interesting things, specially a way to win dollars because any amount is like gold here.

Though from my childhood never had any facilities which people consider as basic things in life, I never felt I’m Poor. Because my father never gave us what we asked but what was needed.
 
Despite his devastated health, condition still he is striving to feed us. Last year I got the job and recently resigned to it, just to be with him closely. He is highly self-respected person. He is not allowing me to take the responsibilities. So I joined as a School teacher in my locale. And preparing for GATE exam which was postponed as my father advised me to go for job, at that time he didn’t told me the reason.After resigning job I came to knew that last year he is almost on death bed, they hided this from me. To support my brothers education he told me to join the job just in case anything happens to him.
 
My father’s only entertainment, watching cricket; for which he has to go to relatives/ friends home.
 
My mother likes to watch movies and old songs; but adjusted with radio, gifted by neighbours (may be gifted is better word.)
 
Brother and me has to do the same.
 
It takes almost two yrs just to buy a small T.V. which is a common thing in most of the people.
 
I mentioned only one thing here. But many are there but they never gave me thought of I AM POOR, but recently when I struggled to find a place to give the freedom to my tears.
 
I don’t know whether my answer make any sense, so many things running in my mind. Almost spent 2 hrs but not able to put in words.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
I guess it would really depend on what kind of results you were wanting to see. Results can be massive or miniscule. You'll see which one based on the effort you put into training for those results. There is no magic formula. Many programs out there each will suffice for results. Consistency is key!!!
 
Progression also. Yet secondary.
 
A waitress carries a beer tray for twenty years… check out those results. The load hasn't changed but her arm did. From consistency. But that's the thing. She could have built a bigger bicep in half the time by doubling the amount of beer mugs she carried over time.
Continue Reading
I guess it would really depend on what kind of results you were wanting to see. Results can be massive or miniscule. You'll see which one based on the effort you put into training for those results. There is no magic formula. Many programs out there each will suffice for results. Consistency is key!!!
 
Progression also. Yet secondary.
 
A waitress carries a beer tray for twenty years… check out those results. The load hasn't changed but her arm did. From consistency. But that's the thing. She could have built a bigger bicep in half the time by doubling the amount of beer mugs she carried over time. That's progression.
 
Find a program that you can stick to FIRST! 3 DAY 5 DAY ONE DAY… THEN ADD THE LOAD! GO SLOW! Choose only one exercise. A compound one. start ridiculously light. Learn proper form. Add 2 percent every week.. Then along the way, add another compound movement. Same thing. Really light. Learn the movement. Teach your body how-to coordinate all the necessary bones muscles and nerves till your an expert! Slowly add more weight. Add another exercise. Continue until all major body groups are now being utilized. Now? Stop! Take a week off. You deserved it.
 
Boredom will set in. Change up the exercises. Switch from free weightvto machines, machines to dumbells, and back to barbells… keep going… slowly add more volume. More sets. If you become lethargic and tired. Take a week off.
 
And in 5 years, you will see results! Real results. People you haven't seen in a while will drop their jaws in awe results! Ex girlfriends calling you back results…. But most importantly, YOUR RESULTS! YOU DIDNT BUY THOSE, THEY WERNT GIVEN TO YOU. YOU EARNED EVERY INCH.
 
Are you happy with it?
 
Yes? It only takes a third of what you were doing in volume to maintain what you have. Maintain it! Don't lose it!
 
No? Back at it! Another 5 years. Keep it fresh. Change it up. Fucj the numbers. Numbers are for egos.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Is this ignorance? Or… I don’t even know.
 
I got a call, a telephone poll. The operator had a soft but unmistakeable accent. I’d guess Galveston. After the questions about (if I recall correctly) how pleased I was with my recycling service, she read from her script, “Now I have some demographic questions about you and your household, if you don’t mind. What is your profession?”
 
“I’m a computer programmer.”
 
“And what is the ethnic background of your family?”
 
“We’re Asian.”
 
She gives that chuckle you make when you figure something out. “That explains it.” Her accent was much stronger when she was spea

Is this ignorance? Or… I don’t even know.
 
I got a call, a telephone poll. The operator had a soft but unmistakeable accent. I’d guess Galveston. After the questions about (if I recall correctly) how pleased I was with my recycling service, she read from her script, “Now I have some demographic questions about you and your household, if you don’t mind. What is your profession?”
 
“I’m a computer programmer.”
 
“And what is the ethnic background of your family?”
 
“We’re Asian.”
 
She gives that chuckle you make when you figure something out. “That explains it.” Her accent was much stronger when she was speaking for herself and not reading from the script.
 
“Explains what?”
 
She answered, in the sweetest, most guileless tone, “Computers are so difficult and you Asians are always so smart.”
 
Simultaneously, the nicest and the most racist thing anyone has ever said to me.

My mother was a reporter for our local newspaper. She had the crime beat.
 
One Tuesday morning, something insane had happened back east which impacted not just the whole country but the entire world. There really wasn't a whole lot going on in our town; our already low crime rate was pretty much non-existent that morning. The police scanner was quiet, no brush fires were burning, and for once she found herself with little and less to do.
 
She decided to go to the grocery store, figuring she'd do a little shopping and ask folks about their thoughts and reactions and fears while she was at it.
 
Everyone seemed to have variations of the same feelings: shock, fear, anger. She went out to her car.
 
There was a man in the parking lot, loading his truck with two shopping carts worth of bottled water. Enough to last one person for the better part of a year, she told me.
 
Bullseye, right? Here's a guy getting ready to go all the way off the grid. Had he been expecting something like this to happen sooner or later? Was he perhaps retired from government or intelligence, potentially still unofficially privy to off-the-record information which had yet to be made public?
 
She asked him why all the water.
 
His response?
 
They've got a great deal on water right now; I couldn't pass it up! No limit; I might come back for more later!
 
It was the afternoon of September 11, 2001, and my mother had to explain to this man that our country was under attack. She had found what may have been the last person in the nation to learn that the Twin Towers had been reduced to the world's biggest funeral pyre that morning.

Both “poor” and “c ds.
 
But I live below the poverty line on Social Security.
 
Were I to move all this to Nepal, I would be in the upper class!
 
I do know many people worse off than myself. But when my father died in 2014 my mother offered by US$30,000 to buy a new car.
 
I bought an old one instead, and sold (eventually gave) the old one to young friends staring a family, To date I have managed to spend only about $12,000.
 
I make a bit over $800 a month.
 
Before I lost the ability to sleep last year, I used to do one or two expert witness cases (for the defense) a year. Until last year I had been charging the State less than 20% of the going rate. This year I had to turn down two jobs (no sleep, no expert.)
 
Since I am relatively rich compared to many friends, I have lent money to them off and on for years. I charge Credit Union rates +1% and unlike most lenders I am not concerned about regular payments. At the bottom of the economy, even a small unanticipated expense can cost you several times the expense in fines and penalties as you can’t pay other bills. All I ask is that people stay in touch and let me know about any issues. Their only alternative is often the usurious payday and auto title loan places which charge around 22% interest every two weeks. I cannot abide good people being raped like that. So I did something, and mostly it works. Payments can be erratic, I have one loan on hold because the family has an adult daughter fighting an autoimmune disease, incorrectly diagnosed by her doctor, but correctly diagnosed by her mother, who thankfully is a force to be reckoned with.
 
I spend about 10% of my income on phone and internet, My cell costs about $12 a month. Much of the rest goes to electricity and gas and food.
 
Years ago, when I determined that money is totally valuless once people no longer trust it, and that banks could and were inflating the currency faster than wages were rising, I decided to invest in friendship—which is more useful than waste paper.
 
My emergency food supply consists mostly of chocolate, because it is both stable in storage and as a luxury good should be good for far more food in trade than say, beans.

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
How do you get the best results possible with the least time invested?
 
Full-body workouts.
If you are a beginner do them twice per week, and if you are intermediate or advance then you can do them three times per week.
 
I would also add in that another great option for advanced trainers is a 4-day upper lower split. But that is for people with especially good recovery abilities.
 
It amazes me how much the bodybuilding industry has confused the shit out of people. Telling them to workout 6 times per week, eat 2 grams of protein per pound of bodyweight, and other useless nonsense. Sure that works for 
Continue Reading
How do you get the best results possible with the least time invested?
 
Full-body workouts.
If you are a beginner do them twice per week, and if you are intermediate or advance then you can do them three times per week.
 
I would also add in that another great option for advanced trainers is a 4-day upper lower split. But that is for people with especially good recovery abilities.
 
It amazes me how much the bodybuilding industry has confused the shit out of people. Telling them to workout 6 times per week, eat 2 grams of protein per pound of bodyweight, and other useless nonsense. Sure that works for the guys taking steroids, but all it does for a natural trainer is lead them nowhere. Yeah, you might experience results in a few months, but after that you’ll stagnate.
 
Full-body workouts on the other hand, are the perfect routines for natural trainers. They offer enough volume, but not too much to where you can’t recover from. In addition, you’re joints and central nervous system get more of a break and time to recover because you’re not training as often.
 
All you need in a full-body workout is a major push, a major pull, and a major legs exercise. The intermediate and advance could also benefit from some assistance exercises for the arms and calves. But other than that, this is all you will ever need to grow. I currently am 6′1 and weigh 203 lbs, at 11 percent body fat. And I have been on a maintenance routine only lifting weights twice per week and sprinting on a third day. I haven’t gained any mass (hence the maintenance routine) but I still have continued to gain strength. One of my example workouts was this:
 
Weighted Dips: Work up to max set of 5 reps
 
Weighted Chin-ups: Work up to max set of 5 reps
 
Squats: Work up to max set of 5 reps
 
Calf raises and forearms: 2–3 sets of 10–15 reps
 
Will you get to be 250 at 5 % body fat and become some absolute beast?? Hell no, not even close. But no natural trainer will ever get that close. If you are around 6 feet tall, the most you can ever expect to weight at 10 percent body fat is probably 215 to 220. And those numbers are for someone with very great genetics.
 
I love how people think they need to follow the split routines 6 days per week because everyone else is doing it.
 
Well, how many people do you see that are big and strong? Not many. How many people do you see at the gym following those splits who are actually big and NOT taking steroids? Probably zero.
 
I talk about this in great detail in my book which you can find here: 
Basic But Brutal

This happened few days back when I went to the National Museum of Nature and Science, Tokyo (
National Museum of Nature and Science,Tokyo
).
 
It had been a long tiring day and after touring the museum, I decided to sit outside to rest my legs. Here comes an American women (seemed to be in her 30s) with a Japanese girl (seemed to be her English student) who sat a few steps away from me. I recognized the two as I had earlier “heard” them in the museum (the American women was way too loud).
 
As I was sitting alone and had no one to talk to, I started listening to their conversation (couldn’t help it as such - the lady was way too loud!!!). They were discussing about the moon. The American lady first explained (in great lengths!!) how we see only the same portion of the Moon’s sphere always and never the other side. Her explanation of this phenomenon seemed pretty good and so I got more interested in their conversation.
 
The next question comes from the American - “Who owns the moon?” The Japanese girl meekly replied that she had no idea. This somehow annoyed the American lady to great lengths. She explained (read “Screamed”) saying that “Since we (Americans) were the first to land on the moon and erected our flag there, it’s we (Americans) who own the moon. If anything happens to Earth in future, the Americans will be the first and only people who have the right to move to the moon. Though it’s not written anywhere, everyone knows the truth.”
 
I couldn’t help but laugh out loud. Both of them looks at me - the Japanese girl smiling and the American lady giving me a death stare!! And I got my cue to leave.
 
P.S. If anyone wants to know who owns the moon - 
The Outer Space Treaty

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I am British and live in the UK; my only real experience of America itself has been New England - Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Maine - where I have friends that I visit from time to time. I was delighted to find that most of the people in that region did not conform to the stereotypical view the rest of the world holds about Americans being uneducated and insular. Sadly, however, the same cannot be said of many Americans from other parts of the USA and I saw most examples of this when I worked at a major UK airport. For example: an American (from Texas) I encountered during the course of m
Continue Reading
I am British and live in the UK; my only real experience of America itself has been New England - Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Maine - where I have friends that I visit from time to time. I was delighted to find that most of the people in that region did not conform to the stereotypical view the rest of the world holds about Americans being uneducated and insular. Sadly, however, the same cannot be said of many Americans from other parts of the USA and I saw most examples of this when I worked at a major UK airport. For example: an American (from Texas) I encountered during the course of my work asked me where to find his baggage. I asked where he had arrived from and he replied “Maleyga, Spain”. Ignoring his mispronunciation of Málaga, I asked him if he’d been there on vacation and it emerged that, in fact, he had been working there for some 2½ years. I asked him if, perhaps, he hadn’t noticed that the local people called it “Málaga rather than “Maleyga” - his reply: “Sure, but that’s ‘cos they’re like all Mexicans, too lazy to learn proper English ….” I was unable to resist a face-palm, and I walked off, leaving him to find his own luggage.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I had just moved to the States and was starting the second half of my sophomore year in high school when I had the following conversation:
 
Classmate: “Where are you from?”
 
Me: “I am from Colombia”
 
Classmate: “Oh, is that in Mexico?”
 
Me: “… no… it’s a country in South America… nowhere near Mexico…”
 
Since it was a conversation it would have been fine had she been mixed up with the city of Columbia, but she didn’t even get the country right for that to have been an option.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
While visiting the states I came across the usual group of people who were unsure of where various European countries were. But there are probably a lot of Europeans who couldn't place American states - so ok, no big deal.
 
But my strangest experience went like this:
 
Me: So what sort of relationship do you guys have with Canada?
 
Other: Fine. Why do you ask?
 
Me: Well, it's a different country.
 
Other: No, it's not.
 
Me: (Taken aback). Well it's on the American continent, but it's a different country.
 
Other: No, it's part of the USA.
 
Me: (Not knowing what to say). Ummmm. I don't mean Alaska. I mean Canada.
 
Continue Reading

But my strangest experience went like this:
 
Me: So what sort of relationship do you guys have with Canada?
 
Other: Fine. Why do you ask?
 
Me: Well, it's a different country.
 
Other: No, it's not.
 
Me: (Taken aback). Well it's on the American continent, but it's a different country.
 
Other: No, it's part of the USA.
 
Me: (Not knowing what to say). Ummmm. I don't mean Alaska. I mean Canada.
 
Other: Just a minute, I'll ask my friends.
 
To my utter amazement his friends backed him up!
 
I still don't know if they were seriously confused or they were pulling my leg.
 
I would like to mentione that during all the conversation everyone was polite friendly and agreeable - indeed this was my impression of most Americans I met.
 
In fairness I should also mention that I have had conversations about the UK while living in Spain which are almost as bizarre.

The girl in question is a sweet person, but she was very, very misinformed. Just to be clear, we are both Americans, so this wasn’t something that happened abroad. My mother’s family is Lebanese, and that’s not a secret or anything, and I’m Christian, and don’t hide that either.
 
One day, as we were chatting, she pointed at the little cross I was wearing, and said, “Um, hmm, I’ve been meaning to ask- Why do you wear that?”
 
“Because I want to? I don’t understand what you’re asking.”
 
“Like… Why do you wear a cross if that’s not your religion?”
 
“…I 
am
 Christian. ”
 
“But… I thought you were Arabic?”
 
This conversation went on for a long, long, painfully awkward long time, before I realized…
 
She thought Islam and Arabic were the same word. 
I had to explain how a Muslim person’s religion is Islam, just like how a Christian person’s religion is Christianity, and a Jewish person’s religion is Judaism. Then, I had to explain quite a lot of other stuff. It was like her brain was a dictionary and one section’s definitions had all been shifted down a line.
 
Thankfully, though, she was very polite about it, and didn’t insist on something wrong being right. We’re still good friends today.

There are countless examples. Many have to do with geography, and they’re the easiest to write about, so here I go.
 
My college-educated friend said to me, when I was going to move to Spain, “How cool; you’re going to be so close to Europe.”
 
My ex-brother-in-law was extremely irritated with me because I could not agree with him that South America was a country, containing the “states” of Venezuela, Chile, etc. .
 
Since my husband is a Swedish Finn, I hear a lot about “Switzerland” when I refer to this. My mother was from Australia. Many have talked to me of “Austria.”
 
When I spent several months in Australia, a friend from here (USA) asked me, “But, they have 
stores
 and everything there, right?”
 
I also lived in Guadalajara Spain. So many people used to “correct” me, advising me that Guadalajara is in México (yes, that is so, but it is also a province in Spain).
 
Outside geography, I endure such things as,
 
“Aren’t you scared to move to Sweden? I heard they’re about to implement Sharia law there.”
 
“Sweden is so dangerous with all those refugees!”
 
“Cool; in Sweden you’ll be able to smoke marijuana without problems (Sweden is absurdly strict with respect to marijuana, which in no uncertain terms is seen as a bad drug and is VERY illegal)!”
 
“You will have to pay horrible taxes in Sweden, and the government controls you.”
 
“Spain’s Spanish is better than México’s”
 
“Mexican Spanish is very limited and simple.”
 
“Have fun; Europe has gone communist!”
 
Perhaps the most illustrative of sheer, unmitigated stupidity:
 
“Donald Trump will make America great again!”
 
Oh, they just keep rolling in.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The one who made my jaw drop is an old co-worker who asked nonchalantly, very loudly, to everyone in an open office: “Is there any difference between Vienna and Venice? Is one a country and the other a city?”
 
A long silence before anyone answered.
 
Her ignorance was even more confounding in the context of the many privileges in her childhood. Her father is a doctor at a prestigious teaching medical school. She grew up in one of the most affluent suburbs of America, attending the best public schools possible — you know, it’s one of those places where Chinese is taught in public schools. She went t
Continue Reading
The one who made my jaw drop is an old co-worker who asked nonchalantly, very loudly, to everyone in an open office: “Is there any difference between Vienna and Venice? Is one a country and the other a city?”
 
A long silence before anyone answered.
 
Her ignorance was even more confounding in the context of the many privileges in her childhood. Her father is a doctor at a prestigious teaching medical school. She grew up in one of the most affluent suburbs of America, attending the best public schools possible — you know, it’s one of those places where Chinese is taught in public schools. She went to college without a single debt.
 
And here’s the clincher — she had traveled extensively through Europe after college. She loved to recount how she had traveled for a few months, going from one city to another. It seems that at no point did she look at a map of Europe and consider the possibility of visiting Venice or Vienna, two of the most famous European cities.
 
Lastly, I would like to say how much I hated working with this co-worker and her proud ignorance. I worked in sales that frequently happened over the phone. Often, when I was on the phone with a client, she would eavesdrop (open office and she seemed to have the most amazing hearing — I suppose to make up for her other deficits), and she would shout out what she thought the answer should be. Of course, it never occurred to her that she was only hearing one side of the conversation and, therefore, her shouted answers were always wrong!

🔥𝗦𝗮𝗱𝗵𝗴𝘂𝗿𝘂🔥: When it comes to activity, what we need to understand fundamentally is that our body has the capability to bend forwards and backwards, as well as twist sideways in either direction. This kind of activity must happen in some form.

If classical Hatha Yoga is not yet part of your life, you must ensure that every day, you bend forward, backward, twist both ways, and squat to stretch the spinal column. This level of activity is essential for everyone on a daily basis if we want to keep the entire system in a healthy state, particularly the neurological system, which can otherwise become an issue as we age.

This one might seem trivial, but it stood out at the time.

title: What is the best workout for me?
article:
AEROBIC FITNESS
I work out of the stepper at least 5 times a week with my heart rate over 130 beats per minute. I also take the dog for a walk for 30 minutes every day.
 
STRENGTH
I go to the gym three times a week and do a superset workout for 40 minutes_ three sets of push out, pull back; push up, pull down; situps, hip strengtheners, a set of cleans and three sets of shoulder exercises.
 
FLEXIBILITY
After the strength training session I do a 20 minute flexibility session aimed at keeping my pelvis and the bones above it and below it in reasonable alignment.
 
You can read all about my workout at ht

In general I find Americans polite and respectful. However American national psychology is quite self-centred. This means that many Americans can lack an awareness of other countries and societies and have strange ideas about other places in the world. These Americans are prone to delusions of superiority which are not anchored in reality. It is these Americans who are likely to be very arrogant.
 
That sort of behaviour is also a “big country” phenomena in my observation. I have noticed similar self-orientated perceptions among people in other large countries like Russia and China. In the latter two the lack of awareness is often imposed upon them from above because Russia and China are not open societies, whereas in the USA the incuriousness is self-imposed.

The case was: She was sitting with her bag next to her (on the chair besides her). A lady, around the same age as the American also arrived and did not find any place to sit. she politely asked the American Lady if she could keep her bag on the floor and vacate the chair if she does not have a companion along.
 
The impertinent American vary casually shrugged and told the Indian lady that she did not have a companion but wouldn’t keep her bag on the f

I met an American lady on an Indian Airport, Delhi Airport to be precise. Just like everyone else, she was waiting for her flight of a hill station.
 
The case was: She was sitting with her bag next to her (on the chair besides her). A lady, around the same age as the American also arrived and did not find any place to sit. she politely asked the American Lady if she could keep her bag on the floor and vacate the chair if she does not have a companion along.
 
The impertinent American vary casually shrugged and told the Indian lady that she did not have a companion but wouldn’t keep her bag on the floor because it would get dirty.
 
The exasperated Indian lady, just stood their stunned and confused for a while. After a long period of waiting, the flight got delayed. The conversation was repeated as the Indian request again and the American denied.
 
By the time, the people sitting around seemed to be ready to intervene. Two of them even stood up and offered their own seats. But the Indian lady denied and turned to the American with a simple and perfect response,
 
“If you do not wish to dirty your bag, then you can take the floor and the bag can take your seat. But kindly, vacate the available seat since no one is using it.”
 
Everybody around us staring smiling, including a handful of foreigner sitting behind us.
 
I don’t believe all Americans are like that but people, irrespective of their nationality can be very rude (to put it politely) sometimes.
