Let me tell you the fact in a simple way without using any complex fitness terms.
The true work is done on an elevated heart rate. If your heart rate is not elevated in any physical activity, that actually means you're not working out.
 
Now, coming to your question 
“will it be effective?”
 depends on the number of exercises and no. Of sets you do at a time.
 
Lets suppose you're training back throughout the day. If you're doing one set of deadlift at a time, then sorry my friend, the work required to build muscle is not happening. However, over the period of time you'll notice some changes in your body.
 
In other case, if you do two or more exercises at the same time. Then your heart rate will elevate and then work happens.
 
The conclusion is, you can workout once at a time or throughout the day. Just you've to make sure that your heart rate is elevated. And another, splitting yiur workouts throughout the day is time consuming.
 
There's no wrong in experimenting. Think, Take action, Experiment and share your knowledge to others ❤️
 
Upvote if you get some value from this.

The Muscly Advisor

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
Troy - I try to move every day in some work-out way. I’ve followed this plan for a lot of years. There are apps now that help with that. I’ve been a long-distance runner, now mostly do shorter distances and sprints to protect my knees (!) but I do have the equivalent of a home gym in my house. I haven’t spent a lot of money. It’s 5, 8 and 10 pound weights, a Bosu, an old Spin bike, a boxer’s jumprope, a TRX system and a small trampoline. If you put my name into Quora I suspect you will see the many questions I have answered regarding work-out routines. If you’re just starting out, I’d book an 
Continue Reading
Troy - I try to move every day in some work-out way. I’ve followed this plan for a lot of years. There are apps now that help with that. I’ve been a long-distance runner, now mostly do shorter distances and sprints to protect my knees (!) but I do have the equivalent of a home gym in my house. I haven’t spent a lot of money. It’s 5, 8 and 10 pound weights, a Bosu, an old Spin bike, a boxer’s jumprope, a TRX system and a small trampoline. If you put my name into Quora I suspect you will see the many questions I have answered regarding work-out routines. If you’re just starting out, I’d book an hour with a Personal Trainer. It will be well worth the time and money. Talk about what you'd like to accomplish, what your goals are and ask if you could talk just a bit about nutrition and diet because that contributes greatly to getting to or staying at goal weight. Places I've worked out at include Tracy Anderson’s Studio in LA, Barry’s Bootcamp in LA, Pure Barre in Los Gatos, here in Northern California where I live. I’ve studied ballet so I do some of those basic exercises. I love to dance so I’ve done Zumba. I subscribe for free to XPT life with Gabby Reece and Laird Hamilton. They give weekly inspiration to get and keep you fit. She’s an Olympian and he’s a big wave surfer, so they are at the top of their game always, but I like to learn from the best! I hope I’ve covered some of what you are asking. I still like the basics - do something cardio first, then sit-ups, planks front and side, lunges, burpees, squats, push-ups. I try to conquer the pull-up which remains hard for me. I ended up putting up a bar in my cellar, and sometimes I just hang from it, then I try hoisting myself up and down for as many times as I can which is usually only a few. I gotta keep working on that. Best of luck and thanks for stopping by…

article:
Oh I've met a few, and I've met a lot of pretty intelligent ones, especially here on quora that absolutely blow my mind. But this is a thread for the ignorant ones so….
 
It was around 2009. Young(er) me had just found out about a mod for a video game I really liked that could make me play online. I was really excited to meet and interact (rampage) with other people from all over the world. So I got to it right away.
 
After a while, I had already formed a 'crew' in the game. We had 4 Americans, an Indian and a coincidentally, a fellow Nigerian. We had a lot of fun there, driving around and chatting

Oh I've met a few, and I've met a lot of pretty intelligent ones, especially here on quora that absolutely blow my mind. But this is a thread for the ignorant ones so….
 
It was around 2009. Young(er) me had just found out about a mod for a video game I really liked that could make me play online. I was really excited to meet and interact (rampage) with other people from all over the world. So I got to it right away.
 
After a while, I had already formed a 'crew' in the game. We had 4 Americans, an Indian and a coincidentally, a fellow Nigerian. We had a lot of fun there, driving around and chatting away. Then one day, some other American came in to talk to us. Upon reading my name tag (which also displayed the country the player is from), the first thing he said was,
 
“You're from Nigeria?”
 
“Yes”
 
“That's impossible, Nigeria has no internet”.
 
I was dumbfounded. Apparently, this guy thought I was lying in the middle of the desert in “Africa”, taking a well deserved break from herding the cattle, fighting Lions and what not; saying enchantments that would enable me to use the “white man's web” to connect with these other people to control my character on the magic screen in front of me. Me and my new friends tried to convince him that Nigeria, and pretty much the rest of the world did infact have internet but he still stood his ground. It turned out that this guy was a complete jackass. Soon he deemed it necessary to use the “N” word in every sentence he made knowing full well there were two blacks talking with him. Lucky for him I didn't feel particularly offended by the word at the time. He also made jokes about how dark I am, even though I am actually lightskinned. This guy went on to insult the Indian too, calling him “terrorist” and other bad 
names
. As if being from an Asian country that isn't China or Vietnam= Terrorist! And he actually expected the other Americans to side with him, even asking them what they were possibly doing, mingling with us 'inferiors'. Fortunately, the other people, being more sensible than him, refused and called him out on his bullshit.
 
He then went on to insult our countries, called us 'poor', ' hungry' and even dared me to go outside and tell a policeman I didn't believe in Allah to prove how 'free' my country was ( disregarding the fact I live in the southern and predominantly Christian part of the country). This was around the time a Nigerian man hijacked a plane in the US so for a while, Nigeria was considered an “anti-US” country.
 
This went on for a while, so we had no choice but to murder the jerk and move on (video game, remember). This brief encounter led me to believe that all Americans were rude, ignorant Jacka**es and this stuck with me for a while. Although now I know that not all Americans are dumb. But the sad truth is that there are still a LOT of ignoramuses, perhaps even more than the smart ones, and this means people are more likely to meet an ignorant American. But the truth is EVERY country has dumb people, and singling out one country to pick on it is wrong. Maybe it's because USA is the current top dog. So everyone expects them to know everything about the rest of the world, like a father would.
 
Also I see a lot of people saying things like
 
“Americans aren't dumb, we have GEDs!!”
 
Well, that is as relevant as saying a tiger isn't aggressive because you saw it climb a tree.
 
“Dumb” in this context refers to “uninformed”, not “uneducated”.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
This incident happened around Christmas while I was working in Mississippi for a short time.
 
I was returning home from work and I was walking back to my apartment. I had just parked my car (that still carried the license plate from NY). An old American lady, who was walking her dog, noticed my license plate and asked me -
 
“Are you from New York? “
 
“Yes, I am.” I replied.
 
“Do they celebrate Christmas in New York ?” she asked me.
 
I paused for a moment but then replied - “Oh yeah, they do!”
 
Now, I am not sure if that qualifies as being ignorant but to me it was - ‘Woah’!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
The most ignorant? Well, when I travelled in Florida with my family, we often ate in restaurants (because why not? We were there to take a much needed family vacation). Being from Israel, we naturally spoke in Hebrew amongst ourselves (and it probably did not help that my English, like my Hebrew, is often peppered with German words and terms when used verbally). I cannot even count the number of waitresses who told us that they speak fluent Spanish if case we prefer.
 
Now, personally, I did not mind, it was clear that the waitresses were simply trying to be friendly and helpful to customers, and
Continue Reading
The most ignorant? Well, when I travelled in Florida with my family, we often ate in restaurants (because why not? We were there to take a much needed family vacation). Being from Israel, we naturally spoke in Hebrew amongst ourselves (and it probably did not help that my English, like my Hebrew, is often peppered with German words and terms when used verbally). I cannot even count the number of waitresses who told us that they speak fluent Spanish if case we prefer.
 
Now, personally, I did not mind, it was clear that the waitresses were simply trying to be friendly and helpful to customers, and besides, I do speak fluent Spanish as well, and I saw it as an invitation to practice it (and it came handy that one time in Orlando where I met a vendor from Venezuela who really spoke only Spanish). But I kept thinking, and still think to this day: If you are as fluent in Spanish as you claim, can’t you recognize that the language we are speaking is not even remotely similar to Spanish?
 
EDIT: Exceedingly stupid comments trying to argue with me about my own experience or proficiency in English, or just comments trying to push baseless speculations are going to be deleted. I really have neither the time nor patience for this.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I uses to work in tourist information in London. It just so happened to be Flying Ant Day when an American gentleman approached.
 
“You information?” He asked, in a Texan accent. “What's with all these bugs?”
 
“Well, we call it Flying Ant Day but it's several days each year where male ants swarm around hoping to find the queen to mate with them.”
 
The gentleman pauses, processing this information. “The Queen? All these bugs gonna mate with the Queen of Engerland?!!
 
“No, sir. No. That would actually be horrific, wouldn't it?”

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: Probably have met my share of ignorant Americans (I’m talking about you Trump), but in this case it has to do with a lady I met at the flea market. She was selling a beautiful american flag, you know the high quality vs some nylon crappy plastic flags. My best friend and I, probably 15 at the time wanted it and asked her the price. She replied “Well since it only has 50 stars on it, I’ll sell it to you at a discount.” No she wasn’t joking. She truly thought our current flag had 53 stars. Sorry Guam, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, not yet… we didnt correct her and took the discount.

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article: A lot of good stuff! Some of the big ones are a reduction in total cholesterol, a reduction in fat weight if done consistently, and more even blood sugar levels. Just be sure you are appropriately resting your body, and being wary of any injuries. Diet and exercise do way better than most medicines in preventing the future onset of heart disease in the vast majority of people. It’s just the determination that is the magic ingredient.

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
A good coach would ask you:
 
What are your goals? 
What does "I am happy with my body" look and feel like to you?
They'd assess your current fitness level and look at limitations/strengths.
 
If you're just starting out, fitness classes are a great place. From Zumba to CrossFit to Body Pump or Yoga, it's a supervised, directed area.
 
If you're interested in weight training, really just ask someone that looks how you want to look "What do you do?" Gyms can be awkward, but almost everyone loves to talk about their workout.

I had never considered our Family poor… even in the past where we struggled to keep food on the table 3 times a day. As a family of 9 I know my parents had struggled a lot to send us to school. They are both Farmers and in the Philippines being a Farmer is hard, Farm necessities are expensive and the prices of the produce just depends on the prices in the market as Farmers are just Price takers. I had seen my mama cried because my older Siblings needed money for school and nobody would lend her the money she needs. I experienced walking kilometers to stores to ask if they would let us have basic goods like salt and sugar for credit only for them to refuse as we still have outstanding balance. Most of the time we don’t have money to buy snacks at school. Almost all my clothes are handdown from my sisters. But all this things doesn’t made me feel poor. Mostly because of my Mother’s teaching…she always say we are not poor; we have a roof over our head, we are able to go to school, we have food despite the difficulty and most of all we have each other to lean on. This I had strongly believed was and will always be my greatest treasure in life. No one is poor as one way or another we have wealth in each of us, and this wealth can never be measure by how much money you have in the bank or how expensive your gadgets are. Knowledge is wealth, good health is wealth, love is wealth, genuine Friends is wealth and Everyone in this world is born and raised with these Wealth all around us. This is the world’s way of being fair to Everyone, by being unfair; No one can have it all. In a world where people see themselves of what they lack and take for granted what we already had, I hope I made you felt Rich. Everyone is Poor as Everyone is Rich in their own ways. Have a great day Everyone!

Depends on your definition of “best.” Best for my cardiovascular benefits? Best for my muscle growth? Best to just get in a good sweat in the least amount of time and effort for me?
 
(Note that I keep mentioning “me" and “my" to emphasize that what works for me doesn't necessarily work the same for others. All of our bodies are different and will respond differently. But you may know that based on how you worded your question.)
 
For the sake of providing some kind of answer, though: 
Vertical climbing.
Excellent for cardio
Low-impact (much needed for me after years of abusing my knees playing basketball on asphalt — a wonder that I don't have a torn ACL)
Hits up nearly all of the major muscle groups, in both the lower and upper body
Can stay at home to do it, and vertical climber machines are fairly easy to transport, depending on the brand and type you get
The vertical climber I have is a MaxiClimber XL-2000. Hands-down the best investment I've made for my physical health, and extremely thankful for getting it pre-COVID, since I have zero plans for paying for a gym membership again.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was in a store some years back, buying foam rubber to make cushions for my couch. I found the type I wanted and said to the girl behind the counter, “I want two yards, please.”
 
Her response? “I can’t sell it to you by the yard. I can only sell it by the foot.”
 
Not realizing the problem, I repeated myself. “Just give me two yards.” She opened her mouth to reply, I looked at the expression on her face and said, “OK. give me six feet.”
 
On the way home in the car, I ranted about the American education system for a solid fifteen minutes.

A
 few kids in the background started to laugh
 
I proceeded to attempt a debate in which he quickly pushed me down. He apologized but not before giving me a lecture on how the world trade centers were holograms placed in our memories to give the NSA an excuse to spy on us.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
If your workout is very light then definitely yes. But remember all muscles of your body needs time to repair. REST IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF BODY BUILDING. If you are not giving your muscle fibers time to repair after a workout do not expect good results.
 
I recommend moderate workout of particular muscle groups a day with adequate rest.
 
For example
 
Monday - Shoulders & Upper Back
 
Tuesday - Chest & Lower Back
 
Wednesday - Cardio & upper Abs
 
Thursday - Arms & Lats
 
Friday - Lower Body
 
Saturday - Cardio & lower Abs
 
Sunday - rest
 
So in this routine, the next time u work on your shoulders you have already given

If your workout is very light then definitely yes. But remember all muscles of your body needs time to repair. REST IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF BODY BUILDING. If you are not giving your muscle fibers time to repair after a workout do not expect good results.
 
I recommend moderate workout of particular muscle groups a day with adequate rest.
 
For example
 
Monday - Shoulders & Upper Back
 
Tuesday - Chest & Lower Back
 
Wednesday - Cardio & upper Abs
 
Thursday - Arms & Lats
 
Friday - Lower Body
 
Saturday - Cardio & lower Abs
 
Sunday - rest
 
So in this routine, the next time u work on your shoulders you have already given enough time for it to recover.
 
Note - larger muscle groups like shoulder, chest, quads etc needs minimum 5–6 days to recover.
 
Smaller muscle groups like abs takes 2 days max to recover.

I am an Indian and I look very typically Indian but having seen Hispanic people in the US I guess in a place like DC one might mistake me for a Hispanic immigrant also.
 
I was a tourist to the US for a few weeks. Washington DC to be precise.
 
I was walking down the street in Adams Morgan area of DC - an upscale residential area. I just knew the way to the Metro station from my friend’s flat. Suddenly this American woman with her children asked me the way to some place in the neighbourhood. And I had no clue where she wanted to go, least of all how to get there.
 
So I said politely that sorry I am a tourist and I have no clue about the neighbourhood.
 
She seemed fairly angry with me for not knowing the neighbourhood. I tried to explain to her that I was a tourist from far away India. She had no idea, it seemed, as to what a tourist was, least of all what or where India was on the global map (if at all she knew about the globe). I just gave up and she kept on hurling abuses at me, or at least that is what it seemed to me. I beat a hasty retreat from there. It was a winter morning in DC and there weren’t too many pedestrians around.
 
I don’t know what she thought of me, but for me she was the dumbest American I have ever met. It is really difficult to believe that America produces the maximum number of Nobel Laureates :-)

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
For someone like me, living in an apartment building, I would say to start with walking down all 9 flights of stairs from the top floor to the bottom, and then back up again as step 1 (do the circuit twice, when the first circuit becomes easier).
 
Then find a suitable area of the apartment big enough for you to lie flat, and do classic push-ups, 10 of them per set, for 3 sets. If you cannot manage the push-ups, then drop your knees to the ground and push from there. Another starting progression if you cannot complete a “full” push-up is to just focus on doing the downward part of the movement - 
Continue Reading
For someone like me, living in an apartment building, I would say to start with walking down all 9 flights of stairs from the top floor to the bottom, and then back up again as step 1 (do the circuit twice, when the first circuit becomes easier).
 
Then find a suitable area of the apartment big enough for you to lie flat, and do classic push-ups, 10 of them per set, for 3 sets. If you cannot manage the push-ups, then drop your knees to the ground and push from there. Another starting progression if you cannot complete a “full” push-up is to just focus on doing the downward part of the movement - usually, you will reach a point where you end up just flopping down the rest of the way… try to avoid banging your nose on the floor, it will hurt… but if you put as much effort into the downward part as you can and get as low as you can on every rep, and then finish with the flop every rep, and just reset back to the top of the movement, you will eventually manage to get all the way down without flopping. Then you just have to do the push, which will be hard, but give it 100% and then stop and reset as needed.
 
Next, bodyweight squats. Sit on a kitchen chair, or the toilet, or a comfortable chair if you really want to. Without using your arms, lean forward and stand up. Once you are fully upright, sit back down again but do not let your weight sink into the chair - just sit down until you feel contact between your body and the material of the seat. Now stand up again. Remember, no hands! Also, your feet should not move at all. Repeat for 10 reps per set, 3 sets.
 
Lunges - from a standing position, take a step forward with one foot. Drive your front knee forward and bend it, until your hip is as close to the heel of your front foot as you can manage, ideally with your rear leg being straight. Now move back up to your starting position and repeat the motion with the other leg. Repeat 10 times per set, for 3 sets.
 
As a beginner workout routine, that would usually be enough to start with.

Firstly, focus on your lifestyle.
Make sure you get at least 7 hours of sleep everyday.
Never miss your breakfast.
Include fruits in your diet.
Eat breakfast like a king and dinner like a begger. Yes, have a heavy breakfast and a light dinner.
Try to incorporate healthy snacks and include high fibre food and green tea that help in detoxification of body in between meals.
Involve yourself in more physical activities.
Now coming to exercises for beginners, you can include
Brisk walking - for already 45 minutes daily.
Jogging
Skipping - keep a check on the count and make sure the graph goes up. Try doing it in the morning and evening.
You can try sports:
Badminton
Football
Swimming - gives you a full body workout.
To make the fun element over power your routine, you can try:
Dancing
Zumba
Hola hoop - works out the belly area.
Power yoga
If you want to just do exercises to enhance just some specific part of your body, you can join the gym and take the help of your instructor who will direct you how to do the exercises the right way.
 
If joining a gym isn't possible to due to time and money constrains, then you can do many exercises at your home's comfort too. Google and YouTube can provide you with the much needed guidance. The most important is getting the exercise right. If you can get someone who can help you with it, it would be great.
 
You can also install some applications that will help you to keep yourself keep on track.
 
Hope this helps.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In 2000, I had moved from Dubai to San Antonio to attend school for a few years.
 
On my first day at school (8th grade), after I mumbled my name to my American homeroom teacher, she asked “Dubai, How exciting! What is the mode of transportation there?”
 
I was utterly confused (evident by my expression), to which she responded by repeating herself loudly and pausing after each word (I’m Indian so she probably assumed I didn't speak much English) “DID. YOU. RIDE. A. CAMEL. TO. SCHOOL?”
 
BIGGEST face palm moment of my life.

title: What are the dirtiest songs you've ever heard?
article:

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article: Working out at home can help you a lot. It is one of the best and cheapest ways to stay active and many exercises can actually be done without requiring basic gym equipment. You can start with doing some yoga to stretch your body. That followed with some sit ups and crunches. Try and rest your muscles alternatively so that you give enough time to recover from the set. You can also include push ups and slowly and steadily by the day increase the strain on your muscles. Just remember, do not exert yourself more than what you can take as it can cause injuries.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was working the night shift at a gas station.
 
As things were often slow at that time, I often took a book.
 
Since I was studying Arabic, and since I am a Latter-day Saint, I took the Book of Mormon in Arabic.
 
I had it open on the counter when several well-dressed white men in their thirties came in. They asked me what the book was. I told them.
 
“Oh,” said one, “so when Saddam Hussein invades us, you want to be able to tell them that you don’t love Jesus.”
 
This was more stupidity than ignorance. Stupidity is a choice.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Moved to Richmond, VA from Toronto in 9th grade:
 
In 9th grade (‘75) girl asked me what is it like to; live in a small town?; live in an igloo?; ride a dogsled?
 
Golfing in about 2000 I went to a local golf course and went to the snack bar to buy a pack of cigarettes for $2.50, gave the girl (probably 15–18 yrs. old) a $5 bill and she had to talk to her mother to figure out how much change to hand me back. I always said I would go back and marry that girl since I could have handed her a $10, told her it was a $100 and she probably wouldn’t have known the difference.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Initially this was a bad experience for me that actually got turned around to something positive.
 
In 1999 I flew into Washington DC to do some sight-seeing and travelling around the U.S. I’d been to America once a year for a number of years for my vacation. This was just another holiday. The man stamping my passport asked where I was staying. I named the hotel and gave the address. He asked how much money I had. I can’t remember now but it was probably $2,000 in traveller’s cheques (checks), which is more or less what I always brought with me. He asked how long I was staying, I said “two weeks;
Continue Reading
Initially this was a bad experience for me that actually got turned around to something positive.
 
In 1999 I flew into Washington DC to do some sight-seeing and travelling around the U.S. I’d been to America once a year for a number of years for my vacation. This was just another holiday. The man stamping my passport asked where I was staying. I named the hotel and gave the address. He asked how much money I had. I can’t remember now but it was probably $2,000 in traveller’s cheques (checks), which is more or less what I always brought with me. He asked how long I was staying, I said “two weeks; the first week in said hotel and second week I’ll probably hit the road and see more of the country”. He asked where in the country I’d go. I said I was thinking of going to southern states but hadn’t set anything in stone yet.
 
He turned and motioned to a security guard behind him and to my surprise they led me away. It was pretty embarrassing. I remember everybody in the line behind me gawping like I was some criminal. Just to paint the scene: I’m white, at the time I was in my late 20s, I had a good job, spoke well, dressed nicely, etc. I never got angry, never cussed or raised my voice.
 
They sat me down in a big waiting room with 10 or 20 others. I noticed the others waiting along side me could not speak English and were having problems filling in their visas.
 
A man in a uniform (a cop? I don’t know) with a handgun sat opposite me. He shouted out “what’s your occupation?”. I said “computing”. In front of everybody, including 5–10 other cops, he shouted “oh… I get it… you’re the type to go online on a Friday night and look for women!”. I was so embarrassed! I just quietly said “no”. He then shouted “I know… you look for a date online because you can’t talk to women in person. I know what you’re like. I know the sort of person you are!”. I was so embarrassed about his shouting, that again, I quietly just said “no”.
 
Then he turned off his computer at the switch instead of shutting it down. He said “Oops. Server problem. What are we going to do? Call tech support? How would you fix it? The computer’s not working. How am I going to process your visa if my computer is broken? You need to fix it!”. I just shrugged. I felt terrible.
 
He sat there in silence for a while, then called me over to his desk and wrote some notes. I sat there dry-mouthed and exhausted from my flight and his behaviour. Eventually he looked up and said “ok, you can go”. I stood up to walk away but just couldn’t. I thought there is no way I can enjoy being in this country after this experience.
 
I desperately looked around for something to say to show I wasn’t going to take all this nonsense. I saw he had a ring on his finger. Out of desperation I said “what’s that ring for?”. He said “I won it in the Super Bowl”. I replied “no you didn’t, you liar. That’s a class ring”. He said “what do you know about football anyway? You guys just kick that stupid little white soccer ball around”. I said “I know more about your football than you do”. He said “yeah? Let’s just see about that”. He hit me with a number of questions about the NFL. I answered everything with ease. He couldn’t believe it! He shouted “oh! Check this guy out! Ask him anything about the NFL!”. All his buddies crowded around the desk and I put my feet up on it LOL. They all fired questions at me and I answered everything perfectly.
 
The officer who had insulted me at the start shouted “You can come back any time! We’ll drink some beers, we’ll watch the game…”. Then he shouted at one of his co-workers (who was wearing a suit) “go and get this guy’s bags for him!”. I sat with my feet up on the desk while they ran off to collect my things from the baggage hall. I felt 10 feet tall when the guy brought my suitcase to me on one of those little trucks. At last I could enjoy my holiday! :)
 
But that was one bizarre experience!

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
This depends on the state of your training and your level of advancement.
 
If you train 3 days a week or less, whole-body is the only rational option.
 Each of the 4 basic movements requires at least 2 and preferably 3 training sessions per week and this cannot be fitted into 3 days with any kind of split.
 
(A whole body routine does not mean that every training session is identical. Just that you train the 4 basic movements (lower body push/pull, upper body push/pull) each time you train. You can vary the exercises, reps, weight etc.)
 
If you are at a level of advancement such that you are unable to
Continue Reading
This depends on the state of your training and your level of advancement.
 
If you train 3 days a week or less, whole-body is the only rational option.
 Each of the 4 basic movements requires at least 2 and preferably 3 training sessions per week and this cannot be fitted into 3 days with any kind of split.
 
(A whole body routine does not mean that every training session is identical. Just that you train the 4 basic movements (lower body push/pull, upper body push/pull) each time you train. You can vary the exercises, reps, weight etc.)
 
If you are at a level of advancement such that you are unable to progress with the stress you can accumulate in the training time you have, you need to add more sessions.
 
Let’s take an example of a very strong lifter, let’s call him Ali, with a 300kg squat, working on 400. Ali has decided to do 8 sets of 3 reps with 250kg (83%) on his main squat day, Monday. He also does front squats on Wednesday, up to 180kg 3x3 and paused squats on Friday, 200kg 5x5. His workout goes as follows.
 
20kg x 20
50kg x 10
80kg x 5
120kg x 5
160kg x 3
200kg x 3
220kg x 1
240kg x 1
250kg x 3,3,3,3,3,3,3,3
 
That’s a total of 16 sets. Ali takes 8 minutes of rest between the work sets, 3 minutes between the lighter warmup sets and 5 between the heavier ones. That’s about 90 minutes of rest total, so we’re looking at close to 2 hours, just for squats.
 
Now, at this point his focus and attention are beginning to flag, his legs tire and he’s getting hungry. Time to stop. Bench presses will have to wait until Tuesday.
 
If you’re not at Ali’s level, there is probably little benefit to splitting up your workout.

Let me tell you my story.
 
My 4th day in America, i went to visit my friend( American) house for lunch, her father was not very welcoming though, so she introduced me etc and we sat for lunch, I have been told you should always respect your elders, atleast everybody from Indian familes teach to thier kids. So i am natuarlly respected him.
 
We sat for lunch, and i felt uncomfortable eating with spoons,fork and knife, so i asked them do they mind if i eat with my hand. The coversation is below:
 
Me: Do you mind, if i eat with my hand?
 
He: its ok, you can.
 
Me: Thanks and started eating with my hand..
 
He: so, everyone in India eat with hands?
 
Me: No sir, depends on Person but my family has been eating with hands always. I think many indians eat with Hands, its just comfortable for us.
 
He: thats weird,
 
Me: I also prefer eating sitting on the floor , ofcourse i didn’t ask them that. Lol.
 
By his discussion, i came to know he has patchy ideas of India .. ok lets get back to the conversation.
 
He: what? On the floor? Oh, Boy you guys have to learn a lot.
 
Me: *smiled*
 
He: i believe India is poor Country and lots of population.
 
Me: Couldn’t say No.( obviously he was comparing with USA)
 
He: So, i see many indians come here, thats why.
 
Me: couldn’t say No ( i didn’t know what to reply)
 
He kept belittling about India ofcourse with his patchy ideas..
 
Me: felt uncomfortable, but i decided to speak up. And waiting for him to say one more thing…
 
He: so, many Indians are not civilized.
 
Me: Thats it, i thought enough is enough in my mind. I started saying…
 
Yes, Sir, We eat with our hands, many of us still sit on the floor and eat, But you are talking about Civilization.. do you know, where was the First human civilzation started in this Planet?
 
He: no, where?
 
Me: India, the First civilization started in in the at Sindu River, they call it Sindhu Civilization. We are the guys , who started using fire for the first time.
 
He: Really? I don’t think so..
 
Me: I can show you in Google, or you can refer 5th grade history text book.
 
He: *silent*
 
Me: So, we are the guys who introduced civilization to the world. But still many of us eat with hands and sit on the floor not because we don’t know how to make dining tables, its because there are specific reasons why we are doing that.
 
Ofcourse, i made him realise many things about what India is , and he changed his perception about India.
 
Note: i think whatever i told him is true, but i may be incorrect. But i couldn’t bear his discussion about India so i spoke. And yes we are good friends now.
 
No offense to anyone.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

I’d like to open with Simon Morton’s ending paragraph, on his reply : -
 
“Really nice guys and not stupid but very insular and didn't really have a great understanding of the rest of the world.” ….. As this is frequently the case, and the laugh or eye-roll you do is tinged with pathos. Although there were exceptions. Anyway….
 
a; I’m 11, on my first foreign holiday out of Britain : Ostend in Brussels. My parents booked a coach trip to Paris, with a quick tour of the city, followed by a show at the Lido (poor man’s Follies - my first tople

Q: “ Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met? “
 
I’d like to open with Simon Morton’s ending paragraph, on his reply : -
 
“Really nice guys and not stupid but very insular and didn't really have a great understanding of the rest of the world.” ….. As this is frequently the case, and the laugh or eye-roll you do is tinged with pathos. Although there were exceptions. Anyway….
 
a; I’m 11, on my first foreign holiday out of Britain : Ostend in Brussels. My parents booked a coach trip to Paris, with a quick tour of the city, followed by a show at the Lido (poor man’s Follies - my first topless women experience😜 ). The bus is moving slowly in traffic, through the Arab quarter & gets parallel to a small park, where kids are playing. Hearing them through the open windows, elderly U.S. lady is amazed how well they speak French !! 🤷‍♂️🤦‍♂️
 
b: I’m 22, on my first surf trip to N. Spain; S.W. France. 1971. Vietnam is still going, we meet up with a SoCal surfer who has “draft dodged”, Given money by parents & uncle, after 2 cousins already injured out, he had flown to Paris & trained it down to Biarritz. After a few months travelling in France, Spain & Portugal, he was … “… hoping to go & get work in New Zealand - IS THAT ANYWHERE NEAR HERE !???” 🤣🙄 [Beautiful irony being N.Z. & France are almost EXACTLY opposite one another, on a globe]
 
c: Now 33, Burleigh Heads, QUEENSLAND, Visiting SoCal surfer spouting off how much cheaper his Macca’s burger would be “back home”, in the usual “We’re #1” mode… until we explain the US-Aus$ exchange rate: ours is a dollar cheaper. in reality 🍔🍟
 
There are plenty more…. 😎

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My entire adult life I’ve either been in the US Army, or worked for them as a contractor. In my travels I’ve encountered pockets of astonishing ignorance ranging from people not knowing that there are other countries in the Americas (hint: there are) to people not knowing the Christianity didn’t exist prior to Jesus (he was a Jew), to people believing that autism is caused by vaccines (the one thing we do know is that it *isn’t* caused by vaccines), to others thinking that prayers alone could cure cancer (sadly, this is untrue as well).
 
I think my favorite one of them all is a woman who was dre
Continue Reading
My entire adult life I’ve either been in the US Army, or worked for them as a contractor. In my travels I’ve encountered pockets of astonishing ignorance ranging from people not knowing that there are other countries in the Americas (hint: there are) to people not knowing the Christianity didn’t exist prior to Jesus (he was a Jew), to people believing that autism is caused by vaccines (the one thing we do know is that it *isn’t* caused by vaccines), to others thinking that prayers alone could cure cancer (sadly, this is untrue as well).
 
I think my favorite one of them all is a woman who was dreadfully ignorant of … well… pretty much everything really, but her lack of understanding about anything involving Hawaii amused me.
 
As we were waiting for our children (who were classmates and friends) to get out of school she lamented to me that her husband was being reassigned from Fort Huachuca, Arizona to Fort Shafter, Hawaii. I asked her what the problem was with moving over there? Was it the economy and how expensive some things were over there? No. Was it being so far from family? No. Was it because they had to board pets in quarantine for a while (I couldn't remember if they had pets)? No.
 
After I finally ran out of reasons why the move could be so traumatic, I flat out asked her. It turns out she was feeling overwhelmed by all the things needed to be done in preparation of the move, and the need to get a passport.
 
"Passport? That's cool, plan on doing a little traveling on the way to Hawaii? Where are you going?"
 
She looked at me like I suddenly grew a leg out of my head. "We're just going to Hawaii."
 
Befuddled I asked why they would need to get a passport if they weren't planning on doing any foreign travel. "Because it's Hawaii!"
 
"You do know that Hawaii is one of the states in the US, right?"
 
"Of course, I'm not stupid."
 
"I only said that because passports are only needed for foreign travel, and I can't imagine a flight from here would take you to a foreign country"
 
"It's because we have to fly over the ocean."
 
"..."
 
Because apparently flying over the ocean means you have to obtain a passport. She was also worried about learning a new language... she didn't believe me that English was the primary language spoken there.
 
Heh.
 
I ran into her randomly last year in the DC area and asked if they ever managed to get in some foreign travel since they already had their passports (because of course she went got them since I was clearly wrong). Turns out that no, they didn't manage to get their passports stamped after all.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
there are lots of poor people on quora.
 
you can tell because they use smart phones instead of computers.
 
they rarely take the extra effort phones appear to require to answer questions without simply streaming a continuous line of text with no structure except punctuation…
 
sure, wealthy folks use smart phones too, but the poor people are still there too.
 
our marriage stole all of our wealth when our ex ran up credit cards we couldn’t pay off…
 
now we’re about as poor as it comes without being back on the streets again.
 
we support our girlfriend of fifteen years because we need help with day-to-day thi
Continue Reading
there are lots of poor people on quora.
 
you can tell because they use smart phones instead of computers.
 
they rarely take the extra effort phones appear to require to answer questions without simply streaming a continuous line of text with no structure except punctuation…
 
sure, wealthy folks use smart phones too, but the poor people are still there too.
 
our marriage stole all of our wealth when our ex ran up credit cards we couldn’t pay off…
 
now we’re about as poor as it comes without being back on the streets again.
 
we support our girlfriend of fifteen years because we need help with day-to-day things and she is a disabled nurse who is now barely able to work in any capacity.
 
she sells her blood when things get really bad like now.
 
we can’t sell our blood, there are too many blood thinners in it.
 
we live in constant fear of that one incident that leaves us homeless because we live from one disability payment to the next with no disposable income to save for a rainy day.
 
quora is where we amuse ourselves as best we can while living in pain every day for the past forty-three years because there are no safe medications to help us with our pain.
 
because we cannot afford both a smart phone and an internet service provider, and because we cannot operate a phone due to its tiny size, our poor eyesight, and our crippled hands, we have only our isp.
 
with our computer it is much easier to type than on a phone and we have built-up our mouse with cardboard to make it fit more comfortably in our hand with a t-wing formation on top that our fingers fit around and below to lift our mouse off the table.
 
our hands would become completely disabled if all we had to work on was a phone.
 
when google, microsoft, yahoo, etc. all went to smart-phone based authentication schemas we had only our girlfriend's phone to use for authentication and that backfired leaving us with no access to any of our original social media accounts.
 
we had to start new accounts and dodge the authentication issue as best we can without a phone.
 
it’s a bit scary.
 
we cannot afford to get the problem fixed, there are far too many hurdles, especially ai help desks.
 
we had an elaborate free private website on weebly that we could scarcely afford to register a personal url for at eighty bucks for five years.
 
when another company bought them out they required a monthly subscription fee of fifteen bucks per month to keep our free account and our paid-for url.
 
so we lost access to our own website on weebly and cannot find it again without our url.
 
we are very poor and therefor marginalized by minor expenses that other people pay without a thought for where the money must come from and what they must do without.
 
we’re doing without much food and with inadequate medication today.
 
we’ll be having ramen again in a little while, just as long as we can stand to wait…
 
because of rent control we can just barely afford to remain where we live.
 
because of rent control our landlord grows more motivated to evict us every year.
 
we are no longer qualified to work in any of the professional capacities we have worked in before.
 
we are far too decrepit to be offered another job, we can scarcely walk.
 
our best skill is now creative writing, but without help we can never finish any of our projects.
 
we hope we will find a writing partner one day, but so far none…
 
quora is a great place for us to find questions that suit our interests and to help us to develop our ideas for our best stories.
 
so far so good, but tomorrow is always in doubt.
 
not even the meals on wheels are reliable, they totally skipped the previous wednesday but only deliver three times a week. wednesday is the only day they provide three meals instead of two.
 
you will note from our punctuation that we are an anti-capitalist.
 
enjoy!
 
-rho…
 
…
 
originally answered…
 
are there any poor people on quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: After a purchase a store clerk asked me for my postal code. I responded that I didn't have a US Postal code, as I was visiting from abroad. Friendly enough this person continued to ask me where I was from. “I'm from the Netherlands” I told him. There was a quizzical look. Ok, nothing new, that name is confusing to many; so I declared: “Holland” this was followed by another blank stare “that's in Europe” I said … it was as if the light bulb inside this person's brain suddenly lit up “ah, Europe” he said with a broad smile on his face…. “Isn't that where the Queen of England lives?”

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
As with all fitness questions, it depends.
 
There are two conditions that I’ll put on a “yes” answer:
You’re not pushing yourself at an extreme level (keeping it under 80% intensity)
You still take a rest day every microcycle (every 1–2 weeks).
If you work out 
hard
 every day your body won’t rebuild and metabolic fatigue will set in quickly (it’ll set in if you work daily, also even where your workout is >50% <80%). You could set experience 
overtraining syndrome
, where your body cannot recover enough between workouts.
 
Additionally, your body requires a certain amount of time to recover between workou
Continue Reading
As with all fitness questions, it depends.
 
There are two conditions that I’ll put on a “yes” answer:
You’re not pushing yourself at an extreme level (keeping it under 80% intensity)
You still take a rest day every microcycle (every 1–2 weeks).
If you work out 
hard
 every day your body won’t rebuild and metabolic fatigue will set in quickly (it’ll set in if you work daily, also even where your workout is >50% <80%). You could set experience 
overtraining syndrome
, where your body cannot recover enough between workouts.
 
Additionally, your body requires a certain amount of time to recover between workouts. If you’re providing enough stimulus to your muscles this is usually between 36 and 48 hours (
depending on the muscle worked (muscles like your core tend to recover faster
), your gender (
women tend to recover faster than men)
, the intensity that you worked the muscle (
the harder you worked it the longer it will take)
, your age (
over 60 you will require as much as 96 hours rest to recover between workouts), 
the nutrition applied, and your hormone profile (
more testosterone, HGH, IGF will lead to quicker recovery when coupled with adequate amounts of protein and glucose
)).
If you don’t give it enough time, you won’t build up past your initial baseline, and your muscles will suffer.
 
As metabolic fatigue builds up, even in lighter intensity training, you’ll feel it all over. It could be something simple at first — you stop improving in your lifts, for example. Eventually you start getting worse. Soon you start getting injuries that aren’t healing. You start to feel depressed. Even one day off with complete relaxation or even a light walk could be enough to clear you out, if you catch it early enough. Serious cases of overtraining could require more time.
 
To re-iterate:
If you don’t work it over 80% intensity every day
If you 
do
 take a break once every 1–2 weeks
You’ll be fine.
 
If you notice things going wrong — you start feeling weaker, you stop improving, you start feeling like crap in general, you start getting injuries…take a step back. Rest. Recover.
Brief anecdote as illustration
 
Once I was really working my pull ups. I was stuck at 18. I would do them daily, at least 4 sets. I hit 18 every time in my first set, I ended up doing about 50 a day. At first I was gaining daily, I went from 8 to 10 to 14, to 18…but then the growth stopped. I was stuck there for a couple weeks.
 
I took 2 days off from doing pull ups.
 
The next time I stepped up to the bar I did 25 in my first set.
 
I’m not saying that you’ll have dramatic results like this, but sometimes the missing part of your workout is actually 
not
 working out.

article:

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article: I like a fresh loaf of French bread cut long ways covered with butter, ham pastrami and roast beef then pepper jack cheese and provolone put it open face in the oven and let it toast to a bubbling Brown and meanwhile shreds lettuce ,chop tomato, peppercinis and black olives, chopped onion salt pepper and Italian seasoning and olive oil and fresh lemon squeeze or red wine vinegar. Mix it all up in a bowl and top your sandwich with it. Put the lid on and cut it into about four servings. Yum!!

article:

We both joined in the spring of freshman year, and as juniors he and I were the fraternity’s president and VP, respectively. Now when I tell you this guy is intelligent, I’m not kidding around. He got excellent grades while double majoring with a heavy course load every semester. He scored over 170 on the LSAT and went on to graduate from Columbia law. Yet despite his impressive intellect and education, he is obscenely igno

The most ignorant person I’ve ever met is, strangely, also one of the most intelligent and well-educated people I’ve ever met. He was one of my college fraternity brothers. We both joined in the spring of freshman year, and as juniors he and I were the fraternity’s president and VP, respectively. Now when I tell you this guy is intelligent, I’m not kidding around. He got excellent grades while double majoring with a heavy course load every semester. He scored over 170 on the LSAT and went on to graduate from Columbia law. Yet despite his impressive intellect and education, he is obscenely ignorant, and unfortunately, I think his supremely high intelligence made him that way. He’s one of only a select few people I’ve ever personally known that I would concede to being more intelligent than myself, and I think he’s the kind of person who’s so smart and so accustomed to being correct that he has lost any ability to maintain an open mind and overcome confirmation bias. He automatically dismisses any opinion he disagrees with as bullshit. Politically he’s a right-wing extremist who’s oblivious to his own extremism and genuinely believes all American liberal ideas to be idiotic nonsense. He lacks any ability to see outside his extremely-narrow worldview. It’s a shame that someone with such an excellent mind can be so hopelessly self-absorbed that they don’t see any errors in their own thinking.

The man (who is White) comes along. He notices the woman after sitting down across from her.
 
The first thing he says to this complete stranger?
 
“You are Oriental.” He informs her.
 
“The Chinese have round faces,” he continues. “The Japanese have oval faces and Koreans have square faces.”
 
“So,” he arrives smugly at his conclusion. “You are Chinese.”
 
Do Asians in America go about their days having to take for granted that they will be reduced to objects of speculation?
 
Being White, I can only imagine how it feels!
 
To place the man EVEN HIGHER on the scale of ignorance, the woman (based on our conversation before the man arrived) was not even “Oriental”!
 
She was Native American.

I have to admit that I’ve had a few laughs at the expense of Americans, mainly because some of them seem to be incredibly ignorant of the world outside of the USA and hold the belief that almost everything that they do culturally is what the rest of the world also does. I’ve lost count of the number of times I’ve been in a chat room and had someone from the US ask, “So what are you guys doing for the 4th of July?”
 
But the biggest clanger I’ve ever heard an American come out with was in 2009, when, on the eve of the US presidential election, Stevie Wonder told his audience, “Don’t forget to vote for Barak Obama tomorrow.”
 
I know the bloke is blind, but surely he knew what country he was in and surely he didn’t believe that the people of Perth, Western Australia, had the legal right to vote in US elections!
 
I hope some one has a story to top this one because I’m sure there could be a book in it - a big book!

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
This depends on the state of your training and your level of advancement.
 
If you train 3 days a week or less, whole-body is the only rational option.
 Each of the 4 basic movements requires at least 2 and preferably 3 training sessions per week and this cannot be fitted into 3 days with any kind of split.
 
(A whole body routine does not mean that every training session is identical. Just that you train the 4 basic movements (lower body push/pull, upper body push/pull) each time you train. You can vary the exercises, reps, weight etc.)
 
If you are at a level of advancement such that you are unable to
Continue Reading
This depends on the state of your training and your level of advancement.
 
If you train 3 days a week or less, whole-body is the only rational option.
 Each of the 4 basic movements requires at least 2 and preferably 3 training sessions per week and this cannot be fitted into 3 days with any kind of split.
 
(A whole body routine does not mean that every training session is identical. Just that you train the 4 basic movements (lower body push/pull, upper body push/pull) each time you train. You can vary the exercises, reps, weight etc.)
 
If you are at a level of advancement such that you are unable to progress with the stress you can accumulate in the training time you have, you need to add more sessions.
 
Let’s take an example of a very strong lifter, let’s call him Ali, with a 300kg squat, working on 400. Ali has decided to do 8 sets of 3 reps with 250kg (83%) on his main squat day, Monday. He also does front squats on Wednesday, up to 180kg 3x3 and paused squats on Friday, 200kg 5x5. His workout goes as follows.
 
20kg x 20
50kg x 10
80kg x 5
120kg x 5
160kg x 3
200kg x 3
220kg x 1
240kg x 1
250kg x 3,3,3,3,3,3,3,3
 
That’s a total of 16 sets. Ali takes 8 minutes of rest between the work sets, 3 minutes between the lighter warmup sets and 5 between the heavier ones. That’s about 90 minutes of rest total, so we’re looking at close to 2 hours, just for squats.
 
Now, at this point his focus and attention are beginning to flag, his legs tire and he’s getting hungry. Time to stop. Bench presses will have to wait until Tuesday.
 
If you’re not at Ali’s level, there is probably little benefit to splitting up your workout.

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?
article:
Unless you are currently bone thin with minimal chest strength, you are not likely going to see any noticeable chest muscle growth from doing push-ups.
 
Hypertrophy (muscle growth) requires that you perform heavy resistance training in a low to medium repetition range (5 to 8 reps per set), and progressively overload (increase) the resistance over time. The only scenario where push-ups would allow for that type of training is if you currently can’t do more than a few push-ups in a row.
 
Assuming you can already do more than a few push-ups in a row, you are going to need to either use a weighted ve
Continue Reading
Unless you are currently bone thin with minimal chest strength, you are not likely going to see any noticeable chest muscle growth from doing push-ups.
 
Hypertrophy (muscle growth) requires that you perform heavy resistance training in a low to medium repetition range (5 to 8 reps per set), and progressively overload (increase) the resistance over time. The only scenario where push-ups would allow for that type of training is if you currently can’t do more than a few push-ups in a row.
 
Assuming you can already do more than a few push-ups in a row, you are going to need to either use a weighted vest, or use some other form of resistance (free weights, machines, etc) in order to effectively train for muscle hypertrophy.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
You can do it everyday or 3–4–5 times a week.
 
But you should do it differently.
Make more reps or make the exercises more difficult or add more weight.
 
Of course the best scenario could be if you changed your workouts from time to time.
 
Because all exercises, no matter if they are very similar, they are developing different type of muscles.

They were both vaguely aware that being cold was bad and how to suckle. With time they've both become less ignorant, but neither still have any idea about the year the Declaration of Independence was signed or how many states there are in the US. I'd

This is such a mean question. It keeps popping up in my feed so I feel compelled to answer so I can at least partially address why it's such a mean question.
 
——
 
Who is the most ignorant person I've met in America? It's actually a tie. I'm related to both. They are my daughters. When I first met them, they were totally ignorant of almost everything. They were both vaguely aware that being cold was bad and how to suckle. With time they've both become less ignorant, but neither still have any idea about the year the Declaration of Independence was signed or how many states there are in the US. I'd guess most newborns are this ignorant, but they are the only two I've actually met.
 
Probably not the answer the questioner wanted, but demonstrably more ignorant than all the other examples I've read up to now.
 
—-
 
This is such a mean question because it gleefully celebrates someone's negative attributes. Largely in a condescending way. I get it. Most people on Quora are smart (to look at self-reported IQs you'd think mere geniuses are the dunces), so it's a safe place to make fun of a the unintelligent or, even more unforgivable, the unitellectual.
 
There are basically three reasons why someone is ignorant about a particular subject:
It isn’t important
They are undereducated
They aren't that smart
None of which are really good reasons for making fun of someone.
 
What I'm really curious about is where on the intelligence scale it goes from being hilarious to make fun of the stupid person to being cruel to make fun of the intellectually disabled person. Does it change if the person had the audacity to be raised by a religious conservative and have accepted what they were taught since they could listen?

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?
article:
There are more than three foundational movements that you would need to include in your workout in order for it to be complete, therefore it’s impossible for you to have a truly complete workout if you limit yourself to only performing three exercises.
 
So my first suggestion is to ditch this arbitrary three exercise limitation, and design your workouts around including as many foundational movements as possible within the amount of time that you have available for your workout. Even if you only have fifteen minutes to exercise, you can still do a hell of a lot more than three exercises.
 
With tha
Continue Reading
There are more than three foundational movements that you would need to include in your workout in order for it to be complete, therefore it’s impossible for you to have a truly complete workout if you limit yourself to only performing three exercises.
 
So my first suggestion is to ditch this arbitrary three exercise limitation, and design your workouts around including as many foundational movements as possible within the amount of time that you have available for your workout. Even if you only have fifteen minutes to exercise, you can still do a hell of a lot more than three exercises.
 
With that being said, if you’re still determined to restrict yourself to three exercises, I suggest you chose a squat, a push, and a pull movement. There are a variety of squat, push, and pull movements that you can perform, depending on the equipment you have access to. Assuming you’re using free weights, I’ll suggest the following:
Front Squat
Bench Press
Bent-Over Row
If you don’t have access to weights, and you’re strictly doing bodyweight exercises, then you could do the following:
Bulgarian Split Squat
Push-Up
Pull-Up
But again, any workout that limits you to just three exercises will still leave out several important foundational movements, so I don’t understand why you would impose such a strange and arbitrary limitation like this on your workouts.

There we were, my wife, my daughters and and myself, at a limestone cave in southern Oregon. The cave was open for touring - for an entry fee. I paid cash and included an American nickel in my payment. The young lady behind the counter looked closely (obviously not closely enough) and asked "what's this? I'm not accepting this!"
 
I also looked closely and saw that it had "E Pluribus Unum", "United States of America" and "In God We Trust" on it. So in answer to her question, I told her it was an American nickel. She repeated that she wasn't going to accept it and I asked her .. "It says "United States of America. This IS the United States of America, isn't it?"
 
However, for several reasons, I gave up:
 
- she was an idiot, and usually, there is little to be gained by arguing with idiots,
 
- it was only a nickel and I was able to replace it with another nickel - not worth making a scene over it,
 
- finally and most importantly, it turned out she was also our guide in that very dark cave and perhaps, even if she was an idiot, it wouldn't have been a good idea to unnecessarily antagonize her.
 
Edited; comment added, a week later: I also met another ignoramus.
 
I had an email friend, who I shall call "Granny" from the deep south of the US. I knew she was something of a cranky, ignorant redneck and my children asked me why I would bother to correspond with her? Because she is like a LOT of people out there, and I wanted to try to see and understand the world through lenses which were different than those I usually use (my own).
 
Oh, she was interesting, all right .. if ever some subject came up about politicians, she'd go on a several page rant about them, calling them every name in the book. I'm not sure she knew the meaning of the term "moderation"; at least, she almost never used it. And ignorant? When my Mom was in her mid-80's, she had a series of small strokes and Granny implied it was my fault for not feeding her all sorts of energy foods that you usually see in those scam ads. As it was, my Mom lived to 89; the average lifespan for women in the US is 82.1, so she certainly wasn't taken from us prematurely.
 
This went on for some years .. sometimes I'd tiptoe around her, sometimes, I'd invite a response and would never be disappointed. This carried on until she sent a note and copied several people, whereupon I and one other man on that list had the gall, the temerity, to respond with some of our own comments to the group she identified. Here is the first line of her reply: "
I do not remembe giving either one of you male atheist permission to rape the addresses of my livery
" [sic]. Then she went on to say how she wished she could castrate me, plus a series of other equally vicious comments. And how is it that I still have that quote? Because her response was so incredible, I copied her letter into my diary file, before I deleted all her email and her address. I haven’t heard from her since (18 months and counting), don’t expect to, but wouldn’t respond to her anyway.
 
Granny was a cranky, unhappy old woman who have obviously burned enough people in her life that she complained about not having many friends. It was my understanding that she was estranged even from her daughter; gee, I wonder why?

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Coping with money has been the largest moments of blank stares and clueless moments. These have racked up in frustrating variety over the years, so I’m going to cover two that caused the deepest sighs of restraint.
 
First moment was the attempt to pay for a fast food meal at a Burger King with two $2 bills for $3+ purchase. The young lady initially puzzled if it was real money, then, still dubious, tried to reject taking the bills as she had no clue how to take “this money” into the register.
 
After a moment of surprised silence, “Well, I would think entering $4 would be simple as it adds to $4.” 
Continue Reading
Coping with money has been the largest moments of blank stares and clueless moments. These have racked up in frustrating variety over the years, so I’m going to cover two that caused the deepest sighs of restraint.
 
First moment was the attempt to pay for a fast food meal at a Burger King with two $2 bills for $3+ purchase. The young lady initially puzzled if it was real money, then, still dubious, tried to reject taking the bills as she had no clue how to take “this money” into the register.
 
After a moment of surprised silence, “Well, I would think entering $4 would be simple as it adds to $4.” This was countered with, “No, no, there’s got to be more”.
 
More what? Likely due to the dumbstruck expression on my face, a manager stepped up and asked if he could help and the young lady thrust the bills at him with the frustrated squeak, “What do I do with these if they’re actually real money? How does this go into the register? 
What keys do I push?!
”
 
Another awkward silence while the manager had a jaw drop moment equal to mine, followed by, “2 + 2 is 4. Enter $4 and give back the change”. The manager gathered coins and handed them to me with, “I’m so very sorry, I hope you have a great day.”
 
Second moment was depositing a stack of 20 dollar bills at the bank. An obviously new trainee teller came to a halt and signaled her mentor at the next window. Although she was trying to be discreet, it was plain she thought the cash was questionable.
 
The other teller was a long-term employee of silvering hair, one I had known for years. She carefully sifted through the bills and then looked quizzically at the younger teller, who came back with, “Look, they’re not all the same … they should all look like this.” She held up one of the newer updated colorful 20 dollar bill.
 
Sorry, short string for me, I busted into giggles. The older teller struggled to not follow into hilarity and quietly explained that the green bills were older bills and perfectly good tender. Poor girl looked astonished as she’d never seen such money before.
 
After a mutual facepalm moment, my comment to the seasoned employee was, “Mercy, I suddenly feel ancient!” Her reply, “I really can’t describe aloud what I’m thinking or feeling.” Her expression spoke volumes.

Some years back we were returning a rental car to Kennedy Airport and stopped at a gas station on Long Island to fill the tank. Talking to the attendant, it emerged that although New York was only a few miles away, he’d never been. It transpired that he’d never even been off Long Island in his entire life. I ended up telling him about some of the places we as Brits had visited in the States.
 
I tell this story not to mock the young man in question but to highlight two things. Firstly, how the limited paid vacation entitlement stymies working people from learning about their own country, let alone going abroad, and secondly, how the state education system sometimes fails to create the spark of curiosity in those passing through it. Nice lad, very limited horizons.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
The best routine for exercising depends on your individual fitness goals and preferences. However, a well-rounded routine should typically include a combination of cardiovascular exercise, strength training, and flexibility/mobility work.
 
As for the routine when you go to the gym start with warmup and stretching of the muscles then perform strength training for 90 min and then if you have some stamina do 10–15 min sprinting as it will increase the rate of fat burned because after doing exercise your body will be depleted from energy and of course diet and sleep play a major role in all of it.

title: Is it good to do weightlifting every day?
article:
In 1999, I was a rookie with the Detroit Tigers. After a game, I strode confidently into the Kansas City Royals’ weight room, rested the weight bar on my shoulders and settled in for some heavy squats.  I rocked my hips back and dropped into my form, feeling totally in control. On the way back up, I got stuck. I leaned forward and the bar spilled over my neck. More than 500 pounds went violently crashing to the floor and members of both teams turned to look.
 
Luckily, nothing was injured that day other than my pride.  It could have been much worse.  I was over-trained; I had an intense weight tr
Continue Reading
In 1999, I was a rookie with the Detroit Tigers. After a game, I strode confidently into the Kansas City Royals’ weight room, rested the weight bar on my shoulders and settled in for some heavy squats.  I rocked my hips back and dropped into my form, feeling totally in control. On the way back up, I got stuck. I leaned forward and the bar spilled over my neck. More than 500 pounds went violently crashing to the floor and members of both teams turned to look.
 
Luckily, nothing was injured that day other than my pride.  It could have been much worse.  I was over-trained; I had an intense weight training session the day before and was just coming off playing nine innings.  “More is better” was my mantra, but I was naïve.
 
At 23, I lifted heavy weights every day. Now, I lift three days a week. I’m not quite as strong, but I’m inching closer to that 500 pound threshold now that I understand the importance of rest and recovery.  If I understood how the body repairs itself when I was a rookie, I would have been stronger, healthier, and a better baseball player.
 
It’s essential to incorporate recovery days into your program so your muscles can adequately repair themselves, grow and become stronger. When we train with weights, we actually create small tears in our muscle fibers. Those fibers then repair and rebuild bigger and stronger while we rest.  If you don’t build in that downtime, you break the muscle fibers down further reducing the chance for solid growth and increasing the risk of injury.
 
If your ultimate goal is size and strength, avoid weight training, even targeting separate muscle groups, on consecutive days.
 
Your body only builds muscle when you are not weight training.  Trust the process, believe in the value of rest, and you’ll be significantly stronger as a result.

Every country I have gone to and lived in has had ignorant people, not just United States. Since you asked however, I will tell you.
 
I moved to the US when I was 11.
 
I was asked if my parents were affiliated with the Taliban by my middle school class mates. They would open their eyes wide open and act like they were terrified when they found out I'm middle Eastern.
 
I was called a terrorist. Referred to as “that terrorist”.
 
Asked if my parents make bombs at home or if my parents plan to kill people.
 
Stared down by most, including some teachers especially on September 11th of every year.
 
One high school teacher asked me if the country where I am from is where they don't allow women to have orgasm and cut their clitoris and if I was subjected to the mutilation (I am obviously middle Eastern, and he was talking about an African country so No. I was not subjected to any mutilation.) He was actually an open minded teacher and I don't think he was trying to come across as ignorant but he did.
 
A lot of people don't realize that when you migrate to the United States, 99% of people want a better life. They are usually escaping from something that is destroying the quality of their life. Middle Eastern run from extremists as well as poverty and lack of choices. Mexican are running from poverty, gang violence, and much more. Syrians are running from their OWN government. Everyone wants a better quality of life so they run from a country that no longer allows them to be physically or emotionally comfortable. So accusing them to be terrorists and rapists only makes the situation worse for them and they feel unaccepted in a new country that they were hoping would provide them new opportunities; where they won't feel threatened by the environment around them.
 
It's sad. It lets you down. Immigrants are grateful for this nation more than its own natural citizens. We come here and we work HARD. We become entrepreneurs, encourage our children to do better in school because not all of us had the opportunity to go to school, we pay taxes and help this country's economy. No one is more grateful for this nation than the immigrants because we know what this country means to us. We have lived in hell before. If I think United States is paradise, then why would I want anyone to threaten my paradise?
 
I have met ignorant people through out my life each more ignorant than the other. I also meet people that welcome me and are grateful for my presence as I am for theirs. They understand the struggle my family and I have gone through.
 
I am proud to say that my parents has built a beautiful life for themselves. We never were offered government assistance and we never asked for it either. I had to get FAFSA for school and it was not a grant it was a loan. We never have lived under welfare. It took us 13 years to finally get a visa to move here. We didn't magically get invited. My family was thoroughly wetted. Inspectors surprise visited our home for an inspection multiple times. Paper work over paperwork and interview over interview. Questions like these were asked: Why did we want to come to the US?, What are our intentions?, How were we going to support ourselves?, Why didn't we want to stay where we were? What did we have to offer the United States?, And hours worth of more questions.
 
If we didn't want to better our lives, we would have not gone through the struggle that it took to get here. In no way do I or my family intends to harm the US or it's people. Yet people choose to not understand that. It's easier to say that we are harmful and threatening than to understand that we just want to LIVE.
 
I guess I experienced more ignorance in school than outside of school because kids aren't afraid to express themselves and what they hear from their parents.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
I have been training seven days a week for the last three years.
 
My split is this:
 
Monday: Legs
 
Tuesday: Chest/Back
 
Wednesday: Shoulders/arms
 
Thursday: Legs
 
Friday: Chest
 
Saturday: Back
 
Sunday: Shoulders/Arms.
 
For me, I genuinely enjoy training and my workouts are medium intensity for about an hour to an hour and a half each day. I take in roughly 3,000 calories per day and get 8 hours of sleep. The split that I use gives my muscles enough time to recover between workouts. When I start to feel a little bit of generalized fatigue and weakness (signs of over training) I just take a day off without changi
Continue Reading
I have been training seven days a week for the last three years.
 
My split is this:
 
Monday: Legs
 
Tuesday: Chest/Back
 
Wednesday: Shoulders/arms
 
Thursday: Legs
 
Friday: Chest
 
Saturday: Back
 
Sunday: Shoulders/Arms.
 
For me, I genuinely enjoy training and my workouts are medium intensity for about an hour to an hour and a half each day. I take in roughly 3,000 calories per day and get 8 hours of sleep. The split that I use gives my muscles enough time to recover between workouts. When I start to feel a little bit of generalized fatigue and weakness (signs of over training) I just take a day off without changing anything in my diet.
 
The VAST majority of the time that you hear people talk about over training, they aren’t really describing over training, they’re just describing being weak willed. Genuine over training IS a thing but it’s hard to get there unless you work out like a fiend and don’t eat/sleep enough.
 
That said, not everybody has the same goals or even the desire to be in the gym as much as me. This is totally understandable. So if you WANT to go to the gym seven days a week, go for it…get a split that makes sense and make sure you eat/sleep enough.
 
I also highly recommend a joint supplement if you’re going to train this much. I train with something called Texas Method where I alternate heavy weight days with hypertrophy (8–12 reps) days. A joint supplement is helpful to ward off some of the inflammation that comes naturally with weight lifting

It was the CEO of a company I worked for some years back. He was the rude side of ignorant At a sales kick-off in Vegas, I passed him in the corridor at the hotel and bid him “Good Morning”. He just ignored me.
 
He came over to the UK a year or two later to speak at a big company conference my boss and I had organised at a lovely, unique venue in Central London. It was my job when he arrived to escort him to the conference theatre. I was nervous, this was the big boss.
 
As we walked up a very grand set of stairs I asked him what he thought of the venue. His gruff response was “I don’t know, I just got here”. I pushed him further saying “look at the ceiling, isn’t it beautiful?” Completely cut me dead. He was very clinical, he hadn’t even said hello when we were introduced.
 
Heard similar stories from colleagues. He didn’t have an ounce of spatial awareness. He’s still the CEO many years later, but when you look at Glassdoor he’s got a negative approval rating. You don’t have to be nice to run an organisation.
 
Thankfully I’ve had the pleasure of working for some very personable CEOs at other companies that have been engaging and appreciative of their employees.
 
[Edited to correct a bit of grammar]
