title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I didn’t technically meet this person, but I was on the New York Subway when I heard a guy behind me have this epiphany.
 
‘So when people talk about growing up, they’ll say, like, they grew up in the 60s or the 70s or something. But we grew up in the 80s AND the 90s. So we can’t say that. I mean, what are we gonna tell them, Janet? What are we gonna tell them?’
 
It was a dizzying trip to New York, with lots of memorable moments. But this one is pretty standout.
 
‘What are we gonna tell them, Janet? What are we gonna tell them
?’

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
Picture this
. It’s July. I was randomly scrolling online when I found out that a 10km run was happening in December. I had thought for a while that running was a cool thing to do but hadn’t ever really tried, so I got my parents to sign me up.
 
Only problem is, 
I hate running
. Like seriously despise it. It’s boring, painful, and completely pointless. I thought that by signing up I’ll be forced to go and practice, but I was completely wrong.
 
Slowly, day by day, the run came closer and closer, and yet, other than a couple of runs here and there I still couldn’t get myself out to run. Finally, t
he d
Continue Reading
Picture this
. It’s July. I was randomly scrolling online when I found out that a 10km run was happening in December. I had thought for a while that running was a cool thing to do but hadn’t ever really tried, so I got my parents to sign me up.
 
Only problem is, 
I hate running
. Like seriously despise it. It’s boring, painful, and completely pointless. I thought that by signing up I’ll be forced to go and practice, but I was completely wrong.
 
Slowly, day by day, the run came closer and closer, and yet, other than a couple of runs here and there I still couldn’t get myself out to run. Finally, t
he day of the run arrived, and I still had never run 10km in my life before.
 
So there I was, at the start line, for an activity I don’t like and was completely unprepared for.
 
The run was tiring, but not too bad. I stopped only twice. At the beginning of the run, I was disgruntled and annoyed that I had ever signed myself up. By a quarter of the way through, I had accepted my fate. And by halfway, I was enjoying it. I ended up finishing the first 10km run in my life in less than one hour.
 
After the run was over, I realised that 
running isn’t so bad after all. It’s the mental barrier that gives the biggest block.
 
Since that day, I’ve been running 4–5 times a week.
 
You can easily search up the scientific benefits of running, but here’s what I can tell you from personal experience:
 
When I run, I get the best ideas
 
It’s a great, almost meditative escape from today’s constant notifications and distractions
 
After running, I feel great, awake, and energised, not to mention focused
 
It’s an activity that you begin to enjoy that you can feel proud of, unlike things like gaming/watching TV
 
So if you’re wondering whether to take the plunge and start running, I’d give a resounding YES, because it’s one of the best activities I’ve started in a long time.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
If you only have access to your own body weight, you can still get a great decent workout routine. I recommend you try this 5 day workout routine: 
 
Day 1: Upper Body Strength Focused Training using pushup variations, pullup variations, lower back exercises, and tricep dip variations. Try this complete upper body strength focused workout to get you started: 
Day 2: Lower Body Strength Focused Training using glute bridges, donkey kicks, lunges, and other body weight exercises to tone up your lower body. You can try this complete lower body workout to get you started:

If you only have access to your own body weight, you can still get a great decent workout routine. I recommend you try this 5 day workout routine: 
 
Day 1: Upper Body Strength Focused Training using pushup variations, pullup variations, lower back exercises, and tricep dip variations. Try this complete upper body strength focused workout to get you started: 
Day 2: Lower Body Strength Focused Training using glute bridges, donkey kicks, lunges, and other body weight exercises to tone up your lower body. You can try this complete lower body workout to get you started:
Day 3: Full Body Core Focused Cardio where you can use burpees, body weight squats, and other core focused full body exercises to work on your core strength and also train your cardio. Try this 20 min body weight only core workout to get you started:
Day 4: back to day 1 to train your upper body 
 
Day 5: back to day 2 to train your lower body 
 
Day 6 and 7: active rest days where you can do light cardio such as walking, hiking, playing tennis, foam rolling for recovery, or gentle yoga for flexibility training. You can try this beginner 10 min yoga routine on weekends:
With the basic workout routine format and some suggested workouts to get you started you should be able to get fit in just 1 month.
 
Hopefully this helps :-)

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My Scottish friends, a married couple, moved over from the UK to USA. One day they were talking to a waiter at a restaurant.
 
The waiter asked them eventually: “How long have you lived in USA?”
 
They answered: “Three months.”
 
The waiter: “Wow! Your English is really good!”
 
Yet I must say I met ignorant people in every country of the world I ever visited. And most likely I can be found completely ignorant by someone coming from a different culture and different reality. E.g. I can drive on snow without any problem, but I had to learn at the age of almost 50 how to prepare the house for a hurricane.

My Scottish friends, a married couple, moved over from the UK to USA. One day they were talking to a waiter at a restaurant.
 
The waiter asked them eventually: “How long have you lived in USA?”
 
They answered: “Three months.”
 
The waiter: “Wow! Your English is really good!”
 
Yet I must say I met ignorant people in every country of the world I ever visited. And most likely I can be found completely ignorant by someone coming from a different culture and different reality. E.g. I can drive on snow without any problem, but I had to learn at the age of almost 50 how to prepare the house for a hurricane.
 
Therefore, I suggest that we judge the situations (because they are funny, or pathetic, or whatever they seem to be), but not the people. Because if we were born the other person and brought up in the same way, we would be equally ignorant.

Hi, I am a certified personal trainer and here are my two cents on this :-
 
Honestly there are a ton of programs online which will suit your purpose, just Google “
bodyweight exercises for home workouts
” or something along those lines and you'll be good
.
 
However what I've noticed is that the general population tends to miss out on the essential parts of a well structured workout routine for example :-
 
1.) Mobility Drills and Stretching to achieve and increase R. O. K for movements and to minimize the risk of injuries
 
2.)Correct execution of the form which when done improperly, can either cause unnecessary aches and pains or injure you
 
(Ex: - back rounding in squats, heels rising up, Having a anterior/posterior tilt in your hips due to tight surrounding muscles)
 
Hence I would recommend virtual online training which fits your budget from reputable sources... It's not 100% compulsory, but think of it this way -
 
if you are willing to give 1–2 hours a day to your body, wouldn't you want it to function optimally and give it the proper care it needs rather than teaching it improper movement patterns and risking 100% avoidable harm?
 
For those interested in some high quality virtual training at a budget friendly price (9.99£) check out 
FIT live 
and sign using my link to get access to the daily live workouts I perform (teaching everything from scratch) :-
 
Fit.live/arya

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
Working out every day can have both positive and negative effects on your body, depending on various factors such as the intensity and duration of your workouts, your overall fitness level, and your body's ability to recover. Regular exercise can lead to improvements in cardiovascular fitness, muscular strength, and endurance. When you work out consistently, your body adapts to the demands placed on it and becomes more efficient at performing physical tasks. Engaging in daily workouts can also contribute to weight loss or weight maintenance, depending on your goals.
 
Exercise has been shown to h
Continue Reading
Working out every day can have both positive and negative effects on your body, depending on various factors such as the intensity and duration of your workouts, your overall fitness level, and your body's ability to recover. Regular exercise can lead to improvements in cardiovascular fitness, muscular strength, and endurance. When you work out consistently, your body adapts to the demands placed on it and becomes more efficient at performing physical tasks. Engaging in daily workouts can also contribute to weight loss or weight maintenance, depending on your goals.
 
Exercise has been shown to have positive effects on mental health. Regular physical activity can reduce stress, improve mood, boost self-confidence, and alleviate symptoms of depression and anxiety. Consistent exercise can also improve your overall energy levels and stamina. Over time, your body becomes accustomed to physical exertion, and you may find that you have more energy throughout the day.
 
It's important to listen to your body, vary your workouts, and prioritize rest and recovery days to avoid overexertion and maintain a healthy balance. Consulting with a fitness professional or personal trainer can help you develop a safe and effective workout plan based on your goals and fitness level.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
Beginners as well as more advanced fitness levels will see the biggest benefits if they work out three to four times a week. The main thing is that you schedule a rest day between the different sessions. You should take at least one day off after two consecutive days of strength training.

Ignorant is not an American only problem, when I lived in Greece, I met ignorant people from all over the world that came there on vacation. The Greeks though, are pretty well informed about most things.
 
Ignorant is not the same as stupid, stupid is also not an American only problem.
 
I did know a young US Navy Sailor, female, who sat down next to me at the base club. She asked me if I had heard the news, I said” that you were pregnant”, she said “yes”. My response was “yes I had heard that”, she responded “I don’t know how it happened” I responded “well, were you having sex” she said “yes, of course” I asked if she was” using birth control” she said “no whats that” I said “well, that’s how it starts”. she looked at me with a blank stare, so I explained to her how having sex leads to pregnancy…clueless, she had no idea the two were linked.
 
I have met others, more than one Brit, who were unaware that Germany had bombed London and other British Cities, during WW2, which she had also never heard of.
 
I met an Australian who thought black folks in America had tails.
 
I also met another Brit that had no idea that the meat purchased in a store belonged to a living animal recently and that that animal had to be killed to obtain it. She thought it was just something that the store made.
 
I could go on, 22 years in the military, and you see it all.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: I worked with an English guy at a job I once had. He got tired of people asking him where he was from, a town called Guildford nobody in America had heard of, and just started saying England instead. A girl once asked him if London was near England. She was definitely not the brightest bulb, but she knew how to get what she wanted. If she didn't feel like working, she would throw up the minute she got to work so she would be sent home. We called her Barf Girl.

Back in the day of film in cameras we were in Jamaica. We took a tour bus to Dunns River Falls.
 
On the bus was the the bus best example of “Ugly Amtherican” I have ever seen. Loud and calling down every country. He was even fat and was wearing ugly shorts. Telling us all that we better do as Uncle Sam says if we know what is good for us.
 
At the falls the bus dropped us off and went to bus parking. As soon as we got in the compound, asshole noticed that his camera only had one picture and he left his extra film in the bus. No film for sale inside the falls either at that time.
 
He noticed my camera strap had several film canisters on it. It also has red maple leafs on it. Hecasked if I had fresh rolls of film. Truthfully I said yes.
 
He demanded, not asked, that I give him a roll of film.
 
“Nope” I said. To make the story shorter, he whined, demanded, pleaded and threatened for film.
 
“Nope, I do not help assholes. Get some from Uncle Sam.”
 
This exchange was witnessed by several others from the bus. No one, even other Americans gave him film.
 
While at the falls, about half the bus came up to me and thanked me for taking a stand. Some said they too refused to loan him film because of my example.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
Something that works really well in your situation, is what I dubbed the “prison cell workout”
 
You literally need no equiptment other than a sturdy towell.
 
But what you do need, however, is a ton of cojones or ovaires (This is NOT for the casual “I just want to get in shape” dabbler…this is for people who are serious about making progress).
 
This type of workout looks really easy on paper, but will smoke even very strong people.

Something that works really well in your situation, is what I dubbed the “prison cell workout”
 
You literally need no equiptment other than a sturdy towell.
 
But what you do need, however, is a ton of cojones or ovaires (This is NOT for the casual “I just want to get in shape” dabbler…this is for people who are serious about making progress).
 
This type of workout looks really easy on paper, but will smoke even very strong people.
 
I still use this once or twice a week to increase my work capactiy and pain threshold.
 
If you can get through this type of routine 3–5 times a week, there’s literally nothing that can stop you.
 
This is not only a workout for your physical body, but also for your mental and spiritual muscles.
 
Big words, I know, but try it and you’ll know what I’m talking about.
 
Here goes…
 
Get your smartphone. Or use your watch to stop the time (you’ll try to beat the time you recorded).
 
As soon as you hit “start” and the clock is ticking, you’ll perform 200 push-ups, 250 squats and 100 towell pullups as fast as possible (with excellent form, obviously).
 
Of course you shouldn’t bang out all 200 push-ups, 250 squats and 100 pullups all in one set!
 
Divide the work up, so that you DON’T go to muscular failure on each and every set! That’s really important, or else you’ll burn out.
 
What I do, for example, is that I do sets of 20 on push-up (so 10 sets per “round”), 25–50 reps on squats, 5–10 reps on pullups.
 
Find a set and rep scheme that works for you. Again, you SHOULD NOT go to muscular failure in each and ever set. Keep 2–3 reps in the tank.
 
With that said, the key do these type of workouts, is to rest as little as possible (remember you’re doing this for time).
 
I always hit a set of push-ups, immediately followed by a set of squats and then, without rest, I bang out my pullups. Then I’ll rest for 45–60sec. Only to start the next set.
 
Trust me, your heart rate will jack the heck up on this routine!
 
You don’t have to run any additional cardio with this and you’ll develop a very “functional” type of strength endurance if you stick to it.
 
Oh, and you’ll also build some lean muscle! Especially if you haven’t used these type of “prison cell workouts” in the past.
 
But make no mistake…This is not for the faint of heart.
 
If you need help with this routine, then shoot me a DM or comment down below!
 
All the best and I’m rooting for you,
 
Mattis Rogers

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Strangely enough, I met several ignorant people in my first year of college, or just happened to hear a lot of questions that suggested ignorance. Here’s what I remember, in chronological order -
 
“Where in Europe is Singapore?”
 
“Coke and Pepsi are owned by the same person, aren’t they?”
 
“Alcohol is most definitely a stimulant.”
 
I’m sure there was more, but I just can’t remember right now. I met more than one person who thought the holiday Boxing Day had something to do with the sport, but given that it is not an American holiday, I can’t consider that to be ignorance on the same level.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

The most ignorant person in America is my nephew. Not only he is very ignorant, but it also cost me $1000 to find out how ignorant he is.
 
But first, let me introduce you to my nephew and I:
The one standing is your truly, and the one down is my nephew. The picture is not really correct, but it gives you a general idea how I want to do with him
 
Now, once when he was in college, I gave him $1000 for him to spend a summer vacation with his best buddies in their homeland in South Korea
 
One or two years later, he graduated, and during graduation week, he sent me an email with some urgent note to tell me to make sure I watched my local TV at certain time
 
So that time came, and I watched, and on the screen, there was a young TV reporter in my nephew’s campus, talking about how ignorant American students can be when it is about geography; then she rolled out a big world map and asked the audience if someone could correctly pick out the country of South Korea from the map …
 
Then the very first person volunteered for that question was my nephew. Dancing and grinning from ear to ear, he went to the map and pointed to …. Japan! Much to my horror!!
 
But on the screen, I saw his (S Korean?) friends laughing, and I overheard one of them said to my nephew “… and all that free food my Mum gave you in Seoul..”
 
A few days later when I caught up with him, I asked him what Mickey Mouse stuff he tried to pull on TV, and he said:” But uncle! But had I given the correct answer, I wouldn’t be on TV, would I?”
 
The point is, many students in that screen knew it was a joke, but the reporter didn’t, or that she knew, but she was playing along for good sport, and that was how I saw my $1000 wasting away in Seoul. [Grrrr
r..]

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
There is no one right answer to exercising regularly. That’s good news, because it allows you to create a workout plan that works best for you, even if your workouts look different. A healthy, safe weekly exercise program can come in many different ways. How often you should exercise depends on your fitness goals, where you start exercising, and how much time suits your body.
There are general guidelines for how much exercise a healthy adult should get each week. However, how you obtain these quantities may vary. Also, if your fitness goals are higher than your general fitness level, you shoul
Continue Reading
There is no one right answer to exercising regularly. That’s good news, because it allows you to create a workout plan that works best for you, even if your workouts look different. A healthy, safe weekly exercise program can come in many different ways. How often you should exercise depends on your fitness goals, where you start exercising, and how much time suits your body.
There are general guidelines for how much exercise a healthy adult should get each week. However, how you obtain these quantities may vary. Also, if your fitness goals are higher than your general fitness level, you should probably exercise more often than is generally recommended. Before starting any exercise routine, it is advisable to consult with your healthcare team, especially if you already know risk factors for heart disease.
 
Weekly exercise recommendations
For most people, the foundation of any exercise program should come from the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) general exercise guidelines.
Get at least 2.5 hours of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week. You can also do moderate and vigorous cardio at the same time.
Resistance exercises (lifting or bodyweight exercises) should target major muscle groups 2-3 times a week.
Flexibility training should be done 2-3 times a week to improve range of motion.
Neuromotor exercise (functional fitness) should be performed 2-3 days a week. Examples include balance, agility, coordination and gait exercises.
How you meet (or exceed) these guidelines is up to you. It’s probably easiest to split your workouts into cardio, 2-3 times a week for flexibility/neuromotor/strengthening 2-3 days a week. You should also include at least one day off each week in your exercise program.
 
Where do you start?
How often you should exercise depends on where you start exercising. Are you new to exercising? It’s best to ask your healthcare team where you should start exercising. In general, exercising 2-3 times a week can be a good start. Once this is possible, you can add more exercise each week. Remember, your main goal is to do any exercise you can, and it’s better than nothing.
Don’t be discouraged if you don’t start your exercise program with the recommended amount of exercise. Any exercise is good for health. If you have a specific fitness goal, your weekly workouts may look different. For example, if you’re training for an endurance event, you’ll be doing more cardio than the ACSM recommends. If you’re trying to increase your strength specifically, your focus on strength training may be greater, possibly over half the guidelines.
 
Do strength training 2-3 times a week
Whatever your fitness goals, you should incorporate strength training into your workouts. Strength training should include a wide variety of exercises and equipment targeting all major muscle groups. In general, it is recommended to perform 2-4 sets of movements per muscle group with 8-12 repetitions.
Older adults or those just starting out should do lower-intensity workouts with sets of 10-15 repetitions. A common misconception about strength training is that you need a gym membership. You can do many strength training exercises with your body weight anywhere. For example, push-ups, squats, sit-ups, and sit-ups are all examples of strength exercises that you can do anywhere.
 
How much cardio should you do?
The ACSM guidelines of 2.5 hours of moderate exercise per week can be broken down in different ways:
5 days a week, 30 minutes each time (can be completed in 10 minutes)
3 days a week, 60 minutes each time (30 minutes above the guideline)
Combination of moderate to high intensity exercise
Depending on your goals and your starting point, you need to do how much cardio and what types of exercise. Examples of moderate exercise include: walking, jogging, dancing, gardening, football, etc. Moderate exercise can be sustained without leaving you out of breath. The heart rate increases, but this rate can be maintained for a while.
 
How Much Flexibility and Stretching Should You Do?
Exercise recommendations tend to focus on strength training and cardio. However, flexibility and neuromotor exercises should not be forgotten. Flexibility and neuromotor training can easily be combined before or after strength training or cardio.
For example: stretching before and after exercise, dynamic warm-ups, yoga, Pilates and balance exercises. Muscles should be warm before doing stretches. Hold the stretch for 10-30 seconds and repeat 2-4 times.
 
Follow us:
https://lifebuddy.siterubix.com/

I once met an American on a shopping mall in El Paso, Texas. I was 11 years old and dressed normally. Normal GAP sweater and jeans with a pair of Nike.
 
I was waiting for my friend sitting on a bench outside of a shop. Then a family walk by. The lady(definitely mother) tell her kid “look, this is what kids look like in China. They normally can't get out of their country. So is very rare to see”(something like that, I can remember the exact word)
 
I was like “WTF”? Of course I didn't say it out loud since I'm only 11. So I just sit there and let those friendly family smile at me like I'm some sort of circus animal. Then the lady gave a dollar and pointed at my clothes. And did a few gesture which I assume she was trying to tell me that I didn't wear the right “costume” and that dollar was the tip for sitting there and let them “observe” me queitely. She didn't even bother to try to speak English with me……
 
To be honest, I feel I'm like the first Panda they have ever seen. Except I'm a human. Man… I know there were not many asians in El Paso, but seriously? A Chinese boy in a shopping mall is really that rare? And wtf is “Chinese normally can't get out of the country?” You can say they rarely come to Texas, but out of country? Really? They can't?
 
LOL, but I was too young to think about that. Also I was pretty happy to get a dollar from a total stranger while have no idea how to describe wtf was that.

This wasn't so much a failure of the person, but more importantly I think our education system.
 
Was traveling in the car with the ex-wife, her 10 year old daughter, and my 7 year old son. I have no idea how it first came up, but the conversation went something like this.
 
Me: yeah, it's crazy to think that all those stars we see at night are Suns that could have planets just like Earth orbiting them. It's silly to think we're the only life in the universe.
 
Ex: Stars aren't Suns, there's only one sun. Ours is the only sun there is!
 
Ex's daughter: yeah, there's only one sun….
 
Me: errrr… (me and my son look at each other kind of lost for a few moments) you know our sun is a star…. Right????
 
Ex: no it's not! It's a sun!!!
 
Me: ummmm… what do you think stars are?
 
Ex: They’re rocks!
 
Ex's daughter: yeah, they’re rocks!
 
Once again me and my son just look at each other blankly for a moment.
 
Me: Rocks? Why would you think they were rocks???
 
Ex:. Because when they fall, they're rocks!!! I've seen them!
 
Me: you mean shooting stars???
 
Ex: Yeah!!
 
Ex's daughter: exactly!
 
Anyway, I questioned them a bit after that. It came down to the sun is big, stars are small. They thought they were little lights cause the sun was reflecting off of them….
 
So I explained meteorites, and stars, and Suns. They finally got it, but they really had never known!
 
She was 32 at the time…..
 
She wasn't a dumb person, she was really pretty smart most of the time. But she and her daughter both had taken shooting stars literally, and never questioned it deeper. Science wasn't her thing, but still…. Education fail!!!!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My wife and I were living in Rome. One day, we took a day trip to Florence. It was a pretty straightforward goal: take a train, get off the train, walk around, have a nice meal and a glass or two of wine, and return home.
 
Florence really makes the best of a bad scenario. The bad scenario is that its central district is completely overrun by tourists. But despite hearing far more English than Italian, it’s still possible to get a little bit of a feel for Florentine culture and history.
 
Everything was going according to the plan. We had randomly chosen a restaurant, and had enjoyed a nice meal. I 
Continue Reading
My wife and I were living in Rome. One day, we took a day trip to Florence. It was a pretty straightforward goal: take a train, get off the train, walk around, have a nice meal and a glass or two of wine, and return home.
 
Florence really makes the best of a bad scenario. The bad scenario is that its central district is completely overrun by tourists. But despite hearing far more English than Italian, it’s still possible to get a little bit of a feel for Florentine culture and history.
 
Everything was going according to the plan. We had randomly chosen a restaurant, and had enjoyed a nice meal. I went to the restroom to… make room for more wine.
 
This restaurant had one door to both men’s and women’s bathrooms, then obviously individual doors for each gender beyond that. (I can’t remember why this made sense, but it did. Maybe there was only one sink in the “antechamber” for both bathrooms?) The exterior door was labelled “bagni” (“bathrooms”) and the interior doors were labeled “donna” and “uomo.” I won’t translate those two exotic terms, for reasons that will be soon be evident. But for now, pause for just a moment and take a guess… a wild conjecture… as to what those two terms mean.
 
I’ll give you a hint. At the moment I was heading to the bathroom, there was a woman who stood in apparent paralysis inside the “bagni” door, but outside the “uomo” and “donna” doors. A man then emerged from the “uomo” door. The woman remained, utterly confused. She wondered aloud, “which door do I use?”, not necessarily talking 
to
 me, but perhaps hoping I could help.
 
I did. I directed her to the “donna” door. I can only assume she found the relief she was looking for, as did I inside the “uomo” door.
 
I came back to my seat and relayed all this to my wife. She was as perplexed as I was, how someone could get so far — to plan a trip to Italy, to get on a plane, to make it from some airport or another all the way to the center of Florence — without somehow picking up a 
little
 vocabulary. And even if she literally just woke up magically transported from her home in ‘merica to this restaurant, how she couldn’t put it together that a 
man
 
walked out of one of the doors
.
 
As I wrapped up my brief narrative, I saw her emerge from the bathroom and take her seat. Turned out, that seat was right next to us. She then explained, exasperated, the intricate system at play in the restroom to her traveling companion, who I can only assume was her husband. I don’t remember all of what followed, but for the first time I was really embarrassed to be an American. The depth of their collective ignorance was really quite staggering.

I didn't meet ignorant Americans, I must admit. In the US, I met, say, rather stubborn people with their minds made up about something they never experienced themselves, having only read about it in books, and who would be relentless in holding on their particular opinion. But that is not contingent upon nationality - one can meet people like this everywhere. Surprisingly, these people were either academics or educated people, and never “blue collars” - well, that thing they call "Ivory Tower” is called so for a reason. I am Russian from Russia, born and raised, and when they asked me about Russia and I would answer they would be trying to prove me wrong because they had read some obscure book on the topic or watched the news regularly.
 
Also, well-traveled Americans maybe somewhat more likely to make biased assumptions, since they have been to other countries they tend to think they are knowledgeable about the world. For example, a person who was an avid traveler and who also visited Russia asked me at a reception if I knew what a watermelon was when I reached for a fruit salad plate.

When I was 18 I got my first car and a couple buddies and I drove down to Florida from Quebec for March break partying.
 
So we’re at the beach one day and I started chatting up a really cute girl who had a Southern drawl that mesmerized me. After a few minutes this hillbilly looking dude walked up to us giving me the stink eye. The cutie said “This is my husband Harold.” Oh.
 
We all talked for a bit and I learned they were from Tennessee. When Harold heard I was from Canada he wanted to know about the snow and ice houses we had ‘up there’. “What are they called?” he asked. I said “You mean igloos?” He said no, it’s something else. I said that they were called igloos but he kept insisting there was another word for them. I remember saying that I did not live in one but a few of my neighbors did. The conversation never did get any smarter and I never forgot it.

Full body workouts are brilliant for the body. Nothing makes the body stronger than full body exercises. Having done both isolation exercises and full body, a huge thumbs up for your choice of exercise. 
 
But, the body needs to recovery time as well to repair the stress and strain done on the muscles and joints. The recovery part along with diet is what actually makes you stronger.

LISTEN TO YOUR BODY
 . Within a short span of time, you'll know when to take it light and when to go full steam ahead. 
 
Have a great path to fitness.

To get the most out of exercise, it is important to create an exercise routine that includes a variety of different exercises.
 
1. Set a realistic goal- Start with a small achievable goal and work your way up. For example, if you are new to exercise. Aim to walk for 20 min a day, three days a week then gradually increase the intensity and frequency.
 
2. Find an activity you enjoy - The more you enjoy the routine, the more chances are you will stick to the routine the for long term. For example, if you love dancing, try a dance fitness class or go for a hike or bike ride
 
3. Make it a habit - Try to exercise at the same time every day, so that it becomes a habit. This could be first thing in the morning, during your lunch break, or in the evening after work.

Yes we have some crazy, stupid people in America as does every other country that I have visited in my travels. However, I don’t feel compelled to get on Quora on a daily basis and insult those countries as do hundreds of the Quora readers who apparently enjoy doing so with my country. In view of the fact that the US has had complete dominance in the Science and Economic Nobel Prizes awarded in the past seventy years with hundreds of thousands of foreign students flocking to our universities (along with the tens of thousands of doctors and scientists waiting years to get into the US as permanent residents/citizens) , I would submit that these quaint yokel encounters are not entirely representative of the intellectual climate in the US. If they are based on jealousy and resentment ( an inability to secure a visa to a country that you purportedly despise), then that is your misfortune. In any case, the editors/web meisters of Quora should not be providing a forum for such poisonous, small minds (as I have pointed out on an annual basis). It is such bad form…and pathetic.

Hence I would like to conclude by saying that a person can be extremely fit by working out at home provided that your determination is unsahakable.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
The pros are - you can train your entire body in one session. Even while doing only three sessions in a week, you hit each muscle thrice. So the frequency is on the higher side and we know that higher frequency leads to more gains. It is beneficial for people who cannot come to the gym often. This type of training is also beneficial for someone whose main goal is to build strength. The cons are- it takes a lot of time to complete the session. Also training this longer leads to central nervous system fatigue, which affects the intensity of training and intensity is one of the major contributors
Continue Reading
The pros are - you can train your entire body in one session. Even while doing only three sessions in a week, you hit each muscle thrice. So the frequency is on the higher side and we know that higher frequency leads to more gains. It is beneficial for people who cannot come to the gym often. This type of training is also beneficial for someone whose main goal is to build strength. The cons are- it takes a lot of time to complete the session. Also training this longer leads to central nervous system fatigue, which affects the intensity of training and intensity is one of the major contributors to hypertrophy. Also training muscle groups like triceps with the same intensity after doing bench press is difficult because intensity is compromised due to the onset of peripheral fatigue at this point. So, my advice to you- follow full body workouts only in cases you want to build foundational strength as in beginners. A full body workout for an intermediate is inferior in terms of hypertrophy.

I think ..…Yes, there are many people who are not so rich using Quora.
 
When I was in 7th or 8th class, my sisters used to clean house thorougly before festivals and when they were changing the papers of shelves (
in rural areas a sheet of newspaper used to put in shelves in place of any coloured or costly sheet, also our parents was not in possession to afford any plastic paint or distemper as my father, a cleark and mother, a housewife were taking care of 7 members of family
), I find an article in which it was described that how Internet is useful for study.
 
I was fond of reading.I also used to read the old(waste) and newly arrived (outdated ) newspapers those days (
also my father couldn't afford Rs. 60–70 per month for daily newspaper)
.
 
In 2011 with the help of my friends I came to know about Internet and opened my Google account. My friends taught me how to use Facebook, Nimbuzz and YouTube.
 
I requested my mother to make my father purchase a
n
 Internet enabled phone. My mother asked about the cost of the same. I told 2–3 thousand for basic keypad and 4–5 thousand for screen touch phone. Firstly my mother refused to help me. But later when I told her that all my friends having internet enabled screen touch phone for study, at least you should talk about basic keypad phone.
 
My mother told the same to my father. After 1–2 week later I again asked my mother. My mother any how gave me 5,000 Rupees. I want to ask my mother..but she scold me …not to ask any question. I didn't purchase any phone and put back that money in my mother's wallet. Next day my mother was asking about my phone, I replied …Nhi mummy, main dosto k phone se hi kaam Chala lunga. Mere admission ke liye Kam aa jayenge wo rupye ( 
No, I can manage with my friend's phone. That money will help me to take admission)
 My mother told …Tu le le..apni cheez apni hoti h..wo kab tak dikhayenge tujhe ( 
You should buy….)
 
Finally I got my Nokia 5233 in June 2011. I tried to search all those things what I want to.. earlier.
 
My father asked me …what have you thought about your next study. I told my father, I want to take admission in B.Tech. Banks are providing Education Loan easily now a days.
 
I took admission in a private college which was near to my home because if I take admission far away from my home. It will be more expensive.
 
Two of my friends also pursuing b.tech in that college. We all three go to college by one old hero motorcycle and expenses were equally divided.
 
I never thought about the expenditures except college fee, I used to suffer economically by stationary, books and assignments expenses. I was consuming half of my family income.
 
I sold my Nokia 5233 which helping me a lot in study especially assignments.
 
Day by day my family’s economic condition going down.
 
I started to teach my neighbor's children to earn some money to bear college expenses. (
Generally many students came to study at my home in vacation but earlier I didn't charge any amount for that… luckily their parents came to request me to spare some of my time to teach their children in lieu of that they offerred me tuetion fee
s)
 
But it affecting my study…also there is a tension in my mind seeing my family condition. One of my elder sister awaiting to get married.
 
I think to quit my study and start submitting some forms for government Job. (
Also there was a rumour that time , future of b.tech 
is 
not secure as there are many students wandering after b.tech
). So I strongly start believing in that.
 
I appeared in many exam for government Job, many of my classmates also doing same. They think a government peon is far better than a unemployed engineer.
 
Finally I got a call letter from (don't want to mention organization’s name). My parents want to stop me to join that service but there is one more problem our paternal house divided in four parts and my father got only 25 square foot of land. It was also a necessity to build that part to live. (
I'm unable to upload pics as I had no camera phone that time)
 
Also my younger brother’s basic education has been totally effected by working in fields as my parents 
has 
grown old ( we have a small piece of agriculture land and some cattles)
 
The sole responsibility to take my family forward was on my shoulder. Seeing no other option I joined that service. Now I am not saying that… I m earning good (what I want) but I am capable to carry all the responsibility of my family. Last year in December my sister got married. My brother completed graduation.
 
You will ask when I joined Quora ?
 
Ans : To check..you can go through my profile. Usually I didn't get enough time to write, But I love to read answers.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article:
That depends on three things:
 
1.) What state your body currently is at
 
2.) What state you’d like to be
 
3.) What you’re willing to do (time, energy, money, etc) to achieve those goals
 
How strong are you? How old are you? What ailments are you currently facing? What sports do you want to play? How strong do you want to be? What’s your body-fat percentage? What do you want to look like?
 
There’s absolutely no ONE BEST WORKOUT. There’s millions of good ways to do it, which is best for you depends on the above three questions.

title: Is a full body workout two or three times a week as effective as a split routine working out 5 or 6 days a week? How do I get the best results possible with the least time invested?
article:
The most effective workout routine for gaining muscle and strength while minimizing fat loss will vary depending on the individual's goals, preferences, and fitness level. However, a common recommendation is to perform a combination of strength training and cardiovascular exercise.
 
For gaining muscle and strength, it is important to prioritize resistance training exercises that target all major muscle groups. This can be achieved through either full-body or split routines.
 
Full-body routines typically involve performing exercises that target multiple muscle groups in each workout session. This c
Continue Reading
The most effective workout routine for gaining muscle and strength while minimizing fat loss will vary depending on the individual's goals, preferences, and fitness level. However, a common recommendation is to perform a combination of strength training and cardiovascular exercise.
 
For gaining muscle and strength, it is important to prioritize resistance training exercises that target all major muscle groups. This can be achieved through either full-body or split routines.
 
Full-body routines typically involve performing exercises that target multiple muscle groups in each workout session. This can be a good option for beginners or those with limited time to workout. Sample full-body workout routines may include exercises such as squats, deadlifts, bench press, rows, and overhead press.
 
Split routines involve dividing workouts into different muscle groups on different days, typically targeting one or two muscle groups per session. This can be a good option for more advanced lifters or those looking to focus on specific muscle groups. Sample split workout routines may include a push/pull/legs split, where push exercises (e.g. chest, shoulders, triceps) are performed on one day, pull exercises (e.g. back, biceps) on another day, and leg exercises on a separate day.
 
In terms of minimizing fat loss, it is important to combine strength training with cardiovascular exercise to create a calorie deficit. Adding in HIIT (high-intensity interval training) or steady-state cardio sessions a few times per week can help to burn additional calories and promote fat loss while maintaining muscle mass.

I recently followed the Mind pump guys on YouTube. Very smart longtime personal trainers and simalar experience as me in my career. I was doing bro split workouts forever and often fighting plateaus for my own progress. Yet I was often doing 2–3 full body workouts for my clients cause it fit best with their schedules and they were having great success with that. Why didn't I apply that to my own program???? Cause I just thought I could and should of been doing 5–6 workouts a week. The mind pump guys shared this also and said they started making a lot of progress themselves when they did 3 full body workouts a week. By hitting each muscle 3 times a week but giving your body more rest overall allows more muscle growth. Also I used to waste a lot of time working on isolation exercises and wasn't doing much the second half of the workouts anyways I still do a little mobility, stretching and walking on off days. I have made a lot of progress and the effort throughout the week is much less. It's crazy! With that being said it's still good to switch it up. I'll do an upper/lower or push/pull/legs split time to time.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Some of the most intelligent people I’ve met are American. I think they’re one of the greatest peoples in the world.
 
But I did meet one 
exceptionally
 foolish gentleman who happened to be American. We were in the Canadian Rockies up in British Columbia which is by far the most beautiful place on the planet.
This photograph gives you only an inkling of this staggering landmass. I’ve never seen so many pine trees in all my life, rolling endlessly like waves on the ocean across barren mountains.
 
I was camping near Golden in the summer months, staying at a campsite with a few other travellers. This wa
Continue Reading
Some of the most intelligent people I’ve met are American. I think they’re one of the greatest peoples in the world.
 
But I did meet one 
exceptionally
 foolish gentleman who happened to be American. We were in the Canadian Rockies up in British Columbia which is by far the most beautiful place on the planet.
This photograph gives you only an inkling of this staggering landmass. I’ve never seen so many pine trees in all my life, rolling endlessly like waves on the ocean across barren mountains.
 
I was camping near Golden in the summer months, staying at a campsite with a few other travellers. This was when I used to do hitchhiking up the Trans-Canada Highway.
In this campsite were a variety of different travellers from across the world. Some were Canadian, a few Australians, there was a German, Spaniard and a couple of Americans.
 
We were isolated. Our campsite was deep in the mountains. I saw black bears and all sorts of other mammals. Everyone was naturally curious about black bears, afraid of being mauled to death but also very eager to get a photograph of them.
 
I remember prepping for hours about how I would react in case a bear approached me, looking for its next meal. I knew how to roll on the ground, stand tall and shout, pop off a firecracker and I read up on how to use bear spray if it came to it.
Now enters one of the most idiotic individuals I have ever met.
 
Let’s call him Captain Know-it-All.
Captain Know-it-All had lectured us for the last two nights around the campfire about how he was a ‘citizen of the world’ (whatever that means) in one of the thickest Californian accents I’ve encountered. He also told us about the wilderness as if he were a pioneer explorer.
 
Captain Know-it-All seemed to have an encyclopaedic knowledge of the outdoors, especially wilderness survival. Yet he was very gaunt and seemed to have only left his daily outing to the coffee shop for the first time on this trip. He was very slim, lanky, tall like a giraffe with long hair and a drawn out face.
 
We were all developing headaches as he tried to impress us. His Romanian girlfriend only encouraged him on, inflating his ego to mountainous proportions.
Around his waist at all times was a tool belt containing every piece of kit you can think, including a small hatchet that was impossible to cut anything with and a strange admixture of blunt instruments except for a sharp hunter’s knife which was far too dangerous for this person to carry.
 
He also had fire starters dangling from the belt, a compass in case he strayed ten metres from his car, and all manners of other rubbish he was never going to use. The only thing this absurd tool belt was going to do was weigh him down when a bear’s stomach grumbled. However, out of all these tools, Captain Know-it-All’s most prized possession was a canister of bear-spray.
I was actually told by an expert wilderness survivalist who lived alone in the Canadian mountains to not carry bear spray with me when hiking. I thought this was counterintuitive, but he explained that many of the people who try to use it have absolutely no idea how to safely discharge a canister.
 
Problems include not only being unable to aim at a fast moving bear charging towards you, but missing the target, not opening it fast enough or misjudging wind direction. You can’t just fire glorified pepper spray into strong winds and 
not
 be throughly coated in eye-burning liquids. This expert judged that those with little experience are more likely to hurt themselves with bear spray than have any successful chance of hurting the bear.
 
The best tips for a black bear encounter are not to run away, but to make yourself big by waving both arms and creating loud noises. This will scare off black bears most of the time rather than blinding yourself with bear spray and potentially aggravating a black bear with the spray.
Now back to Captain Know-it-All.
 
This ‘citizen of the world’ (who was very eager to apologise for being American) was packing his belongings for a day of hiking with his Romanian girlfriend. In the boot of their car, they were arranging everything for the hike as if they were trekking to the Grand Canyon and back.
 
Of course, as they both fiddled with the bear spray, they somehow managed to spray each other in the face and eyes whilst knee deep in the boot of their car.
Safe to say, they didn’t go hiking that day.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My mother.
 
Our family is American. My mother was an alumna of Barnard/Colombia, read voraciously, was deeply and broadly knowledgeable about history, literature, politics, mythology, was an equestrian, spoke three languages, and was a teacher. Not ignorant, with one exception.
 
My father was a chemist, a 100% scientist, amateur astronomer, computer geek, total nerd.
 
One day the conversation turned to overpopulation, one of her political pet peeves. Dad said something about it being a problem because insufficient resources would lead to great suffering. Ma replied that if people did not slow down t
Continue Reading
My mother.
 
Our family is American. My mother was an alumna of Barnard/Colombia, read voraciously, was deeply and broadly knowledgeable about history, literature, politics, mythology, was an equestrian, spoke three languages, and was a teacher. Not ignorant, with one exception.
 
My father was a chemist, a 100% scientist, amateur astronomer, computer geek, total nerd.
 
One day the conversation turned to overpopulation, one of her political pet peeves. Dad said something about it being a problem because insufficient resources would lead to great suffering. Ma replied that if people did not slow down their birth rates, so many babies would accumulate that it would make the Earth so heavy it would crash into the sun.
 
Dad and I laughed; good one, Ma.
 
But she was serious. After a stunned pause, we tried explaining that babies are comprised of materials already on Earth, so a new baby was a rearrangement of existing material, not new mass. We tried every argument we could think of, but her mind was made up. It was astonishing that she could be married to a scientist for 43 years and not understand basic physics, nor that her political beliefs did not overrule scientific laws.
 
People don't believe it when I tell this story, but it's true.

Some anecdotes of sheer ignorance displayed by Americans that I’ve seen myself or have heard from friends. It seems that it mostly has to do with ignorance of the rest of the world and with current affairs.
An American exchange student to the UK asked, ‘can you get into Germany now? I thought there was a big wall around the country.’
A friend, Italian, moved to Columbus, Ohio, and was welcomed by a resident who claimed that the city was ‘founded by Christopher Columbus himself’.
The same friend was told by an economics PhD student that universal healthcare doesn’t work because ‘everywhere that has it is going bankrupt’.
A man who said that he was from New Jersey was greatly offended when my partner told him that she didn’t know exactly where that was. But when she told him that she was from Finland, he asked her whether if that was ‘a country in Asia’.
An American woman who just visited London told me that the city ‘is not really British anymore because there’s literally no white people anywhere’.
A man in Nevada asked me how tall I was. I answered in meters. He didn’t have a clue what I was talking about and proceeded to ask if I’m stupid or not.

title: How to workout
article:
What makes a workout a good workout?
 
When you completed the last rep, or the last lap, or the last submission or whichever sport you train for, how did you feel?
 
Did you feel like a million bucks?
 
Like you have a weight lifted off your shoulders?
 
Does it feel like you tested yourself?
 
Yes?
 
Good.
 
No?
 
Good.
 
Listen…
 
It doesn't matter how you feel, good or bad, motivated or lazy, strong or weak. What matters is that you 
got shit done.
 
You did the workout.
 
Given that you are on a proven program that will elicit changes in body composition and strength. What makes a workout good or even great is doing it.
 
There 
Continue Reading
What makes a workout a good workout?
 
When you completed the last rep, or the last lap, or the last submission or whichever sport you train for, how did you feel?
 
Did you feel like a million bucks?
 
Like you have a weight lifted off your shoulders?
 
Does it feel like you tested yourself?
 
Yes?
 
Good.
 
No?
 
Good.
 
Listen…
 
It doesn't matter how you feel, good or bad, motivated or lazy, strong or weak. What matters is that you 
got shit done.
 
You did the workout.
 
Given that you are on a proven program that will elicit changes in body composition and strength. What makes a workout good or even great is doing it.
 
There are days you 
feel 
like a million bucks. You are excited to step forth and challenge yourself that day.
 
Those are the easy days.
 
Then, there are days you 
feel 
weak. Your sick of the day to day grind. You want to stay in bed.
 
Those days…
 
Those days are the ones that count. Those days are your TEST DAYS.
 
No matter the day, if you can get yourself to the gym and finish your workout, it was a great workout. Even if you just go through the motions.
 
Do it, go through the motions.
 
Those feelings after a workout are great and in many ways that is why we workout. The chemical release feels good, pushing oursleves feels good. Im not trying to downplay those factors.
 
You see the 
feelings
 will come and go. You can't trust them to get you to the gym. You can't trust them to keep you on track.
 
You need to keep yourself on track.
 
That little whisper in your head -
 
“Not today, I could use the rest”
 
“But I have so many other things to do, I can skip today”
 
Shut them down.
 
Feeling lazy? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
Feeling tired? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
Feeling depressed? Too bad, it doesn't get a vote.
 
You have the only vote.
 
And that vote shall and always will be towards 
getting shit done.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

“You’re going to New Hampshire? What country is that in?”
“New Mexico is in the US? I thought it was in Mexico.”
“I like to put unleaded gas in my car. I think it’s better for my car than diesel.”
“This guy is taking me to Disneyland but is only paying for one hotel room for us to stay in. I’m uncomfortable with it, but my mom said I had to, because of all the presents he’s given me.”
“My husband says you shouldn’t be nice to others because it’s like bragging and the Bible says that’s wrong.”
She was very pretty, bless her heart.

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:
If you're trying to lose weight: diet is always the first priority. So get that on track and everything else will come into place.
 
as for exercise, I assume you are a beginner, so you have a lot of lee-way. Anything will work. 
 
I do have a question for you though: do you even like running? or like yoga? and I won't ask about dancing, because everyone likes dancing, except liars. If you don't like running or yoga, then don't do them. For these same reason, if you don't like weight lifting then don't do it!
 
But, assuming you do enjoy and take pleasure in all of the above activities, it might be bes
Continue Reading
If you're trying to lose weight: diet is always the first priority. So get that on track and everything else will come into place.
 
as for exercise, I assume you are a beginner, so you have a lot of lee-way. Anything will work. 
 
I do have a question for you though: do you even like running? or like yoga? and I won't ask about dancing, because everyone likes dancing, except liars. If you don't like running or yoga, then don't do them. For these same reason, if you don't like weight lifting then don't do it!
 
But, assuming you do enjoy and take pleasure in all of the above activities, it might be best to just rotate them:
 
Day 1: Weights
 
Day 2: Run
 
Day3: Dance
 
Day 4: Yoga
 
Day 5: weights, etc. 
 
Take days off as needed. 
 
Tips: On weight days, lift heavy. Don't do high reps. When you lift heavy weights, you are forced to use good technique and pay attention. For this reason, heavier weights are safer. With light weights, people just mindlessly do reps and eventually develop elbow tendinitis or some other easily preventable condition. 
 
On run days, 
for best results
, don't just jog for 40 minutes straight. Do sprints, intervals, or do a stop-and-go-run where you go for a sprint, slow to a walk, and repeat over and over. Acceleration requires the most energy AND it will illicit a hormone response favorable to fat loss (weight loss is not all about calories!)
 
Hope that helps,
 
Nate

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Let’s see…
I have had quite a few Americans ask me why my country is so cold, mention things such as “Serbian rubies” and inquiry me about Vladimir Putin.
Why? They did not understand that Serbia - a small country in southeastern Europe - does not equal Siberia - the vast Russian province taking up most of Northern Asia.
Fifteen years ago, an American woman married to an Egyptian man who emigrated to USA, who took the last name of El Sayed, asked me if I am not dating because my parents don’t allow me to. I asked her where that came from and it turned out that she assumed Serbs were Muslims.

This did not happen to me, but it still counts. A friend from Paris went to Bilbao for a short vacation and she met some American tourists who tried to chat her up, over her T-shirt with JAPAN written on it. One of them asked her if she was particular to Japan because “it’s right next to France”.
Please, note that I have many American friends who are super-educated and that each country has a lot of dumb and ignorant people. We just didn’t know much about them before the internet.

title: Which 3 exercises would give me the most complete workout?
article:
CLEAN (full squat, not “power clean”)
 
PUSH PRESS (standing, overhead press with explosive leg drive)
 
CHIN UPS (hanging from a dead hang, TOUCH CHEST TO BAR (weighted))
 
ONE
 
The clean works grip, core, hams, glutes, quads, lumbar spine/lower back, lats (yes), spinal erectors, traps, neck and possible a little of biceps (when geting it down) and probably a ton of muscles I don’t even know about. It works those muscles explosively and in a natural, athletic fashion. It builds explosive strength from the floor, squat strength and quick hip flexion.
 
TWO
 
Push press has been showed to produce more rate of f
Continue Reading
CLEAN (full squat, not “power clean”)
 
PUSH PRESS (standing, overhead press with explosive leg drive)
 
CHIN UPS (hanging from a dead hang, TOUCH CHEST TO BAR (weighted))
 
ONE
 
The clean works grip, core, hams, glutes, quads, lumbar spine/lower back, lats (yes), spinal erectors, traps, neck and possible a little of biceps (when geting it down) and probably a ton of muscles I don’t even know about. It works those muscles explosively and in a natural, athletic fashion. It builds explosive strength from the floor, squat strength and quick hip flexion.
 
TWO
 
Push press has been showed to produce more rate of force development in the legs than squats or even cleans do. A shorts rom, but enough to give you power to jumpe, sprint etc (which is a short rom too if you break it down). With heavy weights over your head, everything under (back, core, glutes and ofc shoulders girdle) it has to stabilise it, like pillars holding a roof. It devolops massive triceps and delts, even traps and CHEST. Yes. The entire upper body except biceps and. Unlike chest presses, overhead presses develops the delt much much better, and works the meatiest part of the tricep more. You will have a more round chest (less down-heavy like benchers) and wider, rounder delts. Also produces less injury than benching due to more balansed development (and you can actually drop it on the floor, unlike a bench press..). The weight will be heavy AF on the way down since you used legs to get it up. Humans are stronger on exentric reps, and this exercise is actually HEAVIER for that part, which is unique. It may allow you to hold weights close to your max bench OVERHEAD and standing up. Possibly the #1 exercise of all time.
 
THREE
 
Weighted chins will develop the muscles that have already been hit, but not hammered. 2/3 of your torso muscles (or more) will be crushed. Biceps, forearms, lats, rhomboids, rear delts (which compensates for the push press), lower and middle traps, abs and even a bit of upper chest (according to studies). Can be done very heavy.
 
If you get to a 1.5x weight on all these exercises (on chins that means adding 50% of your own bw) for a few reps, you will not have any imbalance. Unlike squat bench and dead, these exercise includes explosive training. They will also give you better delts and traps and a more “masculine”chest. You will be more athletic with those, and more balanced. Squat bench dead has no upper body pulling to work biceps and rear delts, and the bench almost exclusively works the front part. Bad. Another benefit is that squats and deads have higher injury risk, but explosive movements with a moderate weight might build the same size without overloading soft tissue.
 
Please let me know what you think

article:
I want to clarify that these people aren’t ignorant about everything, but I have a few that have left me in awe. The first one was a girl I knew in Louisiana. She was getting married to a military guy, and wanted to be a good military wife. One of the local grocery stores in the small town she lived in had been purchased by someone described by her as a brown person. Number two may just be a personal pet peeve, we were talking about arguing and they said that facts were
Continue Reading
I want to clarify that these people aren’t ignorant about everything, but I have a few that have left me in awe. The first one was a girl I knew in Louisiana. She was getting married to a military guy, and wanted to be a good military wife. One of the local grocery stores in the small town she lived in had been purchased by someone described by her as a brown person. She had no idea what race they were, but she told me she no longer shopped there because she didn’t want to support terrorism.
 
Number two may just be a personal pet peeve, we were talking about arguing and they said that facts weren’t required for arguing a position. I spent the rest of the conversation informing them that they were an aligator, and that they couldn’t argue with my position, because that would require facts to prove otherwise. This same person also has a tendency to decide facts aren’t true if they don’t like the source. If I quote a study, they usually say it was probably a study by a liberal so it doesn’t count.
 
The next one is just kind of cute. It was a little older lady giving out samples of vegan chicken (meat substitute) at a Costco. She wanted to know how they could be sure a chicken never ate meat when everyone knows they love to eat bugs.
 
Number four is I was serving in a restaurant, and someone sent back their hash browns (shredded fried potatoes) because they tasted like potatoes.
 
This last one I’m not sure if it was a typo or just having the wrong definition for a word. I saw an ad for a roommate on craigslist, and it was “Female only, must be emasculate.”
 
*edited to add a few more as I remember them.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: Tales of “the South”: We moved from the West Coast to southern Appalachia about 20 years ago. We knew there were cultural differences, but we all live in the same country, right? Maybe . . . We shopped at a local store. The checkout girl, hearing the funny way we talk, asked, “Where y’all from?” “Washington State!” “Ain’t that near Manassas?”. The next time, different girl, same question. “Mah sister went to Washington!” “What did she see?” “The White House, The Lincoln Memor’al . . .”

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: The most ignorant American I have ever met was fellow who was visiting Nairobi in 1973 at the same time I was visiting my family. If a person is unaware, it is excusable in my view…if he were to find himself in a situation that was new, “foreign” , and did not ask and/or seek information regarding this issue..this would be ignorant act..innocent ignorance versus conscious /deliberate ignorance?!

article:

I went to a pretty good school, so general ignorance wasn’t a common trait, but each of these guys apparently had a terrifying gap in their ‘common knowledge’. (I should also say that both conversations were entirely unrelated, and neither of my friends knew each other). Using aliases for both. And I truly hate to have to affirm this, but apart from altering their names, every detail of these stories is true.
 
#1 - “Jeff” had his first ever serious girlfriend in his 
Continue Reading
I apologize for giving 2 scatological answers, but both are gems from friends of mine in college and I can’t really pick a winner. I went to a pretty good school, so general ignorance wasn’t a common trait, but each of these guys apparently had a terrifying gap in their ‘common knowledge’. (I should also say that both conversations were entirely unrelated, and neither of my friends knew each other). Using aliases for both. And I truly hate to have to affirm this, but apart from altering their names, every detail of these stories is true.
 
#1 - “Jeff” had his first ever serious girlfriend in his freshman year of college, and one day mentioned that he wasn’t sure what to do because he thought his girlfriend might have a really serious medical condition, but she didn’t seem to think it was at all serious and seemed embarrassed that he kept bringing it up. With a touch of prodding, I got him to share with me (it has been >15 years now and I’m using aliases, so I feel ok breaking the ‘confidence’) what was wrong.
 
As it turns out, she pooped. Like a guy. Because “Jeff” had been under the impression that women didn’t ever poop (though thankfully, he knew that they pee). When I asked what he thought happened with their waste that couldn’t be passed as urine, he said he just assumed there was some other way their bodies dealt with that.
 
#2 - “Kevin” and I were chatting about random things and it came up that I’m allergic to dogs. He told me that it was probably for the best, since dogs were disgusting animals. I assumed he took issue with the slobber, or maybe general hygiene, or even that some (I gather) eat their own vomit, poop, etc. Nope. He felt, very viscerally, that it was a perfect metaphor for the nature of a dog that it is born covered in feces. Because dogs are born through the anus. Because dogs don’t have vaginas, and get impregnated also through the anus.
 
His family owned dogs.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Very, very few. I have met ignorant people of all nations, including my native UK. As to Americans, those from the USA, very few stand out as a ignorant. I’ve met a lot of people from the USA over the years on their turf and on mine. The vast majority were absolutely spot on friendly people.
 
There might be 5 who have pissed me off, but this was down to working culture and shit throwing between themselves.
 
I would like to nominate two for joint first though.
 
We saved your asses in WW2
 
This was a bar in a hotel in the Netherlands. It was the regular stay for a lot of civilian contractors for a US ba
Continue Reading
Very, very few. I have met ignorant people of all nations, including my native UK. As to Americans, those from the USA, very few stand out as a ignorant. I’ve met a lot of people from the USA over the years on their turf and on mine. The vast majority were absolutely spot on friendly people.
 
There might be 5 who have pissed me off, but this was down to working culture and shit throwing between themselves.
 
I would like to nominate two for joint first though.
 
We saved your asses in WW2
 
This was a bar in a hotel in the Netherlands. It was the regular stay for a lot of civilian contractors for a US base close by. All except one, were truly good folks. We could laugh, joke and drink together in the bar and it was a warm ex-pat feel. The new guy decided to drop his limited overseas understanding out to the barmaid. Dotty knows my wife and kids and has given them loads of tips for stuff to do when I couldn’t get away from the office. The guy was a smoking hole after Dotty planted him with a tirade on things like pointing up the road, “you find me one American grave there, you won’t, and I can show you Canadians and British”. His colleagues were truly embarrassed for unleashing this prick on the locals without a briefing. I got a memory of the other folks having a laugh at dickhead’s expense and leaving Dotty a tip and an apology. One guy in the whole crowd was an ignorant American, the rest were simply a great bunch of folks.
 
What do you mean you don’t want my money?
 
This was a whiney east coaster in a cigar shop in Edinburgh. I’m perusing a couple of Cubans and this c#ck pushes ahead of me to the counter as his son wants a cigar and NOW. A middle aged guy in a nice suit was stood by the door. Whiney starts to bitch, moan and make squeaky noises at the counter staff and me. He would not shut up and was making a scene, but no-one really cared. All I wanted was to choose a selection, get it boxed, pay and leave. Whiney has to interrupt me every time I opened my mouth, even thought the rude little turd had shoved his way in. I get bored of bad manners very quickly. Turned to his attendant in the suit, “Bodyguard, minder, that kind of thing?”, Whiney was not engaged, just ranting at the counter folks and suit said with a gentle smile, “just the driver that the hotel provides”. “Excellent, could you tell your cargo that an apology or his teeth are the next things out his mouth?”. Whiney, simply did the third option and fucked off. I’m not saying that he got lot labelled as ignorant was because he was American, but because he was American and made a complete twat out of himself.
 
Summary
 
Out of the many folks I have met from the USA, I can only point to those two pricks above as outliers. There are others, but they would be dickheads anywhere on the planet.

He then looked into the Baptistry and said “Oh man it’s just another church. I’m not looking at another church!” and stormed out, leaving the broken bottle everywhere!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In 2006, my wife Jenn and I were on a Mediterranean cruise. One of our ports of call was Athens. On the bus ride from the ship to the Acropolis, we overheard the following conversation between two Americans (as best as I can recollect). The woman was from Texas, had a strong Southern drawl, was in her forties and had bleached blonde, big hair. The man was non-descript.
 
Texas Woman – Did you stay in Rome before boarding the ship?
 
Man – Yes, we did. We spent a couple of days there to see the sights. It was fantastic.
 
Texas – Did you see the Colosseum?
 
Man – Yes, it was unbelievable, just incredible.
Continue Reading
In 2006, my wife Jenn and I were on a Mediterranean cruise. One of our ports of call was Athens. On the bus ride from the ship to the Acropolis, we overheard the following conversation between two Americans (as best as I can recollect). The woman was from Texas, had a strong Southern drawl, was in her forties and had bleached blonde, big hair. The man was non-descript.
 
Texas Woman – Did you stay in Rome before boarding the ship?
 
Man – Yes, we did. We spent a couple of days there to see the sights. It was fantastic.
 
Texas – Did you see the Colosseum?
 
Man – Yes, it was unbelievable, just incredible. Did you go there?
 
Texas – Oh, no! I couldn’t go there! All I could think about were all of the Christians who died there. It’s a terrible place. All those poor martyrs for Jesus. I just wouldn’t feel comfortable going to such a place.
 
Incredulous, my wife and I just looked at each other. First of all, she's incorrect as almost every scholar of Ancient Rome or of Early Christianity has concluded that Christian martyrs were put to death at the Circus Maximus or other venues, not at the Colosseum. Even Christian authorities didn’t cite the Colosseum as a place of martyrdom until something like the 16th Century. Be that as it may, it astounded us that someone would pass up the chance to visit such an extraordinary place like the Colosseum for such a reason.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
The recommended frequency of exercise varies depending on factors such as age, fitness level, health status, and exercise goals. However, general guidelines suggest that adults should aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise per week, along with muscle-strengthening activities on two or more days per week.
 
For example:
Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise includes activities like brisk walking, cycling at a moderate pace, or water aerobics.
Vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise includes activities like running, swimming 
Continue Reading
The recommended frequency of exercise varies depending on factors such as age, fitness level, health status, and exercise goals. However, general guidelines suggest that adults should aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise per week, along with muscle-strengthening activities on two or more days per week.
 
For example:
Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise includes activities like brisk walking, cycling at a moderate pace, or water aerobics.
Vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise includes activities like running, swimming laps, or cycling at a fast pace.
Muscle-strengthening activities can include weightlifting, bodyweight exercises, or exercises that use resistance bands.
It's also beneficial to incorporate flexibility and balance exercises into your routine, especially for older adults, to improve overall mobility and reduce the risk of falls.
 
It's important to consult with a healthcare professional before starting any new exercise program, especially if you have any underlying health conditions or concerns. They can provide personalized recommendations based on your individual needs and circumstances.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
It doesn't make a significant difference, no. While it's true that anabolic hormones are naturally higher at night and shortly after we wake, they normalize for our waking state rather quickly. 
 
What matters FAR more is that you train, period. Morning or evening doesn't matter so much as making sure that you get in and do it, so pick the time that is going to allow you to be successful. The only bad workout is the one you skip. Don't major in the minors.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In 1972 I took a night train from Atocha station in Madrid to Lisbon.
 
I was in a second class car that had a bar in the back of the car just behind me. Having dozed off I was woken up around midnight by a loud voice.
 
It was the voice of an American lady who must have been at least seventy years old, wearing a bright yellow mini-dress, sitting on a bar stool, and loudly berating the attendant in English because he couldn’t prepare the cocktail that she wanted.

So I had just recently moved to America and was at my first day of middle school. My homeroom teacher had asked two girls to help me find my locker.
 
On our way, they asked a bunch of questions.
 
1.) Do you speak Indian? (Facepalm….later that month dozens of people asked me the same thing)
 
2.) Why do you know English (omg person, you can't just ask someone why they know English)
 
Next we walked back to the class and had to say the American pledge when the morning announcements started. I told them that I didn't know the words. Response?
 
3.) Well the words are on the screen but OMG why don't you know the pledge ? Wow your country is really weird to not know the AMERICAN pledge.
 
Facepalm.
 
Later that day in class, I saw
 
1.) China being labelled Russia (and vice versa)
 
2.) Math teacher asking me if I know any math (since I come from a country no one has heard of)
 
3.) Tons of people asking 1 and 2 from above
 
4.) Heard Milky Way was a planet
 
5.) More weird map labelling
 
American people aren't all ignorant, just that all who are seemed to be accumulated at my middle school…
 
Edit: I'm in high school now. I was on the way back home from school in my bus when I heard this conversation:
 
Girl: You're brown so you're Jewish right?
 
Boy: No I'm not, I'm Indian.
 
Girl: How do you say 'young' in Jewish?
 
Boy: I don't know cause I don't speak Jewish. I'm Indian I told you.
 
These are juniors/seniors in high school.
 
Facepalm.
